revision.text:
{{Indigenous Peoples of Canada}} The '''Indian Health Transfer Policy''' of [[Canada]], provided a framework for the assumption of control of health services by [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|Aboriginal Canadians]] and set forth a developmental approach to transfer centred on the concept of self-determination in health.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XWbF_tfYUuEC&pg=PA215&lpg=PA215&dq=Indian+Health+Transfer+Policy+in+canadal&source=bl&ots=SLL8UWqmnS&sig=swsX5CK_9WsknURGPZVkHNNnwPM&hl=en&ei=jhXBSt7ZNYya8AbXiq2lAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3#v=onepage&q=&f=false|title=Unhealthy health policy: a critical anthropological examination|work=By Arachu Castro, Merrill Singer}}</ref> Through this process, the decision to enter into transfer discussions with [[Health Canada]] rests with each community. Once involved in transfer, communities are able to take control of health program responsibilities at a pace determined by their individual circumstances and health management capabilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fniah-spnia/alt_formats/fnihb-dgspni/pdf/pubs/agree-accord/1999_finance_integr-eng.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130111060520/http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fniah-spnia/alt_formats/fnihb-dgspni/pdf/pubs/agree-accord/1999_finance_integr-eng.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-11 |title=Financing a First Nations and Inuit Integrated Health System |work=Heallth Canada }}</ref>
== Background == {{See also|The Canadian Crown and Aboriginal peoples}} To put [[Canada Health Transfer|Health Transfer]] in context, it is useful to understand from a historical perspective how [[First Nations]], [[Inuit]], [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] and the [[Government of Canada|Federal Government]] through [[Indian and Northern Affairs Canada|Indian and Northern Affairs]] have worked together to respond to Aboriginal peoples expressed desire to manage and control their own health programs.
=== 1969 White Paper === {{Main|1969 White Paper}} Federal Government [[Policy]] Paper which proposed to remove the status of treaty individuals under the [[Indian Act]] and to discontinue special services so identified, advocating the increased assimilation of Indigenous people into the [[culture of Canada]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.danielnpaul.com/Canada'sWhitePaper1969.html|title=CANADIAN GOVERNMENT'S 1969 WHITE PAPER|work= Dr. Daniel N Paul, C.M., O.N.S., Hon.D.Litt}}</ref>
===1970 Red Paper=== Aboriginal response to the White Paper emphasizing federal responsibility for [[health care]] to First Nation peoples and emphasizing plans to strengthen community control of their lives and of government-delivered community programs.<ref name="cast"/>
===1975 Indian Relationships Paper=== The White and Red Papers served as an impetus for the collaborative effort of the Federal Government and Aboriginal to begin serious planning for the future.<ref name="cast">Castile, George Pierre Taking Charge: Native American Self-Determination and Federal Indian Policy, 1975-1993 Tucson: The University of Arizona Press 168p, {{ISBN|0-8165-2542-0}} Publication Date: September 2006</ref>
This resulted in the 1975 paper, The Canadian Government/The Canadian Indian Relationships, which defined a policy framework for strengthening Indian control of programs and services. In the health sector, under contribution agreements 75% of the Bands became responsible for such programs as the Native Alcohol and Drug Abuse Program and the Community Health Representative Program.<ref name="cast"/>
===1979 Indian Health Policy===
The stated goal of the Indian Health Policy adopted by the Federal Government on September 19, 1979, is "to achieve an increasing level of health in Indian communities, generated and maintained by the Indian communities themselves". In this regard the policy recognized the historic responsibilities of both federal and provincial governments in providing health services to First Nations and Inuit people, and it removed the issue of treaty rights from health policy considerations to where it rightly belonged – [[Indian Affairs]]. The policy reasoned that improvements to the health status of the Indian population should be built on three pillars: (1) community development, both socio-economic and cultural/spiritual, to remove the conditions which limit the attainment of well-being; (2) the traditional trust relationship between Indian people and the federal government; and (3) the interrelated Canadian health system, with its federal, provincial, municipal, Indian and private sectors.<ref name="healt"/>
A further important aspect of the new policy was the recognition that First Nation and Inuit communities could take over any or all aspect(s) of the administration of their own community health programs, at their discretion and with the support of the Department of National Health and Welfare.<ref>Hogg, P. and M.E. Turpel. "Implementing Aboriginal Self-Government: Constitutional and Jurisdictional Issues." The Canadian Bar Review. Vol. 74, No. 2, June 1995, p. 187-2</ref>
===1980 (Berger Report)=== The report of the Advisory Committee on Indian and Inuit Health Consultation known as the "Berger Report". Recommended methods of consultation that would ensure substantive participation by First Nations and Inuit people in the design, management and control of health care services in their communities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fniah-spnia/pubs/finance/_agree-accord/10_years_ans_trans/2_intro-eng.php|title= Ten Years of Health Transfer First Nation and Inuit Control|work=health Canada}}</ref>
=== 1983 (Penner Report) === The Report of the Special Committee on Indian Self-Government knows as the "Penner Report" recommended that the Federal government establish a new relationship with First Nations and Inuit people and that an essential element of this relationship be recognition of Indian Self-Government. The report identified health as a key area for takeover.<ref name="firm">{{cite web|url=http://www.sicc.sk.ca/saskindian/a84apr22.htm|title=The Impact Of The Penner Report|work=Law Firm of Soonias and Pennington}}</ref>
=== 1983-86 Community Health Projects === First Nations and Inuit Health Branch sponsored demonstration projects for First Nations. The experiment was initiated to provide both Federal and First Nation authorities with the same substantive information with respect to First Nation control of health services.<ref name="firm"/>
=== 1986 The Sechelt Band Self-Government Act === The Sechelt Indian Band Self-Government Act was passed by Parliament in 1986. In April of the following year, the British Columbia Legislative Assembly unanimously passed a bill to give the Sechelt community municipal status. Consequently, the Sechelt Indian Band signed the first Self-Government agreement in which a First Nation community assumed control of their health services.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canlii.org/en/ca/laws/stat/sc-1986-c-27/latest/sc-1986-c-27.html |title=Sechelt Indian Band Self-Government Act, S.C. 1986, c. 27|work=Federation of Law Societies of Canada}}</ref>
=== 1988 Health Transfer South of the 60th Parallel === In order for First Nations and Inuit Health Branch to proceed with health transfer to First Nations as part of administrative reform, the policy framework, authorities and resources had to be developed and secured. A Subcommittee on the Transfer of Health Programs to Indian Control was established with representation from First Nations with experience in health care. The Subcommittee incorporated the experiences from the Community Health Projects and recommended a developmental and consultative approach for health transfer. These recommendations were then used to finalize the health transfer policy framework.<ref name="white">Cameron, K. and G. White. Northern Governments in Transition: Political and Constitutional Developments in the Yukon, Nunavut and the Western Northwest Territories. The Institute for Research on Public Policy, Montreal, 1995.</ref>
On March 16, 1988, the Federal Government Cabinet approved the health transfer policy framework for transferring resources for Indian health programs south of the 60th parallel to Indian control through a process which:<ref name="white"/>
permits health program control to be assumed at a pace determined by the community, i.e., the community can assume control gradually over a number of years through a phased transfer; enables communities to design health programs to meet their needs; requires that certain mandatory public health and treatment programs be provided; strengthens the accountability of Chiefs and Councils to community members; gives communities: the financial flexibility to allocate funds according to community health priorities and to retain unspent balances; the responsibility for eliminating deficits and for annual financial audits and evaluations at specific intervals; permits multi-year (three to five year) agreements; does not prejudice treaty or Aboriginal rights; operates within current legislation; is optional and open to all First Nation communities south of the 60th parallel.
=== 1989 Treasury Board Authorities for Transfer === In 1989, Treasury Board approved the financial authorities and resources to support pre-transfer planning and to fund community health management structures.<ref>Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples, Aboriginal Self-Government: Legal and Constitutional Issues. Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples, Ottawa, 1999</ref>
== Process == The process is designed to occur within the present funding base of federal health programs for [[First Nations]], [[Inuit]] and [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] peoples. Communities are required to provide certain mandatory programs such as communicable disease control, environmental and occupational health and safety programs, and treatment services.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fniah-spnia/pubs/finance/index-eng.php#agree-accord |title=Funding - Reports and Publications |work=Health Canada}}</ref>
Initially, the enthusiasm for this process was varied. For some, it was seen as an important link to [[Self-Government]] where the community plans and controls health programs in their communities according to its own priorities. It was seen as a way to develop programs relevant to a community's own cultural and social needs. Others took a more hesitant approach. As the uptake of control of health services by First Nations increased, the Indian Health Transfer Policy began to be seen increasingly by First Nations people as a stepping stone towards the inherent right of Self-Government.<ref name="healt">{{cite book |title=Aboriginal health in Canada: historical, cultural, and epidemiological |url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=O-jBWP_HgT8C&oi=fnd&pg=PR9&dq=Aboriginal+health+in+Canada:+historical,+cultural,+and+epidemiological&ots=xUvBrZUKlN&sig=dCHefz8KNuzAzZqU82wdnqRKdQI#v=onepage&q=&f=false|work=By James Burgess Waldram, Ann Herring, T. Kue Young}}</ref> Transfer became the cornerstone of [[Health Canada]]'s relationship with First Nations and Inuit communities. Health Services Transfer Agreements between Health Canada and First Nation and Inuit provided the opportunity for communities or First Nations and Inuit organizations to manage their own health programs and services. At first, Transfer was the only option communities had for increasing their control over health programs and services beyond Contribution Agreements. Although many communities were interested in assuming increased control over health services and programs, not all communities were ready to move into this level of control so quickly. It became increasingly apparent that one design could not fit all the diversity of readiness. Some communities expressed interest in alternative strategies which would also give them increased control of resources.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usask.ca/nursing/aboriginalglossary/i.htm|title=Aboriginal Health & Cultural Diversity Glossary|work=usask}}</ref>
Each year brought pressures for change and restructure in the transfer approach. First Nations and Inuit Health Branch searched for ways to respond to communities desiring to increase their control of community resources, either through the transfer process, or through other initiatives. This movement was further supported by a decision of the Departmental Executive Committee of Health Canada on March 15, 1994, which directed First Nations and Inuit Health Branch to commence planning all activities toward the following goals:
the devolution of all existing First Nations and Inuit Health Branch Indian health resources to First Nations and Inuit control within a time frame to be determined during consultations with First Nations and Inuit communities; moving First Nations and Inuit Health Branch out of the health care service delivery business; the transfer of knowledge and capacity to First Nation and Inuit communities so that they can manage and administer their health resources; a refocused role for First Nations and Inuit Health Branch; and a refocused role for Health Canada which will take into account First Nations and Inuit Health Branch's strategic direction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/ahc-asc/branch-dirgen/fnihb-dgspni/poli_1979-eng.php |title=Indian Health Policy 1979|work=Health Canada}}</ref>
In further support the search for alternative pathways to transfer, in late 1994, [[Treasury Board]] approved the Integrated Community-Based Health Services Approach as a second transfer option for communities to move into a limited level of control over health services.<ref>Canada, Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development. Federal Policy Guide, Aboriginal Self-Government: The Government of Canada’s Approach to the Implementation of the Inherent Right and the Negotiation of Aboriginal Self-Government. Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, Ottawa, 199</ref>
1995 saw the distribution and implementation of Pathways to First Nations Control Report of Project 07 Strategic Planning Exercise. This cornerstone document set the essential differences between The Integrated Approach and Transfer. The Integrated Approach is an intermediate measure which provides more flexibility than Contribution Agreements, but less flexibility than the Transfer Agreement.<ref>Canada. House of Commons Special Committee on Indian Self-Government. Second Report: Indian Self-Government in Canada. 1st Session, 32nd Parliament, Issue No. 40.</ref>
In 1995, the [[Government of Canada|federal government]] announced the inherent Right to Self-Government Policy . This policy recognizes First Nations and Inuit have the constitutional right to shape their own forms of government to suit their particular historical, cultural, political and economic circumstances. The policy thus introduced a third option for communities to further increase their control of health services.<ref>Hamilton, A.C. A New Partnership: Report of the Honourable A.C. Hamilton, Fact Finder. Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, Ottawa, 1995.</ref>
Self-governance gives Bands more flexibility to establish program priorities in response to tribal needs rather than following Federal program objectives. Bands are able to expand, consolidate and create new programs to improve services to their communities and to make certain laws governing their community with respect to health. Furthermore, the range of resources for health programs which can be included in a Self-Government arrangement is greater than those included in a Health Service Transfer arrangement and may eventually include fixed assets and services under the [[Non-Insured Health Benefits]] Program.<ref>Green, Joyce. "Constitutionalising the Patriarchy: Aboriginal Women and Aboriginal Government." 4 Constitutional Forum 110, Summer 1993.</ref> The flexibility in terms of how resources are allocated is also greater and reporting requirements are fewer.<ref>Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, 1999-2000 Estimates, Part III – Report on Plans and Priorities, p. 11</ref>
First Nations and Inuit peoples will determine the pace at which Self-Government arrangements proceed. Putting the arrangements in place will of course take time. The process will require intense local or regional negotiations between First Nations and Inuit peoples, the federal government and the provincial or territorial government concerned. Figure 3 depicts the status of First Nations and Inuit control activities at the close of the first decade of transfer, March 31, 1999. The uptake of transfer has steadily increased over the past decade the maps on figure 3 present a progressive overview of the rate of uptake of transfer by First Nation and Inuit communities starting in year one.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://caid.ca/IndHeaPol1979.pdf|title=About Health Canada. Indian Health Policy|work=The Federal Indian Health policy }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Aboriginal peoples in Canada}} *[[Canada Health Act]] *[[Canada Health and Social Transfer]] *[[First Nations and diabetes]] *[[Health care in Canada]] *[[Indian Act]] *[[National Aboriginal Health Organization]] *[[Numbered Treaties]] *[[Royal Commission on the Future of Health Care in Canada]] *[[First Nations Health Authority]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070220013037/http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fnih-spni/pubs/agree-accord/10_years_ans_trans/3_transfert_e.html Health Canada (2008),a. Ten Years of Health Transfer First Nation and Inuit Control] *[https://archive.is/20070813194243/http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fnih-spni/pubs/agree-accord/10_years_ans_trans/2_intro_e.html Health Canada (2008),b. Ten Years of Health Transfer First Nation and Inuit Control] {{Canadian Aboriginal case law}} {{Indigenous rights footer}}

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2604:2000:6B56:9B00:DD17:A82F:CB99:955C|2604:2000:6B56:9B00:DD17:A82F:CB99:955C]] ([[User talk:2604:2000:6B56:9B00:DD17:A82F:CB99:955C|talk]]) to last revision by Jmertel23. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
An '''infection rate''' (or incident rate) is the [[probability]] or [[risk]] of an [[infection]] in a [[population]]. It is used to measure the [[Rate (mathematics)|frequency of occurrence]] of new instances of infection within a population during a specific time period.
[[File:Infection rate formula.jpg|center|500px||A formula that describes the incidence of infection within a population]]
The number of infections equals the cases identified in the study or observed. An example might by [[HIV|HIV infection]] during a specific time period in the defined population. The population at risk are the cases appearing in the population during the same time period. An example would be all the people in a city during a specific time period. The constant, or K is assigned a value of 100 to represent a percentage. An example would be to find the percentage of people in a city who are infected with HIV: 6,000 cases in March divided by the population of a city (one million) multiplied by the constant (K) would give an infection rate of 0.6%. . Calculating the infection rate is used to analyze trends for the purpose of infection and disease control.<ref>{{cite web | title = Calculation of Infection Rates|url = http://health.utah.gov/epi/diseases/HAI/resources/Cal_Inf_Rates.pdf |publisher = Utah Department of Health|date= 2017| accessdate = 2017-01-09 }}</ref>
An online infection rate calculator has been developed by the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] that allows the determination of the [[Streptococcus|Streptococcal A infection]] rate in a population.<ref>{{cite web | title = Group A Streptococcus Calculator | publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention |date= 4 July 2008 |url = https://www2a.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/abcs/calc/calc_new/calculator.html | accessdate = 2017-01-09 }}</ref>
==Clinical applications== [[Health facility|Health care facilities]] routinely track their infection rates according to the guidelines issued by the [[Joint Commission]].<ref>{{cite web | title= Basic Statistical Data Used in Acute Care Facilities | publisher = JB Learning | url = http://www.jblearning.com/samples/0763750344/45561_CH01.pdf | accessdate = 2017-01-09 }}</ref> The [[Hospital-acquired infection|healthcare-associated infection]] (HAI) rates measure infection of patients in a particular hospital. This allows rates to compared with other hospitals. These infections can often be [[Infection control|prevented]] when healthcare facilities follow guidelines for safe care. To get payment from [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]], hospitals are required to report data about some infections to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s (CDC’s) National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN). Hospitals currently submit information on [[Central line-associated bloodstream infection|central line-associated bloodstream infections]] (CLABSIs), [[Catheter-associated urinary tract infection|catheter-associated urinary tract infections]] (CAUTIs), [[Surgical site infection|surgical site infections]] (SSIs), [[Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus|MRSA Bacteremia]], and ''[[Clostridium difficile (bacteria)|C. difficile]]'' laboratory-identified events. The public reporting of these data is an effort by the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|Department of Health and Human Services]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Healthcare-Associated Infections (HAI) data | publisher = Medicare.gov| url = https://www.medicare.gov/hospitalcompare/Data/Healthcare-Associated-Infections.html | accessdate = 2017-01-09 }}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
For meaningful comparisons of infection rates, populations must be very similar between the two or more assessments. However, a problem with mean rates is that they cannot reflect differences in risk between populations,<ref>{{cite web | title= NHSN Standardized Infection Ratio |url = https://www.cdc.gov/nhsn/pdfs/ps-analysis-resources/nhsn-sir-guide.pdf | accessdate = 2017-01-09 | date= December 2016 }}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://shea-online.org The Society for Healthcare Epidemiology of America] epidemiologists or physicians in infection control. * [http://www.apic.org Association for Professionals in Infection Control and Epidemiology] infection prevention and control professionals. * [http://www.cbic.org The Certification Board of Infection Control and Epidemiology, Inc.]
{{Public health}} {{Occupational safety and health}}
[[Category:Epidemiology]] [[Category:Medical hygiene]] [[Category:Public health]] [[Category:Infectious diseases]]
{{Med-stub}}

The '''Integrated Opisthorchiasis Control Program''', commonly known as the "Lawa Project", located in [[Khon Kaen Province]], [[Thailand]], is an effort to reduce chronic infection by the Southeast Asian [[liver fluke]] (''[[Opisthorchis viverrini]]'') among the native peoples of [[Isan]] ({{lang-th|อีสาน}}; {{rtgs|''isan''}}), the northeast region of Thailand.<ref name=Sripa2015>{{cite journal|last1=Sripa|first1=Banchob|last2=Tangkawattana|first2=Sirikachorn|last3=Laha|first3=Thewarach|last4=Kaewkes|first4=Sasithorn|last5=Mallory|first5=Frank F.|last6=Smith|first6=John F.|last7=Wilcox|first7=Bruce A.|title=Toward integrated opisthorchiasis control in northeast Thailand: The Lawa project|journal=Acta Tropica|date=January 2015|volume=141|pages=361–367|doi=10.1016/j.actatropica.2014.07.017|pmc=4454771}}</ref> The project operates under the aegis of the Tropical Disease Research Laboratory, Department of Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, [[Khon Kaen University]]. It is directed by [[Banchob Sripa]]. Its aim is to eliminate the practice of consuming raw or undercooked fish, the major cause of [[opisthorchiasis|liver fluke infection]] and [[cholangiocarcinoma|bile duct cancer]] in the region. The project is unique in that it follows the principles of [[EcoHealth]], a [[One Health]] approach to improving human and animal health. The project has been the subject of newspaper and TV reports by BBC, ''The New York Times'', and ''The Guardian''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Holmes|first1=Oliver|title=Thai doctor fights against carcinogenic raw fish dish that killed his parents|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jun/28/thai-doctor-fights-against-carcinogenic-raw-fish-dish-that-killed-his-parents|work=The Guardian|accessdate=24 January 2018|language=en|date=28 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Head|first1=Jonathan|title=Thailand's deadly fish dish|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/health-33095945|work=BBC News|accessdate=24 January 2018|date=13 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Fuller|first1=Thomas|title=In Thailand, a Treasured Delicacy That Can Prove to Be Deadly|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940CE3DC1F31F934A15757C0A9679D8B63|work=The New York Times|accessdate=23 January 2018|date=27 April 2011}}</ref>
==The area and population== The project area consists of several villages around the ''Kaeng Lawa'' (Thai: แก่งละว้า), a lake and wetlands about 25 kilometers south of the city of Khon Kaen. The people's primary occupations are rice farming and fishing. The lake is a source of the [[Cyprinidae|cyprinid]] fish that the locals consume raw in dishes known as ''[[Koi (dish)|koi pla]]'' and ''pla som'', which are often infested with the cysts or [[metacercariae]] of the liver fluke. Cats and dogs also ingest the fish, making them hosts for the fluke. Northeast Thailand still has the highest incidence of bile duct cancer in the world,<ref>{{cite web|title=World Cholangiocarcinoma Day 2018 CCA: The statistics|url=http://worldcholangiocarcinomaday.org/the-statistics/|website=worldcholangiocarcinomaday.org|accessdate=25 January 2018}}</ref> and the prevalence of ''O. viverrini'' infection in some villages in Khon Kaen Province has reached 100 percent.<ref name=Sripa2015/> <!--Kaeng Lawa (Kaeng Lawa) is a lake (class H - Hydrographic) in Changwat Khon Kaen (Khon Kaen), Thailand (Asia) with the region font code of Asia/Pacific. It is located at an elevation of 155 meters above sea level.
Its coordinates are 16°9'0" N and 102°40'59" E in DMS (Degrees Minutes Seconds) or 16.15 and 102.683 (in decimal degrees). Its UTM position is TC58 and its Joint Operation Graphics reference is NE48-13.
Current local time is 14:31; the sun rises at 08:08 and sets at 20:16 local time (Asia/Bangkok UTC/GMT+7). The standard time zone for Kaeng Lawa is UTC/GMT+7 --> [[File:VillagehealthvolunteersfromLAWAproject.jpg|thumb|Village health volunteers teaching children about liver fluke infection]] <!-- {{Information |Description = {{en|A village health volunteer teaching children about liver fluke infection.}} |Source = from Banchob Sripa who posted it on Facebook |Author = Banchob Sripa |Permission = '''Evidence:''' The license agreement has been forwarded to OTRS. Ticket: 2018041210001551{{OTRS pending|year={{subst:CURRENTYEAR}}|month={{subst:CURRENTMONTH}}|day={{subst:CURRENTDAY2}}}} }} -->
==Lawa model== The first attempts at opisthorchiasis control in Thailand began in the 1950s and included education on liver fluke infection and safe cooking, but these efforts had limited success since the consumption of raw fish dishes is an ingrained part of the rice-fish culture of the indigenous people.<ref name=Sripa2017>{{cite journal|last1=Sripa|first1=Banchob|last2=Echaubard|first2=Pierre|title=Prospects and Challenges towards Sustainable Liver Fluke Control|journal=Trends in Parasitology|date=October 2017|volume=33|issue=10|pages=799–812|doi=10.1016/j.pt.2017.06.002}}</ref> With the introduction of [[praziquantel]] in the 1980s, treatment became a part of the program. The prevalence of infection was reduced, but after funding reductions during the [[1997 Asian financial crisis|economic crises]] in the 1990s, prevalence rates rose again to as high as 85 percent in some areas of the northeast by 2009.<ref name=Sripa2015 /> In 2007, researchers at Khon Kaen University, led by Banchob Sripa, decided to take a more multidisciplinary approach, incorporating EcoHealth principles, which involve the collaboration of human and animal health specialists toward improving the health of people, animals and the environment as well as achieving greater understanding of how the ecosystem affects human and animal health.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sripa|first1=Banchob|last2=Tangkawattana|first2=Sirikachorn|last3=Sangnikul|first3=Thinnakorn|title=The Lawa model: A sustainable, integrated opisthorchiasis control program using the EcoHealth approach in the Lawa Lake region of Thailand|journal=Parasitology International|date=August 2017|volume=66|issue=4|pages=346–354|doi=10.1016/j.parint.2016.11.013}}</ref> The "Lawa model" as it became known, involves community participation as a key element. Village health volunteers, staff of local sub-district hospitals, teachers, and others maintain a campaign of continuous education, teaching in the community and the schools about liver fluke disease and discouraging the consumption of raw or undercooked fish. The campaigns often involve "edutainment" activities (songwriting, dancing, and music) to attract public attention.
==Benefits== After implementation of the Lawa model, the prevalence of infection declined from 67 percent to 16 percent over three years in Lawa village with little reinfection after treatment, a common reason for failure in the past.<ref name = Sripa2015/> An intensive program in nine schools in the village reduced infection to undetectable levels. In 2012, the schools were certified as liver fluke free. Infection typically begins in childhood, leading to the lifelong chronic infection that often results in cancer.
An analysis conducted by the university on the [[social return on investment]] estimates a return of 3.47 relative to resources invested, with the primary benefit going to villagers and especially the children of the students who should avoid a lifetime of chronic infection and its possible consequences.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sarnwong|first1=Auttapan|title=Analysis of Social Return on Investment Integrated Opisthorchiasis Control Using the EcoHealth/ One Health Approach (Lawa Project)|date=June 2017|publisher=Office of the Research Promotion Program in Higher Education and National Research Universities}}</ref> Such projects are hard to assess solely on the basis of an economic analysis.
== References == <!-- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags, these references will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x19jhxafGPQ&feature=youtu.be Lawa model: a WHO CC showcase ] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQy5n8G-maM&feature=youtu.be Liver fluke report for Khun Banchob ] * [https://www.kku.ac.th/news/v.php?q=0002192&l=en KKU reveals the Lawa project]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Integrated Opisthorchiasis Control Program, or Lawa Project in northeast Thailand}}

{{Infobox lake | name = Lake Tisza | image = Tisza-t%C3%B3.jpg | caption = | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = | coords = {{coord|47|36|N|20|40|E|type:waterbody_region:HU|display=inline,title}} | lake_type = [[reservoir]] | inflow = [[Tisza River]] | outflow = [[Tisza River]] | catchment = | basin_countries = Hungary | length = {{convert|27|km|abbr=on}} | width = | area = {{convert|127|km2|abbr=on}} | depth = {{convert|1.3|m|abbr=on}} | max-depth = {{convert|17|m|abbr=on}} | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = | cities = }} '''Lake Tisza''' ({{lang-hu|Tisza-tó}}), also known as '''Kisköre Reservoir''' (Hungarian: ''Kiskörei-víztározó''), is the largest [[artificial lake]] in [[Hungary]]. It is located at the southeastern edge of [[Heves (county)|Heves county]], next to counties [[Borsod-Abaúj-Zemplén]], [[Hajdú-Bihar]] and [[Jász-Nagykun-Szolnok]].
As part of the ongoing [[Tisza River]] [[flood]] control project, the [[Tisza Dam]] was built in 1973. Its filling was finished in the 1990s, resulting a 127 km² [[lake]]. The lake is 27 km in length, with an average depth of 1.3 m and a maximum depth of 17 m; it contains 43 km² of small [[island]]s.
Following the [[reservoir (water)|reservoir's]] completion, Hungarians began to flock to the site for holidays, since it compared favorably with the crowded and expensive [[Lake Balaton]], the traditional holiday site. As a result, [[tourist]] infrastructure has been developed on the reservoir—renamed Lake Tisza—and the [[Politics of Hungary|government]] has designated it an official tourism destination.
The lake (or reservoir) has a new local [[ecology]] with a diversity of [[birds]], [[plant]]s, and [[animal]]s.
Lake Tisza Ecocentre in Poroszló was erected to collect and display the [[nature]] and [[wildlife]] of the Tisza River valley and Lake Tisza. It was opened to the public on 27 April 2012.
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081130031605/http://www.tiszato.hu/ Webpage of the lake] * [http://www.tiszataviokocentrum.hu/en/ Webpage of Lake Tisza Ecocentre] * [http://en.funiq.hu/tisza-to Lake Tisza at funiq.hu]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Theiss, Lake}} [[Category:Reservoirs in Hungary]] [[Category:Lakes of Hungary]] [[Category:Geography of Heves County]] {{Hungary-geo-stub}}

revision.text:
[[Lone worker]] monitoring is the practice of monitoring the safety of employees who may be exposed to risk due to work conditions in which they are located out of sight and sound from a person who may be able to offer aid in the event of an emergency.
==Legislation== In some areas including the United Kingdom<ref>[http://www.bsia.co.uk/web_images/securitenews/288_lone_workers_employers_guide.pdf]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, BSIA Lone Workers guide for Employers</ref> Australian States<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.worksafe.qld.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0003/58206/managing-work-environment-facilities-cop-2011.pdf|title=Queensland - Managing the work environment and facilities Code of Practice 2011|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405150601/https://www.worksafe.qld.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0003/58206/managing-work-environment-facilities-cop-2011.pdf|archive-date=2015-04-05|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.commerce.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/atoms/files/working_alone.pdf|title=Western Australia - Guidance Note Working Alone 2009|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.worksafe.vic.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/9555/WS_MIA_WORKING_ALONE_WEB.pdf|title=Victoria - Working Alone Information Sheet|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705132014/http://www.worksafe.vic.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/9555/WS_MIA_WORKING_ALONE_WEB.pdf|archive-date=2013-07-05|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref> and certain Provinces in Canada,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://humanservices.alberta.ca/documents/WHS-PUB_wa001.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130604041043/http://humanservices.alberta.ca/documents/WHS-PUB_wa001.pdf |archivedate=2013-06-04 |df= }}, Working Alone (Part 28 of the Occupational Health and Safety Code)</ref><ref>[http://www2.worksafebc.com/publications/ohsregulation/part4.asp], WorkSafeBC OHS Regulations General Conditions Part 4</ref><ref>[http://safemanitoba.com/sites/default/files/uploads/regulations/part9.pdf], Workplace Health and Safety Regulation</ref><ref>[http://www.qp.gov.sk.ca/documents/English/Regulations/Regulations/O1-1R1.pdf], The Occupational Health and Safety Regulations</ref> legislation has driven the adoption of lone worker policies as well as methods of monitoring the safety of these employees. In the United States, no explicit legislation exists regarding an employer's obligation to monitor the safety of its lone or isolated employees except in the shipbuilding industry.<ref>[https://www.osha.gov/Publications/OSHA_FS_3591.pdf], OSHA Shipbuilding Factsheet</ref>
==Methods of Monitoring Lone Worker Safety== Numerous methods have been developed and are currently in use by companies world-wide. These methods include: * '''Phone-based check-in systems.''' Employees are required to call in to a designated receiver after a predetermined time. Check-ins are often performed hourly or bi-hourly. The two approaches to phone-based check-in systems are call centre-driven and cloud-based automated monitoring, which may use a [[Software as a service|software-as-a-service]] (SaaS) model. * '''Buddy systems.''' Employees may be paired up to perform certain tasks. Theoretically, should an emergency occur and one of the employees be rendered incapacitated, the other would remain available to call for help and provide aid. * '''Safety monitoring smartphone applications.''' With the widespread adoption of [[smart phones]], the deployment of a dedicated application allowing employees to quickly request aid has become more feasible. These applications may provide a [[panic button]] or allow for prompt check-in without requiring a phone call to be made. * '''Safety monitoring devices.''' Dedicated monitoring devices for monitoring local environmental conditions, such as dangerous levels of gases, that smartphone-based Lone Worker monitoring solutions are unable to account for.
==See also== * [[Lone worker]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.hse.gov.uk/contact/faqs/workalone.htm Health and Safety Executive - Can a person be left alone at their place of work?] *[http://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/hsprograms/workingalone.html Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and Safety - Working Alone - General]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lone Worker}} [[Category:Occupational safety and health]]

{{Infobox Officeholder | name = MaryAnn Baenninger | image = Mary ann baenninger.jpg | order = 12th President of [[Drew University]] | office = | term_start = July 21, 2014 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Robert Weisbuch]] | successor = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|yyyy|mm|dd}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[Temple University]] <small>(B.A. & Ph.D.)</small> | residence = [[Madison, New Jersey]] | profession = [[Academia|Academics]] | website = {{url|www.drew.edu/president|Office of the President}} |}}
'''MaryAnn Baenninger''' is a [[psychology]] professor and president of [[Drew University]], a Methodist-affiliated [[liberal arts college]] in [[Madison, New Jersey]].
==Life== Baenninger received a [[Bachelor of Arts]] (B.A.) and [[Doctor of Philosophy]] (Ph.D.) in Psychology from [[Temple University]] in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cur.org/bio/atlarge_bio21.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080807161712/http://cur.org/bio/atlarge_bio21.html |archivedate=2008-08-07}}</ref> After serving as a psychology professor on the faculty of [[The College of New Jersey]] (formerly [[Trenton State College]]) in [[Ewing, New Jersey]], and as an executive associate director with the [[Middle States Commission on Higher Education]] in Philadelphia, Baenninger was appointed as president of [[College of Saint Benedict and Saint John's University|College of Saint Benedict]] in [[Saint Joseph, Minnesota]] in 2004. During her tenure at the private Roman Catholic college for women, Baenninger is "credited with building out the school’s study abroad programs, attracting international students and supporting undergraduate research. She also won praise for diversifying the student body and more than doubling the school’s endowment." In February 2014, Drew University's board of trustees chose Baenninger<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drew.edu/news/2014/02/24/drew-names-maryann-baenninger-as-next-president|title=Drew Names MaryAnn Baenninger as Next President - Drew Today - Drew University|publisher=|accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref> as its first full-term female president. She succeeded Vivian A. Bull, who had replaced Robert Weisbuch on an interim basis after he stepped down in June 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2012/05/drew_university_president_step.html|title=Drew University president stepping down from post|accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref>
Baenninger is married to Ron Baenninger, a retired Temple University psychology professor.<ref>Ron Baenninger. [http://www.insidehighered.com/views/2009/02/09/baenninger "Confessions of a Male Presidential Spouse".] ''[[Inside Higher Ed]]'', 2/9/2009.</ref>
==Published writings== * Baenninger, MaryAnn, [http://www.universitybusiness.com/article/institutional-strength-caocfo-partnerships "Institutional Strength from CAO/CFO Partnerships"], ''University Business Magazine'', October 2009. * Baenninger, MaryAnn, [https://web.archive.org/web/20130105005040/http://www.csbsju.edu/About/College-of-Saint-Benedict/Office-of-the-President/Speeches/Golden-Thread.htm "A Golden Thread: The Liberal Arts in the 21st Century"], ''CSB/SJU'', 22 April 2005. * Baenninger, MaryAnn, [http://chronicle.com/article/For-Women-on-Campuses-Access/129242/ "For Women on Campuses, Access Doesn't Equal Success"], ''The Chronicle of Higher Education'', 2 October 2011.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.cic.org/Research-and-Data/Making-the-Case/Pages/Interview-with-MaryAnn-Baenninger.aspx Interview with MaryAnn Baenninger], Council of Independent Colleges
{{DEFAULTSORT:Baenninger, Maryann}} [[Category:American psychologists]] [[Category:American women psychologists]] [[Category:Temple University alumni]] [[Category:American university and college presidents]] [[Category:College of Saint Benedict and Saint John's University]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2011}}
{{spanish name 2|first= Canela|second=Lázaro}} '''Miguel Canela Lázaro''' was born in [[Santiago de los Caballeros]], [[Dominican Republic]], on September 29, 1894, the son of Pedro Canela (also born in [[Santiago de los Caballeros|Santiago]]) and Dolores Antonia Lázaro (a [[Spanish people|Spaniard]]). He died in [[Santo Domingo de Guzmán|Santo Domingo]], [[Dominican Republic]] on December 1, 1977. <ref name="Zaglul98">{{Citation | last = Zaglul Emuldesi | first = Antonio | title = Ciencia y Humildad: Biografía del Dr. Miguel Canela Lázaro | publisher = Editora Taller | location = [[Santo Domingo de Guzmán|Santo Domingo]], [[Dominican Republic]] | language = Spanish | year = 1998}}</ref> The Rouvière and Canela ligament (shown in Fig. 15 of "Anatomy of the ankle ligaments: a pictorial essay" <ref name="Golano201001">{{Citation | last = Golanó | first = Pau | title = Anatomy of the ankle ligaments: a pictorial essay | journal = Knee Surgery, Sports Traumatology, Arthroscopy | publisher = Springer-Verlag / Heidelberg | volume = 18 | issue = 5 | pages = 557–69 |date=Jan 2010 | doi = 10.1007/s00167-010-1100-x | pmc=2855022 | pmid=20309522|display-authors=etal}}</ref>) is named after him and his supervisor at the [[University of Paris Descartes|University of Paris]], [[Henri Rouvière]], for their joint work .<ref name="Rouviere1932">{{Citation | last = Rouvière | first = Henri | last2 = Canela | first2 = Miguel | title = Le Ligament péroneo-astragalo-calcanéen | journal = Annales d'Anatomie Pathologique | volume = 9 | pages = 745 | year = 1932}}</ref>
He was also a [[conservation movement|conservationist]] and a [[diplomat]]. He received both a [[surveying|surveyor]] (1917) and [[Medical Doctor|medicine doctorate]] (1924) degrees from the [[University of Santo Domingo]].<ref name="Zaglul98"/>
== Notes ==
{{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.quisqueyavirtual.edu.do/wiki/Miguel_Canela_L%C3%A1zaro Miguel Canela Lázaro] at [http://www.quisqueyavirtual.edu.do/wiki/Enciclopedia_Virtual_Dominicana Enciclopedia Virtual Dominicana] (in Spanish)
