{{Infobox dam | name = Mosul Dam | image = MosulDam-July2012-01.JPG | image_size = 300px | image_caption = | name_official = | location_map = Iraq | location_map_size = | location_map_caption = | location_map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|36|37|49|N|42|49|23|E|type:landmark_region:IQ-BG|display=inline,title}} | dam_crosses = [[Tigris]] river | location = 45 mi north of [[Mosul]], [[Ninawa Governorate]], [[Iraq]] | operator = [[Ministry of Water Resources (Iraq)|Ministry of Water Resources]] (17 August 2014){{cite web|title=Kurdish forces 'retake Mosul dam' from IS militants |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-28826349|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=17 August 2014|date=17 August 2014}} | dam_length = {{convert|3.4|km|abbr=on}} | dam_height = {{convert|113|m|abbr=on}}{{cite web|title=Iraqi Dam Assessments|url=http://www.envirozan.info/EZ_Docs/Dams/D_Iraqi%20Dam%20Assessments.pdf|publisher=United States Army, Corps of Engineers|accessdate=27 February 2012|location=Iraq|date=6 June 2003|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924001422/http://www.envirozan.info/EZ_Docs/Dams/D_Iraqi%20Dam%20Assessments.pdf|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=}} | dam_type =Embankment, earth-fill clay-core | dam_width_base = | dam_width_crest ={{convert|10|m|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} | dam_elevation_crest = {{convert|341|m|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} | construction_began = 25 January 1981 | opening = 7 July 1986 | cost = US$1.5 billion | spillway_count = 2 | spillway_type = Service: Controlled chute
Emergency: Fuse-plug ogee | spillway_capacity = Service: {{convert|13000|m3/s|ft3/s|abbr=on|sigfig=2}}
Emergency: {{convert|4000|m3/s|ft3/s|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} | res_name =Lake Dahuk | res_capacity_total = {{convert|11100000000|m3|acre.ft|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} | res_capacity_active = {{convert|8100000000|m3|acre.ft|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} | res_capacity_inactive = {{convert|2950000000|m3|acre.ft|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} | res_catchment = | res_surface = | res_elevation = {{convert|330|m|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} | plant_commission = Mosul 1: 1986
Mosul 2: 1985
Mosul 3: 1989 | plant_turbines = Mosul 1: 4 × {{convert|187.5|MW|abbr=on}} [[Francis-type]]
Mosul 2: 4 × {{convert|15.5|MW|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} [[Kaplan-type]]
Mosul 3: 2 × {{convert|120|MW|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} Francis pump-turbine{{cite web|title=Mosul Multipurpose Development Iraq|url=http://www.poyry.ch/linked/en/aboutus/Mosul_e.pdf|publisher=Poyry|accessdate=27 February 2012}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|title=Electrical Power Stations in Iraq|url=http://www.auptde.org/newsite/UploadImages/News/110/322.pdf|publisher=Arab Union of Electricity|accessdate=27 February 2012}}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} | plant_capacity = {{convert|1052|MW|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} | plant_annual_gen = {{convert|3420|GWh|sigfig=4}} | extra = }} '''Mosul Dam''' ({{lang-ar|سد الموصل}}), formerly known as '''Saddam Dam''' ({{lang|ar|سد صدام}}), is the largest [[dam]] in [[Iraq]]. It is located on the [[Tigris]] river in the western governorate of [[Ninawa Governorate|Ninawa]], upstream of the city of [[Mosul]]. The dam serves to generate hydroelectricity and provide water for downstream irrigation. At full capacity, the structure holds about {{convert|11.1|km3}} of water and provides electricity to the 1.7 million residents of Mosul. The dam's main {{convert|750|MW|adj=on}} power station contains four {{convert|187.5|MW|adj=on}} [[Francis turbine]]–generators. A [[pumped-storage hydroelectricity]] power plant with a capacity of {{convert|250|MW}} and a [[run-of-the-river]] dam downstream with a {{convert|62|MW|sing=on}} capacity also belong to the Mosul Dam scheme. It is the fourth largest dam in the [[Middle East]], as measured by reserve capacity, capturing snowmelt from [[Turkey]], some {{convert|70|mi}} north.{{cite web |url=http://enr.cbonstruction.com/news/Front2003/archives/030505.asp| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030808092931/http://enr.construction.com/news/front2003/archives/030505.asp| archivedate=8 August 2003| title=Iraqi Dam Has Experts On Edge Until Inspection Eases Fears| last=Wright| first=Andrew G. |work=[[Engineering News-Record]]|date=5 May 2003}} Built on a [[karst]] foundation, concerns over the dam's instability have led to major remediation and rehabilitation efforts since the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]]. == Characteristics == The Mosul Dam is a {{convert|113|m|abbr=on}} tall and {{convert|3.4|km|abbr=on}} long earth-fill embankment-type with a clay-core. The width of the crest is {{convert|10|m|abbr=on}}. At an elevation of {{convert|330|m|abbr=on}} above sea level, the reservoir, named Lake Dahuk, withholds {{convert|11100000000|m3|acre.ft||abbr=on|sigfig=3}} of water. Of that capacity {{convert|8100000000|m3|acre.ft||abbr=on|sigfig=2}} is active (or useful for power and downstream releases) and {{convert|2950000000|m3|acre.ft||abbr=on|sigfig=3}} is inactive (dead) storage. On the east side of the dam is the service [[spillway]] which is controlled by five [[radial gate]]s and has a maximum discharge capacity of {{convert|13000|m3/s|ft3/s|abbr=on|sigfig=2}}. Further to the east is a [[fuse-plug]]-controlled emergency spillway with a {{convert|4000|m3/s|ft3/s|abbr=on|sigfig=2}} capacity. At the toe of the dam on its west side is the main hydroelectric power station (Mosul 1). It contains four {{convert|187.5|MW|abbr=on|sigfig=4}} [[Francis turbine]]-generators for an installed capacity of 750 MW. Behind the power station are four [[surge tank]]s. Downstream of the dam is the Mosul regulation dam, which serves to regulate the tail-waters of the main dam but to generate electricity as well. The hydroelectric plant (Mosul 2) has an installed capacity of 62 MW with four 15.5 MW [[Kaplan turbine]]-generators. Immediately upstream of the dam is the 240 MW [[pumped-storage]] power station (Mosul 3). It serves as a [[peaking power station]] by pumping water to small reservoir above Lake Dahuk, storing it, then releasing the water back down to two 120 reversible-Francis turbines during peak energy usage. The entire Mosul multi-purpose project has an installed capacity of 1,052 MW. == History == === Planning === [[File:Aski Mosul.gif|thumb|left|Historical Castle of Aski Mosul before being submerged by the dam's reservoir]] Development of Iraq's rivers progressed rapidly in the mid-20th century as the country sought to control water resources for agriculture and to prevent flooding in [[Baghdad]]. Planning for the Mosul Dam began in the 1950s with the help of [[Sir Alexander Gibb & Partners]], a British firm who identified a location in 1953. In 1956, the Iraq Development Council contracted Koljian American to carry out studies for an irrigation dam at the location. The studies were completed the next year when Iraq asked the Harza Company to carry out a similar investigation who recommended a different location in 1960, based on [[karst]] foundations for two other recommended locations. In 1962, Iraq sought a third opinion from the Soviet Technoprom Export company who recommended a separate site. A fourth company, a Finland firm, Imatran Voima carried out a study in 1965 and a fifth company, Geotehnika of Yugoslavia, carried out studies in 1972. Based off the findings of all five companies which cited complex foundations, Iraq had a French firm, Soletanch, to carry out in-depth geological studies which occurred between 1974 and 1978. In 1978 the Swiss Consultants Consortium became the official consultants for the dam.{{cite journal|author1=Nadhir Al-Ansari|author2=Issa E. Issa|author3=Varoujan Sissakian|author4=Nasrat Adamo|author5=Sven Knutsson|title=Mystery of Mosul Dam the most Dangerous Dam in the World: The project|journal=Journal of Earth Sciences and Geotechnical Engineering|date=2015|volume=5|issue=3|pages=15–17|url=http://pure.ltu.se/portal/files/102425140/Vol_5_3_2.pdf|accessdate=4 March 2016|issn=1792-9660}} === Construction === During [[Saddam Hussein]]'s rule, the construction of the Mosul Dam began in 1981 by a German-Italian consortium that was led by [[Hochtief]] Aktiengesellschaft. Because the dam was constructed on a foundation of soluble [[gypsum]], the engineers recommended thorough grouting within the foundation before the superstructure was built. Instead, to speed construction of the dam, engineers blanket-grouted {{Convert|25|m|ft|abbr=on}} deep around the foundation and a curtain {{Convert|150|m|ft|abbr=on}} directly below the dam.{{cite web |author1=Julie R. Kelley |author2=Lillian D. Wakeley |author3=Seth W. Broadfoot |author4=Monte L. Pearson |author5=Christian J. McGrath |author6=Thomas E. McGill |author7=Jeffrey D. Jorgeson |author8=Cary A. Talbot |title=Geologic Setting of Mosul Dam and Its Engineering Implications |url=http://el.erdc.usace.army.mil/elpubs/pdf/tr07-10.pdf |publisher=U.S. Army Corps of Engineers |accessdate=14 March 2016 |pages=25–32 |date=September 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160412181624/http://el.erdc.usace.army.mil/elpubs/pdf/tr07-10.pdf |archive-date=2016-04-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }} A [[grout curtain|grouting]] gallery that would allow continuous grouting of the dam's foundation in order to promote stability was also installed. Construction was complete in 1984 and in the spring of 1985, the Mosul Dam began to inundate the [[Tigris River]], filling the reservoir which submerged many archaeological sites in the region. The power station began generating power on 7 July 1986. Because of significant structural stability issues associated with the Mosul Dam, ongoing grouting and additional construction and repairs are necessary. In 1988, Iraq began construction on the [[Badush Dam]] downstream which would serve the primary purpose of absorbing and releasing a Mosul Dam flood wave in the event of a breach. Works were halted in 1991 though due chiefly to UN sanctions.{{cite web|author=Daniel Pipes |url=http://www.danielpipes.org/5107/saddams-damn-dam-ie-the-mosul-dam |title=Saddam's Damn Dam |date= |accessdate=2014-08-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nce.co.uk/worries-grow-over-mosul-dam/304195.article|title=Worries grow over Mosul Dam}} === Demolition concerns during the 2003 invasion === [[File:Mosul Dam chute spillway.jpg|thumb|Chute [[spillway]] with ski jump section to dissipate the energy of the rushing water]] In early April 2003, following the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]] by a U.S.-led coalition, military intelligence had developed several scenarios, including one in which Iraqi forces would have wired the dam for detonation. This would release the {{convert|110|m|adj=on}} high waterline of the lake reservoir, to reach Mosul in about two hours. Subsequent investigation found nearly 500 dam workers to still be at work nearly a month after pay had stopped being distributed. === 2014 takeover of dam by ISIS === {{Main|Battle for Mosul Dam}} For several weeks in July and August 2014, [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIS or ISIL) held Mosul Dam.{{cite news |last=Tilghman |first=Andrew |date=2 September 2014 |title=Islamic State still threat to Mosul Dam, Pentagon says |url=http://www.armytimes.com/article/20140902/NEWS05/309020056/Islamic-State-still-threat-Mosul-Dam-Pentagon-says |newspaper=Army Times |accessdate=16 October 2014 }} On August 7, 2014, the organization captured the dam complex from the [[Peshmerga]]. ISIL's control of the dam created fears that its power supply could be restricted or that its water flows to downstream areas would be greatly inhibited. In a less likely scenario, there were worries the dam could be breached, causing widespread flooding and destruction downstream.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/08/world/middleeast/isis-forces-in-iraq.html?_r=0 | title=Rebels Captured Iraq's Largest Dam | date=7 August 2014 | agency=New York Times | accessdate=7 August 2014 | author=Rubin, Alissa J.}}{{cite news | url=https://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/mosul-dam-control-terrifying-dam-iraq-life-death/story?id=24878057 | title=Why Control of a Terrifying Dam in Iraq Is Life or Death for Half Million People | date=7 August 2014 | agency=ABC News | accessdate=7 August 2014 | author=Ferran, Lee}} On August 17, 2014, the Peshmerga and the Iraqi Army launched a successful operation to retake control of the dam from ISIL militants. [[United States]] airstrikes assisted the Kurdish and Iraqi military, damaging or destroying 19 vehicles belonging to ISIS, as well as striking an ISIL checkpoint near the dam.{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-28826349 | title=Kurdish forces 'retake Mosul dam' from IS militants | date=17 August 2014 | agency=BBC News | accessdate=17 August 2014}} == Instability and remediation == The earthen [[embankment dam]] is located on top of [[gypsum]], a soft mineral that dissolves in contact with water. Continuous maintenance is required to plug, or "[[grout]]", new leaks with a liquefied slurry of cement and other additives.[http://www.defendamerica.mil/articles/sep2005/a090905ms3.html "Mosul Dam Repairs Benefit Tigris Basins"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071101034648/http://www.defendamerica.mil/articles/sep2005/a090905ms3.html |date=2007-11-01 }}, defendamerica.mil, September 2005 More than {{convert|50000|t}} of material have been injected into the dam since leaks began forming shortly after the reservoir was filled in 1986, and 24 machines currently continuously pump grout into the dam base. Between 1992 and 1998 four sinkholes formed downstream of the dam and a fifth sinkhole developed east of the dam in February 2003 that was filled several times. In August 2005 another sinkhole developed to the east. A September 2006 report by the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] noted, "In terms of internal erosion potential of the foundation, Mosul Dam is the most dangerous dam in the world." The report further outlined a worst-case scenario, in which a sudden collapse of the dam would flood Mosul under {{convert|65|ft}} of water and [[Baghdad]], a city of 7 million, to {{convert|15|ft}}, with an estimated death toll of 500,000.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/29/AR2007102902193.html?hpid=topnews "Iraqi Dam Seen In Danger of Deadly Collapse"] by Amit R. Paley, ''[[The Washington Post]]'', October 30, 2007 A report on 30 October 2007 by the US Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction (SIGIR) said that the dam's foundations could give way at any moment.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7070706.stm#infographic "Iraq dismisses Mosul Dam warnings"] BBC news, October 31, 2007 According to ''[[The Economist]]'', "One study says that if the dam collapses, Mosul would be submerged within hours. Another warns that half a million Iraqis could be killed by floodwaters, and more than a million forced from their homes. Disease and looting as the floodwaters raced through [[Baiji, Iraq|Baiji]], [[Tikrit]], [[Samarra]], and even parts of [[Baghdad]] would complete that dreadful scenario." Nadhir al-Ansari, an engineer involved in the building of the dam who is currently Professor of Engineering at the [[Luleå University of Technology]], Sweden, said that the floodwaters would take four hours to reach Mosul and 45 hours to reach Baghdad, and that more than a million people would be killed if a "good evacuation plan" were not in place.{{cite news|last1=Borger|first1=Julian|title=Mosul dam engineers warn it could fail at any time, killing 1m people|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/02/mosul-dam-engineers-warn-it-could-fail-at-any-time-killing-1m-people|accessdate=2 March 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2 March 2016}} In 2004, dam manager Abdulkhalik Thanoon Ayoub ordered the dam's water level, which can reach {{convert|330|m|ft|0}} above sea level, to have a maximum of {{convert|319|m}}, thus reducing the pressure on the structure. Nevertheless, Iraqi officials maintain that the U.S. government is overstating the risk. The Army Corps of Engineers has proposed that the [[Badush Dam]] downstream be completed to serve its purpose of obstructing the large wave that would result if the Mosul Dam collapsed. This has been resisted by Iraqi officials, who note that the current plan for the Badush Dam is US$300 million to provide hydroelectric power and help irrigation while the proposed expansion would cost $10 billion. In 2007, the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]] developed and executed a US$27 million plan to help continue maintenance and repairs on the dam in the short-term. The Iraq Government was also recommended a long-term solution that includes the construction of {{Convert|67|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} deep walls around the dam foundation. The project would cost $4 billion and take approximately four to five years to complete. ===Renewed instability concerns following ISIL control=== Maintenance had been deferred during the [[Battle for Mosul Dam]] due to security concerns, and many workers did not work both because of the risk of attacks by ISIL and lack of pay. Half of the workers who worked at the dam have quit because they had not been paid for more than five months, and budget shortfalls and political infighting between the Kurdish regional government and the central government of Iraq have made it difficult to hire new workers. Together these factors have made Mosul Dam the "most dangerous dam in the world", because there are "almost certainly an unprecedented level of untreated voids" in the dam's foundation."{{cite news|title=‘Most dangerous dam’ facing collapse, threatens half million in Mosul: U.S. Army|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/02/10/world/dangerous-dam-facing-collapse-threatens-half-million-mosul-u-s-army/#.VtSfNPkrLIV|accessdate=29 February 2016|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[Japan Times]]|date=February 10, 2016}} Growing instability concerns due to the previous control of the dam by ISIL, and poor security led the Iraq government to award a US$2 billion contract to an Italian company, Trevi, in December 2015. The contract covers repairs to the dam and the Italian government plans to send 450 additional troops to provide security at the dam site.{{cite news|last1=Squires|first1=Nick|title=Italy to send 500 soldiers to defend Iraq's largest dam in Mosul|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iraq/12053500/Italy-to-send-500-soldiers-to-defend-Iraqs-largest-dam-in-Mosul.html|accessdate=30 December 2015|work=Telegraph|date=16 December 2015}} In January 2016, U.S. General [[Sean MacFarland]] warned that the dam might undergo a "catastrophic" collapse. He added, "What we do know is this—if this dam were in the United States, we would have drained the lake behind it."{{cite news|title=The Mosul dam: A watery time-bomb: The most dangerous dam in the world |url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21692903-most-dangerous-dam-world-watery-time-bomb|accessdate=14 February 2016|work=[[The Economist]]|date=13 February 2016}} Maintenance had suffered as ISIL had removed equipment and chased technicians away in August 2014, and the grouting schedule had not been maintained.{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/iraqs-mosul-dam-could-face-catastrophic-collapse-top-121320504.html |agency=[[Reuters]] |title=Iraq's Mosul dam could face catastrophic collapse: top U.S. general |publisher=News.Yahoo.com |date=January 28, 2016 |accessdate=January 29, 2016}} He indicated that contingency plans are in the works to protect people downstream in case of a collapse. Some Iraqi officials continued to dismiss claims of a potential failure. In February 2016, the Minister of Water Resources, Muhsin al-Shammari, stated "The looming danger to Mosul dam is one in a thousand. This risk level is present in all the world's dams."{{cite news|title=Iraq's water minister judges only tiny danger of Mosul dam collapse|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-mosul-dam-idUSKCN0VF0VE|accessdate=29 February 2016|agency=Reuters|date=6 February 2016}} In February 2016, the [[United States Embassy in Iraq]] warned of a "serious and unprecedented" danger of the dam collapsing and suggested that plans for evacuation should be made, as the cities [[Mosul]], [[Tikrit]], [[Samarra]], and [[Baghdad]] could be at risk in the event of collapse, and that up to 1.5 million people could be killed due to the ensuing [[flash floods]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35690616 BBC News (2015) US warns of Mosul dam collapse in northern Iraq, February 29th] The [[Prime Minister of Iraq]], [[Haider al-Abadi]], repeated these concerns, and called for citizens in Mosul to evacuate and move at least 3.5 miles away from the river,{{cite news|last1=Borger|first1=Julian|title=Iraqi PM and US issue warnings over threat of Mosul dam collapse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/29/iraq-us-issue-warnings-threat-of-mosul-dam-collapse|accessdate=29 February 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=29 February 2016}} a proposal that was criticized by Professor al-Ansari: "What are all these people, millions of people, supposed to do when they get 6 km away? There is no support for them there. Nothing to help them live." On February 29, a Trevi spokesman said that the contract had still not been signed. There were concerns that the dam could collapse before the repair works begin. On March 2, 2016, the Iraqi government announced that the contract with Trevi was finalized and signed.{{cite news|last1=Borger|first1=Julian|title=Mosul dam engineers warn it could fail at any time, killing 1 m people|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/02/mosul-dam-engineers-warn-it-could-fail-at-any-time-killing-1m-people|accessdate=4 March 2016|publisher=The Guardian|date=March 2, 2016}} A team of Italian specialists from Trevi arrived on April 14 to set up camp for the group of engineers who are expected to arrive within a few weeks.{{cite news|title=Italian team arrives as part of Mosul Dam emergency repair |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/italian-team-arrives-as-part-of-mosul-dam-emergency-repair-project/|accessdate=April 18, 2016|publisher=CBS News|date=April 14, 2016}} [[Ministry of Defence (Italy)|Italian Defence Minister]] [[Roberta Pinotti]] met Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi on May 9 to discuss logistics for deploying 450 troops near the frontline with ISIL to protect the workers carrying out repairs on the dam.{{cite news|title=Italian defense minister in Iraq for Mosul dam talks |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/Default.aspx?pageID=517&nID=99006&NewsCatID=352|accessdate=May 18, 2016|work=Hurriyet Daily News|date=May 10, 2016}} Trevi started working on the dam in September 2016.{{cite news|title=Mosul battle may cost ‘the most dangerous dam in the world’ |url=https://english.alarabiya.net/en/perspective/features/2016/10/20/Is-Mosul-hosting-one-of-most-dangerous-dams-in-the-world-.html|author=Francesca Astorri|accessdate=28 December 2016|publisher=Al-Arabiya|date=20 October 2016}} The repairs were started in October 2016. In May 2017, Iraqi [[Ministry of Water Resources (Iraq)|Minister of Water Resources]] Hassan Janabi stated that no danger to the dam remained and it was going back to normal operation. Carlo Crippa, the project manager, said the dam structure now showed no significant signs of distress. However, constant maintenance will be necessary, as "the rocks of the foundations are prone to dissolution due to the circulation of water." Five waterways that controlled the flow of water into the dam became operational after 12 years, with Janabi saying the water level was at the highest level since 2005.{{cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/mosul-dam-no-longer-brink-catastrophe/3839850.html|title=Mosul Dam No Longer on Brink of Catastrophe|first=Rikar|last=Hussein|agency=Voice of America}} == Notes and references == {{Reflist|33em}} ==See also== {{stack|{{Portal|Iraq|Water|Renewable energy|Arab world}}}} * [[List of hydroelectric power station failures]] * [[Haditha Dam]] * [[Tabqa Dam]] * [[Baath Dam]] * [[Lake Tharthar]] * [[Lake Habbaniyah]] * [[Lake Milh]] * [[Lake Qadisiyah]] * [[List of dams and reservoirs in Iraq]] == Further reading == *{{cite journal |author=Filkins, Dexter |authorlink= |authormask= |date=January 2, 2017 |title=Before the flood : a failing dam threatens millions of Iraqis |department=A Reporter at Large |journal=The New Yorker |volume=92 |issue=43 |pages=22-28 |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/01/02/a-bigger-problem-than-isis |}} Online version is titled "A Bigger Problem Than ISIS?". == External links == *{{Commons category-inline}} {{Tigris}} {{Tigris dams}} [[Category:Dams in Iraq]] [[Category:Dams on the Tigris River]] [[Category:Nineveh Governorate]] [[Category:Earth-filled dams]] [[Category:Geography of Iraqi Kurdistan]] [[Category:Hydroelectric power stations in Iraq]] [[Category:Pumped-storage hydroelectric power stations]] [[Category:Reservoirs in Iraq]] [[Category:Dams completed in 1986]] [[Category:Energy infrastructure completed in 1985]] [[Category:Energy infrastructure completed in 1986]] [[Category:Energy infrastructure completed in 1989]] [[Category:1986 establishments in Iraq]] [[Category:1980s in Iraq]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = No Smoking | image = No Smoking (Poster).jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Anurag Kashyap]] | producer = Kumar Mangat Pathak
[[Vishal Bhardwaj]] | story = Anurag Kashyap
[[Raj Singh Chaudhary]] | screenplay = Anurag Kashyap | based on = {{Based on|''[[Quitters, Inc.]]'' (1978)|[[Stephen King]]}} | starring = [[John Abraham (actor)|John Abraham]]
[[Ayesha Takia]]
[[Paresh Rawal]]
[[Ranvir Shorey]] | music = Vishal Bhardwaj | cinematography = [[Rajeev Ravi]] | editing = [[Aarti Bajaj]] | studio= Big Screen Entertainment and Eros Internationalhttp://creative.sulekha.com/30-years-of-eros_229994_blog | distributor = [[Eros International]] | released = {{Film date|2007|10|26|df=y}} | runtime = 128 minutes | country = India | language = Hindi | budget = {{INRConvert|23|c}} | gross = {{INRConvert|3|c}}{{cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Consumer/bwmEEnWusJRuQ3K93FlOKN/Ten-Bollywood-directors-who-found-success-late.html|title=Here are 10 directors who didn’t taste success in the first few attempts, but are at the top of the game today|last=Jha|first=Lata|work=[[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]]|date=27 October 2015|accessdate=5 May 2016}} }} '''''No Smoking''''' is a 2007 Indian [[neo-noir]] [[psychological thriller|psychological thriller film]] written and directed by [[Anurag Kashyap]] and co-produced by [[Vishal Bhardwaj]] and Kumar Mangat. The film stars [[John Abraham (actor)|John Abraham]], [[Ayesha Takia]], [[Ranvir Shorey]] and [[Paresh Rawal]] in the lead roles, while [[Bipasha Basu]] appears in an [[Item number]].{{cite web|title=No Smoking Cast & Crew|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/moviemicro/cast/id/201583|publisher=''[[Bollywood Hungama]]''|accessdate=9 August 2012}} The film is loosely based upon the short story ''[[Quitters, Inc.]]'' by [[Stephen King]], which was previously adapted as one of three segments featured in [[Cinema of United States|Hollywood]] [[anthology film]], ''[[Cat's Eye (1985 film)|Cat's Eye]]'' (1985). It became the first Indian film to be [[Media based on Stephen King works|adapted from a Stephen King short story]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-the-inspiration-behind-anurag-kashyap-films/20120621.htm|publisher=''[[Rediff.com]]''|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=21 June 2012|title=The Inspiration Behind Anurag Kashyap's Films}} The story follows K ([[John Abraham (actor)|Abraham]]) a self-obsessed, narcissist [[Chain smoking|chain smoker]] who agrees to [[Smoking cessation|kick his habit]] to save his marriage and visits a [[Drug rehabilitation|rehabilitation centre]], but is caught in a [[labyrinth]] game by Baba Bengali ([[Paresh Rawal|Rawal]]), the man who guarantees he will make him quit.{{cite web|title=No Smoking|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/shropshire/films/bollywood/2007/09/no_smoking_preview.shtml|publisher=''[[BBC]]''|author=Manish Gajjar|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=10 October 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.apunkachoice.com/titles/nos/no-smoking/mid_24772/preview/|publisher=Apunkachoice|accessdate=11 August 2012|title=No Smoking preview}} The film released worldwide on 26 October 2007, but was met with a lukewarm response from Indian [[Film critic|critics]] and mixed response from overseas critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/entertainment/Biased-criticism-doesn-t-help-Anurag-Kashyap/Article1-254812.aspx|publisher=''[[Hindustan Times]]''|accessdate=16 August 2012|date=30 October 2007|title=Biased criticism doesn't help: Anurag Kashyap}}{{cite web|title=Lashing from critics for 'No Smoking' hurt: Anurag Kashyap|url=http://news.oneindia.in/2008/01/06/lashing-from-critics-for-no-smoking-hurt-anurag-kashyap-1199601142.html|publisher=''[[Oneindia.in]]''|accessdate=16 August 2012|date=6 January 2008}} The film did not perform well at the [[box office]] either, becoming one of the major disasters of the year.{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-02-10/did-you-know-/28543177_1_anurag-kashyap-smoking-satya|publisher=''[[Times of India]]''|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=10 February 2011|title=Anurag Kashyap's 'No Smoking'}} According to Kashyap, the film failed because, it was considered much ahead of its time, courtesy of its dark and unusual storyline comprising with elements of [[Surrealist cinema|surrealism]], [[fantasy]], [[dream]], [[reality]],{{cite web|title=Anurag’s Saif option|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2007-11-30/news-interviews/27972064|publisher=''[[Times of India]]''|author=Sandipan Dalal|accessdate=12 August 2012|date=30 November 2007}} [[Horror film|horror]] and [[dark humour]] which left critics and the cinema-goers baffled, this was frowned upon by Indian audiences, as it was unconventional, pretentious and they had never seen anything like it.{{cite web|url=http://www.apunkachoice.com/scoop/interviews/20080107-0.html|publisher=Apunkachoice|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=7 January 2008|title=Critics failed to understand 'No Smoking': Anurag Kashyap}}.But in later years the film received positive reviews and has become a [[cult]] film. ''No Smoking'' was nominated at several award ceremonies in 2008, primarily for the technical aspects of the film, including 3 [[Filmfare award]] nominations. Before a full cinematic release in India, the film was invited to be screened at the [[Rome Film Festival]] where it won huge appreciation from the audience and critics alike.{{cite web|title=No Smoking in Rome|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/oct/25john.htm|publisher=''[[Rediff.com]]''|accessdate=14 August 2012|date=25 October 2007}} In 2011 the film was played at several film festivals in [[India]] and [[China]], receiving unanimous applause and praise, as well as winning a number of awards.{{cite web|publisher=''[[Times of India]]''|author=Shree Misra|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=20 July 2011|title=No Smoking wins awards at Indian Film Festival|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-07-20/news-interviews/29794341}} ==Plot== The film begins with a man waking up in decrepit old house in an unknown area. He gets a call from his wife enquiring where he is. The man doesn't know where he and searches the house for a cigarette. He accidentally opens a room and finds it filled with Russian soilders. One of the them starts chasing him and opens fire at him. The man gets shot in the leg and jumps into a bathtub he finds in the snow. The man wakes up in a bathtub. The man is revealed to be'K' ([[John Abraham (actor)|John Abraham]]) a wealthy businessman in his 30s, and a heavy chain-smoker. He is confident, narcissistic and very arrogant in nature. His family and friends beg him to quit smoking, to no avail. K's friend Abbas ([[Ranvir Shorey]]) and his doctor ([[Kiku Sharda]]), offer to set up an appointment at a rehabilitation centre called 'Prayogshaala' ('The Laboratory'), which they claim will surely rid K of his habit. K finally relents after his wife Anjali ([[Ayesha Takia]]) leaves him, unable to take the strain K's smoking addiction places on their relationship. K decides to check out Prayogshaala, and meets Shri Shri Prakash Guru Ghantal Baba Bengali Sealdahwale ([[Paresh Rawal]]). The centre operates behind the front of another business, 'Kalkatta Karpets'. K finds the building to be unconventional and confusing, similar to a [[Labyrinth]]. The method Prayogshaala uses to cure their patients of their addiction is based on fear and psychological manipulation. Each time a patient gives in to their vice, Baba makes sure that something shocking happens to them. The first offense is almost killing a loved one, by keeping him/her in a chamber full of cigarette smoke the person has smoked in his entire life, for a duration of 5 minutes. The second offense is losing a finger. The third offense is the death of a loved one. The last offense is taking the soul of the person from his body, although this offense is described very loosely. K initially refuses to sign the contract and pay the fee of {{INR}} 21,11,111 for his treatment but is forced to do so by Baba and his disciples. Baba then tells K that he is free to leave, but he must abide by the rules or he will suffer the consequences. K witnesses other members of the group as they try to quit smoking. Many end up losing fingers as they cannot resisit the urge to smoke. K tries to keep to the terms but fails twice and is punished. He is now very conscious about the third time. After some time, K meets an old friend, Alex, who is now a Cuban cigar seller. At an event, K is forced to place a cigar in his mouth, in order to appease his friend. Seconds later, he receives a phone call from the police, who inform him that his wife is missing and possibly dead. He calls Baba and is told that for smoking, his wife will be killed, as per the rules. He protests that he did not actually smoke and Baba apologizes for the mistake, but says it is too late. K asks Baba to tell the police about this, but the line goes dead and the phone number is non-existent on dialling. K's protests are ignored and the police believe that he is delusional. Trying to prove his story, he seeks out Abbas, who had lost a finger at the rehabilitation centre, only to find that the man has all fingers intact. Mocking him, the police force K to smoke. Shortly afterwards, K gets a phone call that his brother committed suicide due to his smoking habit. K raves angrily at the police and is thrown in the jail. K is eventually bailed out. Soon, he learns that Baba permits sins and vices to be done during a period known as 'Zero Minute'. He attends an event, where he sees Baba, but is unable to reach him. K decides to light a cigarette. Suddenly, K wakes up in a Russian army base, with a call from his wife. She asks him why he believes she is dead. K is confused, but escapes from the base by jumping into water and ends up in a ragged room, from which he sees himself staring out from a hospital room. He also sees his wife and Baba. He calls out but no one can hear him, and he is told that it is because his body no longer hears his inner soul. The final punishment is complete. In a series of haphazard events, the twisted path of K's soul is shown, until it finally reaches his body once again. K wakes up in his home to find his wife sleeping near him. He also discovers that he is missing two fingers. Later, K is seen recommending the "Prayogshala" centre to a friend. ==Cast and crew== ===Cast=== * [[John Abraham (actor)|John Abraham]] known in the film as simply K, a [[Ego (spirituality)|self obsessed]], [[wikt:smart aleck|smart aleck]], [[narcissist]], chain smoker who agrees to [[quit smoking]] for his wife, but is caught up in the game of Baba Bengali in the process, after he refuses to co-operate.{{cite web|title=No Smoking film gallery|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/shropshire/content/image_galleries/no_smoking_gallery.shtml?1|publisher=''[[BBC Films]]''|accessdate=11 August 2012|date=October 2007}} * [[Ayesha Takia]] as Anjali / Annie, the wife of K, who is fed up of his habit and forcefully tries to make him quit by threatening to leave him.{{cite web|title=No Smoking film gallery|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/shropshire/content/image_galleries/no_smoking_gallery.shtml?2|publisher=''[[BBC Films]]''|accessdate=11 August 2012|date=October 2007}} Annie is the secretary of K, who seems to have a crush on him and looks exactly the same as Anjali. Throughout the movie, it is implied she happens to be both Annie and Anjali as K liked spreading rumors in office about their affairs. * [[Paresh Rawal]] as [[Shri]] Shri Prakash Guru Ghantal Baba Bengali Sealdahwale, the film's main [[antagonist]], who is extremely mysterious, yet very clever and powerful. He forcefully makes people quit smoking, otherwise bad things keep on happening in their lives. He knows at all times if someone is breaking his agreement, even if they are in another country, or [[no man's land]]. * [[Ranvir Shorey]] as Abbas Tyerwalla, the friend of K, who was also the one to introduce him to smoking. He recommends the prayogshala (Laboratory) to K, as he himself had to learn to quit smoking from Baba Bengali. * Karan Makhija as the doctor and another friend of K, who learnt to quit smoking from Baba Bengali. * Joy Fernandes as Alex * [[Jesse Randhawa]] in a [[item number|special appearance]] as a dancer in the song "''Jab Bhi Cigarette''" * [[Bipasha Basu]] in an [[Item number]] "''Phook De''" (during the [[closing credits]]) * [[Rasika Dugal]] in [[Character actor|character role]] * [[Anurag Kashyap]] as man in the elevator (uncredited) * [[Vikramaditya Motwane]] as an employee in K's office * [[Gajraj Rao (actor)|Gajraj Rao]] as Drunk Man outside restaurant. ===Crew=== * '''Banner''': ''Big Screen Entertainment'' & ''[[Eros Entertainment]]'' * '''Producers''': Kumar Mangat, [[Vishal Bhardwaj]] * '''Director''': [[Anurag Kashyap]] * '''Lyrics''': [[Gulzar (lyricist)|Gulzar]] * '''Music Director''': [[Vishal Bhardwaj]] * '''Background Score''': Hitesh Sonik, [[Clinton Cerejo]] * '''Director of Photography''': [[Rajeev Ravi]] * '''Choreography''': [[Ganesh Acharya]] * '''Co-Producer''': [[Sunil Lulla]] * '''Action''': Jai Singh Nijjar * '''Editor''': [[Aarti Bajaj]] * '''Screenplay''': [[Anurag Kashyap]] * '''Art Director''': [[Tariq Umar Khan]] * '''Sound''': Kunal Sharma * '''Publicity Designs''': Rahul Nanda, Himanshu Nanda & HR Enterprises * '''Story / Writer''': [[Anurag Kashyap]] * '''Compositing Supervisor/Particle FX''': Saareesh Churiwala ==Production== ===Development=== The idea for the film came during the making of ''[[Satya (1998 film)|Satya]]'' (1998), when director [[Ram Gopal Varma]] pitched a story about a chain smoker's encounter with someone who despises smoking. Varma later incorporated his own idea of the story as a short segment in his anthology film, ''[[Darna Mana Hai]]'' (2003). During the shooting of Kashyap's ''[[Black Friday (2007 film)|Black Friday]]'', his assistant narrated him a different script about a chain smoker who wakes up without cigarettes and is unable to get any because of a curfew. Kashyap decided to take the story forward, taking inspiration from ''Quitters, inc'' and a surreal moment from ''Cats Eye'', subsequently making him develop the story into a darker and more unreal version. ===Casting=== After the scripting was complete in 2006, Kashyap narrated the film to [[Shahrukh Khan]], who was keen to do the film but later would back out for unknown reasons. When the deal fell through Kashyap who was in bad shape at the time, as one of his films were delayed and the other stuck in production, tried to get a hold of all the top actors, though none of them responded except for Abraham.{{cite web|title=No Smoking passes from Shahrukh to John|url=http://entertainment.oneindia.in/bollywood/gupshup/2007/no-smoking-shahrukh-john-abraham-041007.html|publisher=''[[Oneindia.in]]''|author=[[Taran Adarsh]]|accessdate=11 August 2012|date=4 October 2007}} [[Vishal Bhardwaj]], Kashyap's friend and producer of the fiim recommended [[Saif Ali Khan]], as he was part of the smoking segment in ''Darna Mana Hai'', though Kashyap had already finalised Abraham. Later false reports surfaced that Saif be appearing in a [[Cameo appearance|cameo]], on the request of co-producer Kumar Mangat, who worked together in ''[[Omkara (2006 film)|Omkara]]'' (2006).{{cite web|title=Saif and Bipasha: No butts please|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2007-07-21/news-interviews/27990194_1_saif-ali-khan-bipasha-basu-saif-and-bipasha|publisher=''[[Times of India]]''|accessdate=11 August 2012|date=21 July 2007}}{{cite web|title=Saif Ali Khan is not doing 'No Smoking'|url=http://www.apunkachoice.com/scoop/bollywood/20070726-2.html|publisher=Apunkachoice|accessdate=11 August 2012|date=26 July 2007}} Due to the film having a complex storyline, when Kashyap was auditioning Abraham he read him a badly written fake script title ''Lapata'' (Lost), which Abraham declined to. After which he read him the real script of ''No Smoking'', he immediately agreed to do it.{{cite web|title='No Smoking will create a genre|url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/oct/23slid4.htm|publisher=''[[Rediff.com]]''|author=Patcy N|date=23 October 2007|accessdate=24 August 2012}} Initially Takia was not comfortable with the love making scenes and the clothes of the secretary (Annie), though Kashyap refused to make any changes.{{cite web|title='Our cinema is immature'|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/oct/24anurag.htm|publisher=''[[Rediff.com]]''|author=Patcy N|accessdate=14 August 2012|date=24 October 2007}} There is also a scene where Abraham is seen nude from rear, this stirred up some controversy.{{cite web|title=John Abraham to do a nude scene for No Smoking|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/1179640/John-Abraham-to-do-a-nude-scene-for-No-Smoking|publisher=''[[Bollywood Hungama]]''|accessdate=14 August 2012|date=19 October 2006}} Abraham who had previously quit smoking, smoked up to 90 cigarettes a day during the shooting to give the film a more believable look. Later when the film was complete Abraham went for an X-ray and found his lungs were heavily damaged.{{cite web|title=Smoking turns John Abraham's lungs black|url=http://entertainment.oneindia.in/bollywood/features/2007/john-lungs-turns-black-191007.html|publisher=''[[Oneindia.in]]''|author=Upala KBR|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=19 October 2007}} Originally director [[Rajkumar Santoshi]] was set to make his acting debut by playing the role of the doctor, and writer [[Abbas Tyrewala]] was to play the role later given to Shorey, hence Kashyap named the character after the writer.{{cite web|title=Rajkumar Santoshi to act in No Smoking|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/1174279|publisher=''[[India Fm]]''|author=|date=31 October 2006|accessdate=24 August 2012}} ===Filming=== Most of the filming was done in unique ways. In one scene where Abraham and Shorey are seen as teenagers smoking [[Marijuana]], most directors would have used child actors but Kashyap decided instead to alter the appearance of the actors and make them improvise and behave as kids themselves.{{cite web|title='No Smoking' defies convention|url=http://www.apunkachoice.com/scoop/bollywood/20071025-4.html|publisher=Apunkachoice|author=Nikhil Kumar|accessdate=16 August 2012|date=23 September 2007}} The film was shot extensively in parts of the [[Russian Federation]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Uzbekistan]] and [[Siberia]], in extremely cold climates with temperatures of minus 25 [[Celsius|degrees Celsius]] (°C), despite this none of the crew members had any problems during the shooting.{{cite web|title=No Smoking to be shot in Russia|url=http://businessofcinema.com/bollywood-news/ino-smokingi-to-be-shot-in-russia/|publisher=''Businessofcinema''|author=Johnny Vaz|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=12 January 2007}}{{cite web|title=John Abraham shoots in chilly climate|url=http://www.apunkachoice.com/scoop/bollywood/20070122-2.html|publisher=Apunkachoice|accessdate=14 August 2012|date=22 January 2007}} During the shooting in Uzbekistan, a Russian actor dressed as a soldier had to chase Abraham. After running 200 meters the man collapsed, as the shooting was on high altitudes, there was a lack of oxygen. He had to be rushed to the hospital, as he had stopped breathing.{{cite web|title='I am doing films that are more meaningful'|url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/oct/23slid4.htm|publisher=''[[Rediff.com]]''|author=Patcy N|date=23 October 2007|accessdate=24 August 2012}} ==Reception== ===Critical reception=== ====India==== The film was heavily panned by Indian critics. ''[[Sify]]'' gave it 2 out of 5 stars saying "You try so hard to understand what ''No Smoking'' tries to say, but the film is like one big puzzle that refuses to get solved. John makes a sincere attempt to leave a mark and succeeds to an extent. Really, one wonders, what prompted John to instantly approve this bizarre story".{{cite web|title=No Smoking|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/no-smoking-review-bollywood-14549765.html|publisher=''[[Sify]]''|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=27 October 2007}} [[Rajeev Masand]] of ''[[IBN Live]]'' giving it 1.5/5 said "What the director gives us is an extremely arrogant piece of work that reeks of over-confidence and self-proclaimed genius. How else do you explain the intentionally incohesive screenplay, the bizarre dialogue, and the blatant disregard for the viewer's time and patience?".{{cite web|title=No Smoking Review|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/review-no-smoking-is-a-colossal-disappointment/51232-8.html|publisher=''[[IBN Live]]''|author=[[Rajeev Masand]]|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=27 October 2007}} [[Nikhat Kazmi]] of ''[[Times of India]]'' also gave it 1.5/5 stars and said "''No Smoking'' leaves you completely baffled and desperately looking for logic in its surreal sequences of John in a jaded jail, John in a tunnel, John in a bathtub, John in Siberia-like surroundings".{{cite web|title=No Smoking|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/hindi/No-Smoking/movie-review/2493801.cms|publisher=''[[Times of India]]''|author=[[Nikhat Kazmi]]|accessdate=10 August 2012}} Indu Mirani from ''[[DNA India]]'' rated it 1.5/5 saying "There is a fine line between intelligence and indulgence and with ''No Smoking'', director Anurag Kashyap crosses it often. It’s not like he has made a rank bad film, but ‘No Smoking’ is so influenced by graphic novels and Neil Gaiman books, that understanding its plot’s many forward and backward movements would be out of the scope of the layman".{{cite web|title=No smoking|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mobile/report.php?n=1130068|publisher=''[[DNA India]]''|author=Indu Mirani|date=26 October 2007|accessdate=24 August 2012}} [[Khalid Mohamed]] of ''[[Hindustan Times]]'' rated it 1 star and said "Too in-depth man, too in-depth, puffing, driving, the sex act, fingers being chopped. Kcuf, kcuf. what’s happening out here? You can’t make out, you don’t care, and you’re fed up of the affectations, the self-indulgence."{{cite web|title=Review: No Smoking|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Reviews/Review-No-Smoking/Article1-254292.aspx|publisher=''[[Hindustan Times]]''|author=[[Khalid Mohamed]]|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=26 October 2007}} [[Taran Adarsh]] from ''[[Bollywood Hungama]]'' giving it 1 out of 5 said "You try so hard to understand what ''No Smoking'' tries to say, but the film is like one big puzzle that refuses to get solved. What ails ''No Smoking'', did you ask. Simple, it's the most complicated cinematic experience of 2007. On the whole, ''No Smoking'' fails miserably. Very disappointing!".{{cite web|title=No Smoking|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/moviemicro/criticreview/id/201583|publisher=''[[Bollywood Hungama]]''|author=[[Taran Adarsh]]|accessdate= 23 August 2012|date=26 October 2007}} Prithviraj Hegde of ''[[Rediff.com]]'' gave the film 0 stars and said "The movie unfolds like a bad dream and spins into a downward spiral that's unreal, incomprehensible and leaves you dazed. And as you may have gathered, I still have no clue what the movie was about."{{cite web|title=No smoking|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/oct/26smoke.htm|publisher=''[[Rediff.com]]''|author=Prithviraj Hegde|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=26 October 2007}} On the contrary, [[Chandril Bhattacharya]] of [[Anandabazar Patrika]] praised the movie uninhibitedly and described the film as first of its kind in India and historical.{{cite web|title=Collar tola chhobi|url=http://archives.anandabazar.com/archive/1071110/11rabimag.htm|publisher=[[Anandabazar Patrika]]|author=chandril bhattacharya|accessdate= 23 August 2012|date=11 November 2007}} In 2012 ''No Smoking'' was voted no 2 on the list "The Ten Worst Films Of John Abraham" by ''[[Rediff.com]]''.{{cite web|title=The Ten Worst Films Of John Abraham|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-9-the-ten-worst-films-of-john-abraham/20120410.htm|publisher=''[[Rediff.com]]''|author=Sukanya Verma|date=10 April 2012|accessdate=24 August 2012}} ====Overseas==== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] website the film has received 50% fresh rating, indicating mixed reviews.{{cite web|title=No Smoking(2007) - Rotten Tomatoes|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1192358-1192358-no_smoking|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes}} Phelim O'Neill of ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave it 3 out of 5 saying "While no screen credit is offered to [[Stephen King|King]], it's clear his tale directly forms this film's basis, making it kind of a first for [[Indian cinema]]. It could be the beginning of a trend. While a slack pace, unsettled internal logic and a goofy subplot undo much of director Kashyap's hard work.{{cite web|title=No Smoking|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/oct/26/bollywood.horror|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|author=Phelim O'Neill|accessdate=10 August 2012|date=26 Oct 2007}} ''[[Film 4]]'' also rated it 3 out of 5 stars and said "Those whose concept of Bollywood involves elephants, saris and dance numbers might be pleasantly surprised by Anurag Kashyap's film, a slick thriller that combines a screwball sensibility with a nightmarish twist".{{cite web|title=No smoking review|url=http://www.film4.com/reviews/2007/no-smoking|publisher=''[[Film 4]]''|accessdate=10 August 2012}} Tajpal Rathore from ''[[BBC Films]] ''gave it 1 out of 5 and said "''No Smoking'' is a surprisingly sincere effort, but shouldn't make your life feel any more fulfilled, even if you are a smoker. The shoddy screenplay is stale, and its situations laughable, and though the actors' give it their all, it just doesn't light up in the end. No smoke, and no fire, in what is ultimately a bit of a drag".{{cite web|title=No Smoking (2007)|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/films/2007/10/22/no_smoking_2007_review.shtml#rating|publisher=''[[BBC Films]]''|author=Tajpal Rathore|accessdate=10 August 2012|date=22 October 2007}} ===Box office=== The film was screened in private a day before its release, as most of the audience could not decipher the film, they left, which resulted in a negative word of the mouth spreading. The film was further affected from negative critical reception.{{cite web|title=Jab We Met gives Box Office a breather|url=http://entertainment.oneindia.in/bollywood/box-office/2007/jab-we-met-rules-box-office-051107.html|publisher=''[[Oneindia.in]]''|author=[[Taran Adarsh]]|accessdate=11 August 2012|date=5 November 2007}} ''No Smoking'' opened to a poor response at the box office, and was one of the biggest disasters of the year.{{cite web|title=´Jab We Met´ Succeeds ; ´No Smoking´ Sinks ; ´Bhool Bhulaiyaa´ Races To 41 crores |url=http://www.planetbollywood.com/BoxOffice/index.php?id=49|publisher=''Planet Bollywood''|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=2 November 2007}} ==Awards== [[53rd Filmfare Awards]] * ''Nominated'': [[Filmfare Award for Best Art Direction]] - [[Wasiq Khan]] * ''Nominated'': [[Filmfare Award for Best Cinematographer]] - [[Rajeev Ravi]] * ''Nominated'': [[Filmfare Award for Best Special Effects]] - Sudeepto Bose{{cite web|title=Sudeepto Bose VFX artist|url=http://www.sudeepto.com|publisher=SudeeptoBose}} ==Impact and legacy== {{Quote box |quote = “I was extremely angry and bitter after ''No Smoking''. People reviewed me rather than the movie. It was a new kind of film and while it was getting international recognition, in my own country it was being ripped apart. I learnt a lesson though and it was that if you have to do something new, you have to go step by step. First and foremost, look at how the film would recover money. ''No Smoking'' was an expensive film and it hurts" |source = [[Anurag Kashyap]]'s reaction to the failure of ''No Smoking''. |width = 35%}} The film was made on huge budget and at the time when it sank at the box office, the director Kashyap fell into depression not expecting the critics to lash at it. He admitted that most of the audience expected to see a film about quitting smoking and that pre release the extensively played item song featuring Basu gave audience the wrong type of image as they expected her to play the lead role opposite Abraham. In 2011 Kashyap stated that ''No Smoking'' was his favourite, of all his films.{{cite web|title=Anurag Kashyap: I loved No Smoking the most|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/slide-show/slide-show-1-part-two-interview-of-anurag-kashyap/20110905.htm|publisher=''[[Rediff.com]]''|author=Aseem Chhabra|date=5 September 2011|accessdate=24 August 2012}} ''No Smoking'' has garnered a strong [[Cult film|cult following]], among Kashyap fans and movie buffs, who rate it as one of the most abstract stories, which can have [[Aesthetic interpretation|multiple interpretations]].{{cite web|url=http://forbesindia.com/blog/life/i-dont-try-to-make-cult-films-anurag-kashyap/|publisher=''[[Forbes|Forbes India]]''|author=Abhishek Raghunath|accessdate=9 August 2012|date=1 January 2012|title=I Don’t Try to Make Cult Films: Anurag Kashyap}} The film has seen more positive response from overseas than in India,{{cite web|url=http://www.glamsham.com/movies/scoops/09/feb/12-i-was-extremely-angry-n-bitter-after-no-smoking-020909.asp|publisher=''Glamsham''|author=Sampurn|accessdate=11 August 2012|date=12 February 2009|title=Anurag Kashyap: I was extremely angry & bitter after No Smoking}} though the audience now views it as a modern masterpiece, critical reception has still not improved. It is often compared to the films of [[Hollywood]] director [[David Lynch]], who is known for his cult surrealistic films.{{cite web|title=Why Anurag Kashyap is like Bhansali|url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/nov/15rs.htm|publisher=''[[Rediff.com]]''|author=Raja Sen|accessdate=16 August 2012|date=15 November 2007}}{{cite web|title=Gangs of Wasseypur - Gags of Wasseypur|url=http://www.thehindu.com/arts/cinema/article3754000.ece|publisher=''[[The Hindu]]''|author=[[Sudhish Kamath]]|accessdate=16 August 2012|date=11 August 2012}} No Smoking has been played at several [[Film festivals]]. It was played at the Indian film festival and won multiple awards, after being repeatedly screened. The film was also played at various venues in [[Beijing]], ([[China]]) and [[Rome]]. ===Interpretations=== ''No Smoking'' is notable as being the only [[Bollywood]] film which can have multiple interpretations.{{cite web|title=What is your Interpretation|url=http://interpretationofnosmoking.blogspot.in/2010/03/interpretaion-of-no-smoking-by-anurag.html|publisher=blogspot|accessdate=1 February 2015|date=8 March 2010}} Kashyap explained that the film has nothing to do with quitting smoking but relatively about the state of mind, which refers to the [[Mood (psychology)|mood]] or the [[Mental health|mental state]] of the films [[protagonist]], K. He has left it upon the audience themselves to make their own interpretations and speculate what transpires.{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/movies/anurag-kashyap-no-smoking-is-a-state-of-mind-news-bollywood-kkfuyRbdibj.html|publisher=''[[Sify]]''|author=Sonia Chopra|accessdate=11 August 2012|date=26 October 2007|title=Anurag Kashyap: No Smoking is a state of mind}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/oct/30anurag.htm|publisher=''[[Rediff.com]]''|accessdate=11 August 2012|date=30 October 2007|title=The director's guide to No Smoking}} There are many unofficial [[blog]]s on the internet by fans trying to solve the films meaning. ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = No Smoking | type = [[Album]] | artist = [[Vishal Bhardwaj]] | cover = | alt = | released = {{start date|df=yes|2007|09}} (India) | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Film soundtrack|Feature film soundtrack]] | length = | label = [[Eros Labs|Eros Entertainment]] | producer = Kumar Mangat & [[Vishal Bhardwaj]] | prev_title = [[Omkara (2006 film)|Omkara]] | prev_year = 2006 | next_title = [[U, Me Aur Hum]] | next_year = 2008 }} The official soundtrack was composed by [[Vishal Bhardwaj]] who also co-produced the film. Background Score was done by Hitesh Sonik & [[Clinton Cerejo]]. The lyrics were penned by [[Gulzar (lyricist)|Gulzar]].{{cite web|title=No Smoking songs|url=http://ww.smashits.com/no-smoking/songs-6592.html|publisher=SmasHits.com|accessdate=18 August 2012}} The music rights were sold to [[Eros Entertainment]] and were released in September 2007.{{cite web| title=No Smoking(Music) - Erosentertainment| work=Music Review| url=http://music.erosentertainment.com/musicstore/Search_Result.asp?Page=11|publisher=''Eros Music''|accessdate=14 October 2007}} The album is available to download from [[iTunes Store|iTunes]].{{cite web|title=No Smoking - EP (Original Soundtrack)|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/no-smoking-ep-original-soundtrack/id264976991|publisher=[[iTunes Store]]|accessdate=10 August 2012}} ===Track listing=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Song !! Singer(s)!! Lyricist !! Duration |- |''Phook De (Club Mix)'' | [[Rekha Bhardwaj]] | [[Gulzar (lyricist)|Gulzar]] | 5:15 |- | ''Kash Laga'' | [[Sukhwinder Singh]], [[Daler Mehndi]], [[Vishal Bhardwaj]] | [[Gulzar (lyricist)|Gulzar]] | 5:47 |- | ''Ash Tray'' | Deva Sengupta | [[Gulzar (lyricist)|Gulzar]] | 4:39 |- | ''Phook De'' | [[Sukhwinder Singh]] | [[Gulzar (lyricist)|Gulzar]] | 5:55 |- | ''Jab Bhi Ciggaret'' | [[Sunidhi Chauhan]] | [[Gulzar (lyricist)|Gulzar]] | 5:06 |- | ''Jab Bhi Ciggaret (Jazz)'' | [[Adnan Sami]] | [[Gulzar (lyricist)|Gulzar]] | 5:03 |- |} ===Reception=== The soundtrack album received critical acclaim. Abhishek Singh from ''Planet Bollywood'' said "Over all, as expected, the music turns out to be daringly different and in complete contrast to anything that you might have ever listened. Almost all the songs carry the message of the film along and for that reason only, one can’t be sure of this album on a stand alone basis but seen along side the concept of the movie, it sure hits the bulls eye".{{cite web|title=No Smoking music review|url=http://www.planetbollywood.com/displayReview.php?id=101407073113|publisher=''Planet Bollywood''|accessdate=11 August 2012}} Joginder Tuteja from ''[[India Fm]]'' said "With music by Vishal Bhardwaj and lyrics by Gulzar saab, one expects an unconventional soundtrack in the offering. Well, unconventional it is and in at least a couple of places, exciting too! This has to be one of the most original tracks ever written. 'Jab Bhi Cigarette' is the opening song of the album and may well be termed as the title song of the album".{{cite web|title=No Smoking - Music Review|url=http://entertainment.oneindia.in/music/reviews/2007/no-smoking-music-review-021107.html|publisher=''[[Oneindia.in]]''|author=Joginder Tuteja|accessdate=11 August 2012|date=2 November 2007}} Satyajit from ''Glamsham'' said "''No Smoking'' dares to be different for chartering unexplored territories and have surprises in raucously driven vivacious tracks like “Phoonk De” and “Jab Bhi Cigarette”. [[Rekha Bhardwaj]]’s peculiar nasal twang will be garnering major spotlight in “Phoonk De (club mix) with chartbusting success after her subtle and submissive ''[[Laaga Chunari Mein Daag]]''".{{cite web|title=Music Review : No Smoking|url=http://www.glamsham.com/music/reviews/13_music_review_no_smoking_100701.asp|publisher=''Glamsham''|author=Satyajit|accessdate=11 August 2012}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0995740|No Smoking}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|1192358-1192358-no_smoking|No Smoking}} {{Anurag Kashyap}} {{DEFAULTSORT:No Smoking (2007 Film)}} [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:2000s psychological thriller films]] [[Category:2000s Hindi-language films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:Smoking cessation]] [[Category:Films directed by Anurag Kashyap]] [[Category:Indian neo-noir films]] [[Category:Films based on short fiction]] [[Category:Films shot in Kazakhstan]] [[Category:Films shot in Russia]] [[Category:Films shot in Uzbekistan]] [[Category:Films scored by Vishal Bhardwaj]] [[Category:Films featuring an item number]] [[Category:Indian avant-garde and experimental films]] [[Category:Surrealist films]] [[Category:Indian psychological thriller films]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Open PHACTS | image = | image_border = | size = frameless | caption = | map = | msize = | mcaption = | abbreviation = | motto = | formation = 2011 | extinction = | type = [[Public–private partnership]] | status = | purpose = [[Semantic interoperability]] for [[drug discovery]] through [[Open innovation]] | headquarters = | location = | coords = | region_served = | membership = 27 member organisations | leader_title = | leader_name = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | budget = | key_people = {{Plainlist| * [[Antony John Williams]] * [[Carole Goble]] * [[Barend Mons]] * [[Gerhard Ecker]]}} | website = {{Plainlist| * {{URL|www.openphacts.org}} * {{URL|https://github.com/openphacts}}}} | remarks = }} '''Open PHACTS''' (Open Pharmacological Concept [[Triplestore|Triple Store]]) is a European initiative [[public–private partnership]] between academia, publishers, enterprises, [[Pharmaceutical industry|pharmaceutical companies]] and other organisations working to enable better, cheaper and faster [[drug discovery]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Williams | first1 = A. J. | authorlink1 = Antony John Williams| last2 = Harland | first2 = L. | last3 = Groth | first3 = P. | last4 = Pettifer | first4 = S. | authorlink4 = Steve Pettifer| last5 = Chichester | first5 = C. | last6 = Willighagen | first6 = E. L. | last7 = Evelo | first7 = C. T. | last8 = Blomberg | first8 = N. | last9 = Ecker | first9 = G. | authorlink9 = Gerhard Ecker| last10 = Goble | first10 = C. | authorlink10 = Carole Goble| last11 = Mons | first11 = B. | authorlink11 = Barend Mons| title = Open PHACTS: Semantic interoperability for drug discovery | doi = 10.1016/j.drudis.2012.05.016 | journal = [[Drug Discovery Today]]| volume = 17 | issue = 21–22 | pages = 1188–1198 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22683805 | pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Ecker | first1 = G. F. | last2 = Williams-Jones | first2 = B. | doi = 10.1002/minf.201280004 | title = Open Innovation in Drug Discovery | journal = [[Molecular Informatics]]| volume = 31 | issue = 8 | pages = 519 | year = 2012 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal| first1 = Alasdair J.G. | last1 = Gray| first2 = Paul |last2 = Groth| first3 = Antonis | last3 = Loizou| first4 = Sune | last4 = Askjaer| first5 = Christian | last5 = Brenninkmeijer| first6 = Kees | last6 = Burger| first7 = Christine| last7 = Chichester| first8 = Chris T. | last8 = Evelo| first9 = Carole | last9 = Goble| authorlink9 = Carole Goble| first10 = Lee | last10 = Harland| first11 = Steve| last11 = Pettifer| authorlink11 = Steve Pettifer| first12 = Mark| last12 = Thompson| first13 = Andra| last13 = Waagmeester| first14 = Antony John| last14 = Williams| authorlink14 = Antony John Williams| doi=10.3233/SW-2012-0088| title = Applying linked data approaches to pharmacology: Architectural decisions and implementation| journal = Semantic Web| volume = 5 | issue = 2| pages = 101–113| year = 2014 | pmid = | pmc = | arxiv = 1005.2643}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal| pmid = 24267948| year = 2013| author1 = Ciccarese| first1 = P| title = PAV ontology: Provenance, authoring and versioning| journal = [[Journal of Biomedical Semantics]]| volume = 4| issue = 1| pages = 37| last2 = Soiland-Reyes| first2 = S| last3 = Belhajjame| first3 = K| last4 = Gray| first4 = A. J.| last5 = Goble| first5 = C| last6 = Clark| first6 = T| doi = 10.1186/2041-1480-4-37}}</ref> It has been funded by the [[Innovative Medicines Initiative]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.imi.europa.eu/content/open-phacts |title=Open PHACTS at IMI - The Innovative Medicines Initiative |format= |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> selected as part of three projects to "design methods for common standards and sharing of data for more efficient drug development and patient treatment in the future".<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Watson | first1 = R. | doi = 10.1136/bmj.d1577 | title = Europe provides €172m for research into innovative medicines | journal = BMJ | volume = 342 | pages = d1577 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21393337| pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | doi = 10.1007/978-3-642-41338-4_5| chapter = Incorporating Commercial and Private Data into an Open Linked Data Platform for Drug Discovery| title = The Semantic Web – ISWC 2013| volume = 8219| pages = 65| series = Lecture Notes in Computer Science| year = 2013| last1 = Goble | first1 = C. | authorlink1 = Carole Goble| last2 = Gray | first2 = A. J. G. | last3 = Harland | first3 = L. | last4 = Karapetyan | first4 = K. | last5 = Loizou | first5 = A. | last6 = Mikhailov | first6 = I. | last7 = Rankka | first7 = Y. N. | last8 = Senger | first8 = S. | last9 = Tkachenko | first9 = V. | last10 = Williams | first10 = A. J. | authorlink10 = Antony John Williams| last11 = Willighagen | first11 = E. L. | isbn = 978-3-642-41337-7}}</ref>
==Partnerships== A total of 27 partners are currently involved including: * Academia: [[Maastricht University]], [[University of Santiago de Compostela]], [[University of Vienna]], [[University of Manchester]], [[University of Bonn]], [[Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics]], [[European Bioinformatics Institute]], [[Vrije Universiteit]] of Amsterdam, [[Technical University of Denmark]], [[University of Hamburg]] * Pharmaceutical companies: [[Pfizer]], [[Merck KGaA]], [[Eli Lilly and Company]], [[Novartis]], [[GlaxoSmithKline]], [[AstraZeneca]] * Other companies: [[ChemSpider]], [[Biovia]], Eagle Genomics, Entagen * Publishers: [[Royal Society of Chemistry]], [[Thomson Reuters]]
==Drug discovery== The Open Pharmacological Space created by the consortium is intended to support [[open innovation]] and in-house non-public drug discovery research<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Müller | first1 = S. | last2 = Weigelt | first2 = J. | title = Open-access public-private partnerships to enable drug discovery--new approaches | journal = IDrugs : the investigational drugs journal | volume = 13 | issue = 3 | pages = 175–180 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20191434 }}</ref> by removing bottlenecks in [[drug development]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Dalgleish | first1 = R. | last2 = Molero | first2 = E. | last3 = Kidd | first3 = R. | last4 = Jansen | first4 = M. | last5 = Past | first5 = D. | last6 = Robl | first6 = A. | last7 = Mons | first7 = B. | last8 = Diaz | first8 = C. | last9 = Mons | first9 = A. | last10 = Brookes | first10 = A. J. | title = Solving bottlenecks in data sharing in the life sciences | doi = 10.1002/humu.22123 | journal = Human Mutation | volume = 33 | issue = 10 | pages = 1494–1496 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22623360 | pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Mons | first1 = B. | authorlink1 = Barend Mons| last2 = Van Haagen | first2 = H. | last3 = Chichester | first3 = C. | last4 = Hoen | first4 = P. B. 'T. | last5 = Den Dunnen | first5 = J. T. | last6 = Van Ommen | first6 = G. | last7 = Van Mulligen | first7 = E. | last8 = Singh | first8 = B. | last9 = Hooft | first9 = R. | last10 = Roos | doi = 10.1038/ng0411-281 | first10 = M. | last11 = Hammond | first11 = J. | last12 = Kiesel | first12 = B. | last13 = Giardine | first13 = B. | last14 = Velterop | first14 = J. | authorlink14 = Jan Velterop| last15 = Groth | first15 = P. | last16 = Schultes | first16 = E. | title = The value of data | journal = Nature Genetics | volume = 43 | issue = 4 | pages = 281–283 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21445068| pmc = }}</ref> Resources from the project are publicly available on [[GitHub]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://github.com/openphacts |title=Open PHACTS on GitHub |format= |work= |accessdate=2012-07-10}}</ref>
To reduce the barriers to drug discovery in industry, academia and for small businesses, the Open PHACTS consortium built the Open PHACTS Discovery Platform. This platform is freely available, integrating pharmacological data from a variety of information resources and providing tools and services to question this integrated data to support pharmacological research.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
[[File:Mengniu Milk Deluxe OMP.png|thumb|A pack of Mengniu Milk Deluxe contains OMP, sold for about twice the price of standard milk.<ref name="caijing1" />]] '''Osteoblast milk protein''' ('''OMP''', {{zh|造骨牛奶蛋白}}) is the name used by [[Mengniu]], a Chinese dairy company, for a [[milk protein]] used as a [[food additive]] in their Milk Deluxe ({{zh|s=特伦苏|t=特倫蘇|p=Telunsu}}) since 2005.<ref name="hindu">{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/099200903021022.htm|title=Health official says milk additive OMP safe but not legal|date=2009-03-02|work=[[The Hindu]] via [[Xinhua]]|accessdate=2009-03-06}}</ref> It is supposed to help the absorption of [[calcium]] and promote [[bone growth]] in the [[osteoblast]]s and prevent [[osteoporosis]].<ref name="Ang">{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/feb/12/china-milk-investigation/|title=China milk investigation|last=Ang|first=Audra|date=2009-02-12|work=[[The Washington Times]] / [[Associated Press|AP]]|accessdate=2009-03-06}}</ref>
In February 2009, the safety of OMP was questioned by the [[General Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine]] (AQSIQ), national quality supervision department in China, when they were doing a general clean-up on the use of food additives after the [[2008 Chinese milk scandal]] where [[melamine]] was found in some milk products.<ref name="Ang" /><ref name="Wei">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/afx/2009/02/11/afx6037577.html|title=China says probing two firms on milk products|last=Wei|first=Michael|author2=Lucy Hornby |author3=Ben Blanchard |author4=ed. Jerry Norton |date=2009-02-11|work=[[Forbes]] / [[Reuters]]|accessdate=2009-03-06}}</ref> Mengniu stopped adding OMP to its milk on February 2 after a government order, but did not recall products already on the market.<ref name="chinacsr">{{cite news|url=http://www.chinacsr.com/en/2009/02/16/4478-mengniu-asked-not-to-add-omp-to-milk-deluxe/|title=Mengniu Asked Not To Add OMP To Milk Deluxe|date=2009-02-16|work=chinacsr.com|publisher=BDL Media Ltd.|accessdate=2009-03-06}}</ref><ref name="Guodong">{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-02/14/content_10819644.htm|title=Mengniu milk additive not harmful to health, MOH says|author=DU Guodong (ed.)|date=2009-02-14|work=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|accessdate=2009-03-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217081845/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-02/14/content_10819644.htm|archivedate=2009-02-17|df=}}</ref> On February 13 the [[Ministry of Health of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Health]] stated that OMP is "not harmful to human health",<ref name="Guodong" /> but the ban on its use stayed in place because the importer had not submitted the necessary paperwork.<ref name="hindu" /><ref name="caijing2" />
The raw ingredients for OMP were imported from the [[Tatua Co-operative Dairy Company]] in New Zealand<ref name="Wei" /><ref name="stuff">{{cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/farming/1398343/Another-NZ-dairy-firm-in-China-milk-probe|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130112041610/http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/farming/1398343/Another-NZ-dairy-firm-in-China-milk-probe|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-01-12|title=Another NZ dairy firm in China milk probe|date=2009-03-05|work=stuff.co.nz|publisher=[[Fairfax New Zealand]] / [[NZPA]]|accessdate=2009-03-06}}</ref> via [[Shanghai Tongyuan Food Technology Co. Ltd.]] ({{lang|zh|上海统圆食品技术有限公司}}).<ref name="caijing1">{{cite news|url=http://english.caijing.com.cn/2009-03-04/110111459.html|title=Dairy's Pride Sours in Additive Controversy|last=Li|first=Hujun|author2=Wang, Shanshan |author3=Liu, Jingjing |author4= Zhao, Hejuan |date=2009-03-04|work=[[Caijing]]|accessdate=2009-03-06}}, translation from [http://magazine.caijing.com.cn/templates/inc/chargecontent2.jsp?id=110075606&time=2009-03-02&cl=106 {{lang|zh-Hans|蒙牛OMP是怎样炼成的？}}]</ref><ref name="hk" /> Mengniu first stated that the major active ingredient in OMP is [[Insulin-like growth factor 1]] (IGF-1), but later denied adding IGF-1 and said that OMP is the same as [[Milk Basic Protein]] (MBP). IGF-1 could possibly cause [[cancer]] in extreme doses.<ref name="caijing1" /> The company claimed that the additive is widely used in Europe, the United States and Japan, and had been certified by the [[New Zealand Food Safety Authority]] and the [[U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA). However it turned out that the FDA letter<ref name="GRAS">{{cite web|url=http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~rdb/opa-g196.html |title=Agency Response Letter GRAS Notice No. GRN 000196 |last=Tarantino |first=Laura M. |date=2006-09-01 |publisher=FDA - CFSAN/Office of Food Additive Safety |accessdate=2009-03-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117080848/http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~rdb/opa-g196.html |archivedate=January 17, 2009 }}</ref> referred to a perhaps different additive used by the Japanese [[Snow Brand Milk Products Company]]. A director of the [[Guangdong Dairy Industry Association]] said that OMP is seldom used in milk products overseas and no conclusion about the impact of OMP on human health has been proven globally. The association may contest any official declaration from the Ministry of Health that OMP is safe.<ref name="caijing2">{{cite news|url=http://english.caijing.com.cn/2009-02-20/110072112.html|title=U.S. FDA Denies It Approved Mengniu Additive|last=Li|first=Hujun|date=2009-02-20|work=[[Caijing]] Online|accessdate=2009-03-06}}</ref>
According to Mengniu and the Ministry of Health, OMP is made from milk by degreasing by [[Skimmer (machine)|skimming]] and [[Membrane technology|membrane filtration]] and its major components are [[lactoferrin]] and [[lactoperoxidase]].<ref name="caijing1" /><ref name="hk">{{cite press release |title=LCQ11: Dairy products containing OMP and IGF-1 |url=http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/200903/04/P200903040156.htm |publisher=[[Government of Hong Kong]] |date=2009-03-04 |accessdate=2009-03-06}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Food additives]] [[Category:Milk]] [[Category:Health in China]] [[Category:Food safety]]

'''Patient-delivered (partner) therapy''' (PDT or PDPT), also called '''expedited partner therapy''' (EPT),<ref>[http://www.ama-assn.org/ama/no-index/about-ama/16410.shtml Report 7 of the Council on Science and Public Health (A-06) - Expedited Partner Therapy (Patient-delivered Partner Therapy): An Update] American Medical Association. Retrieved on Nov 22, 2009</ref> is the clinical practice of treating the sex partners of patients diagnosed with [[Chlamydia infection|chlamydia]] or [[gonorrhea]] by providing prescriptions or medications to the patient to take to his/her partner without the health care provider first examining the partner.<ref name=EPTFinalReport2006>[https://www.cdc.gov/std/treatment/EPTFinalReport2006.pdf Expedited Partner Therapy in the Management of Sexually Transmitted Diseases (2 February 2006)] U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention National Center for HIV, STD, and TB Prevention</ref>
EPT may also include other forms of implementation than PDPT.<ref name=EPTFinalReport2006/>
==Efficacy== PDPT works as an addition to the usual ''patient referral'', the latter being that the [[index patient]] has a responsibility for informing sex partners of their exposure to a sexually transmitted infection.<ref name=trelle/> PDPT significantly reduces the risk of persistent or recurrent infection compared with patient referral alone; a review found that addition of PDPT gives a [[relative risk]] of 0.73, with a 95% [[confidence interval]] of 0.57 to 0.93.<ref name=trelle>{{cite journal |vauthors=Trelle S, Shang A, Nartey L, Cassell JA, Low N |title=Improved effectiveness of partner notification for patients with sexually transmitted infections: systematic review |journal=BMJ |volume=334 |issue=7589 |pages=354 |date=February 2007 |pmid=17237298 |pmc=1801006 |doi=10.1136/bmj.39079.460741.7C |url=}}</ref>
Pitfalls include that EPT may compromise the quality of care provided to partners, especially when used as a first-line approach for partners who would otherwise seek clinical services. For instance, the medication could cause serious adverse reactions, including allergy, which could have been foreseen by a visit to a health care provider.<ref>[http://www.cdph.ca.gov/pubsforms/Guidelines/Documents/CA-STD-PDPT-Guidelines.pdf Patient-Delivered Partner Therapy for [[Chlamydia trachomatis]] and Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Interim Guidance for Medical Providers in California] California Department of Public Health. Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STD) Control Branch, in collaboration with: California STD Controllers Association. June 2011</ref>
==See also== *[[Sexually transmitted disease]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Sexually transmitted diseases and infections]]
