{{Infobox royalty |name=Princess Tsehai |birth_date={{Birth date|1919|10|13|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Addis Ababa]], [[Ethiopian Empire]] |death_date={{Death date and age|1942|8|17|1919|10|13|df=y}} |death_place= [[Nekemte]], [[Ethiopian Empire]] |spouse= Lieutenant-General ''[[Ethiopian aristocratic and court titles|Lij]]'' [[Abiye Abebe]] |father=[[Haile Selassie|Haile Selassie I of Ethiopia]] |mother=[[Menen Asfaw]] |place of burial=[[Ba'eta Le Mariam Monastery]] |religion = [[Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church|Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo]] |full name = Walatta Birhane |house = [[Solomonic Dynasty|House of Solomon]] }} '''Princess Tsehai Haile Selassie''' (13 October 1919 – 17 August 1942) was the third daughter and fourth child of Emperor [[Haile Selassie]] and Empress [[Menen Asfaw]] of [[Ethiopian Empire|Ethiopia]].
==Biography== Princess Tsehai was born in [[Addis Ababa]]. She often accompanied the Emperor to public events during his exile in [[Great Britain]] (1936–1941), where she trained as a nurse at [[London]]'s [[Great Ormond Street Hospital for Sick Children]]. She graduated as a state registered children's nurse on 25 August 1939. After the restoration of her father in 1941, she married Lieutenant-General (later Brigadier-General) ''[[Ethiopian aristocratic and court titles|Lij]]'' [[Abiye Abebe]], and moved with him to [[Welega Province]] when he was appointed governor there.
She later worked at [[Dessie]] Hospital in [[Ethiopian Empire|Ethiopia]].
Princess Tsehai died in [[Nekemte]] on 17 August 1942, from complications during childbirth. Her baby did not survive. She was buried in the crypt of the [[Ba'eta Le Mariam Monastery]] in Addis Ababa that had been built as the mausoleum church of Emperor [[Menelik II]].<ref>Mentioned by her father in his ''Life and Ethiopia's Progress'' (translated by [[Edward Ullendorff]] [Chicago: Research Associates, 1999]), at p. 296. Ullendorff's note provides some details about her and Abiye Abebe's lives.</ref>
Emperor Haile Selassie founded the Princess Tsehai Memorial Hospital in her memory, which also served as a nursing school. After the [[Ethiopian Civil War|1974 revolution]], the hospital was renamed the [[Armed Forces General Hospital (Ethiopia)|Armed Forces General Hospital]].
== Patronages == * Honorary President of the Association for the Benefit of Ethiopian Women (1935-1942).
== Honours == === National honours === * Knight Grand Cordon with Collar of the [[Order of the Queen of Sheba]] (1930).<ref>[http://www.royalark.net/Ethiopia/shoa6.htm Royal Ark]</ref> * Imperial Coronation Medal (1930).<ref>[http://www.royalark.net/Ethiopia/shoa6.htm Royal Ark]</ref>
[[File:Waizero Manen.jpg|thumb|250px|center|Empress [[Menen Asfaw]] seated in the center and Standing women from left to right are '''Princess Tsehai''', [[Princess Tenagnework]], and [[Princess Zenebework]], her daughters, and on the far right is Princess [[Wolete Israel Seyoum]], her daughter-in-law.]]
==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Princess Tsehai of Ethiopia''' |2= 2. [[Haile Selassie|''Emperor'' Haile Selassie I]] |3= 3. [[Menen Asfaw|''Itege'' Menen Asfaw]] |4= 4. [[Makonnen Wolde Mikael|''Ras'' Mäkonnen Wäldä-Mika'él Guddisa]] |5= 5. [[Yeshimebet Ali|''Woizero'' Yeshimebet Ali Abba Jifar]] |6= 6. ''Dejazmach'' Asfaw Mikael, ''Jantirar'' of [[Ambassel]] |7= 7. ''Woizero'' Sehin Mikael |8= 8. ''Dejazmach'' Wolde Mikael Gudessa |9= 9. ''Immabet'' Tenagnework Sahle Selassie |10= 10. ''Dejazmach'' Ali Abba Jifar of [[Oromo people|Woreilu]] |11= 11. ''Immabet-Hoy'' Walatta Ihata Giyorgis Yimeru |14= 14. [[Mikael of Wollo|''Negus'' Mikael of Zion]] |15= 15. ''Woizero'' Fantaye |16= 16. ''Dejazmach'' Wolde Malakot Yamana Krestos |17= 17. ''Woizero'' Kalama Worq |18= 18. [[Sahle Selassie|''Meridazmach'' Sahle Selassie]] |19= 19. ''Woizero'' Yimegnushal Ayele |22= 22. ''Ato'' Yimeru of [[Gurage people|Gurage]] |23= 23. ''Woizero'' Araza-Aregai |28= 28. ''Imam'' Ali Abba Bula |29= 29. ''Woizero'' Getie |30= 30. Gabru |31= 31. Hirut }}

{{other uses|Ptosis (disambiguation)}}{{Infobox medical condition | Name = Ptosis (breasts) | Image = Ptosis.jpg | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = {{ICD9|611.81}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = plastic | eMedicineTopic = 128 | MeshID = }} Female [[breast]] '''ptosis''' or sagging is a natural consequence of [[Ageing|aging]]. The rate at which a woman's breasts drop and the degree of ptosis depends on many factors. The key factors influencing breast ptosis over a woman's lifetime are [[cigarette]] smoking, her [[gravidity|number of pregnancies]], [[gravity]], higher [[body mass index]], larger [[bra]] cup size, and significant weight gain and loss.<ref name=thompson/> <ref>{{Cite journal |title=Breast Ptosis: Causes and Cure |journal=Annals of Plastic Surgery |volume=64 |issue=5 |pages=579-584 |date= May 2010 |url=https://journals.lww.com/annalsplasticsurgery/Abstract/2010/05000/Breast_Ptosis__Causes_and_Cure.16.aspx |doi=10.1097/SAP.0b013e3181c39377 }}</ref> Post-menopausal women or people with collagen deficiencies (such as [[ehlers-danlos|Ehlers-Danlos]]) may experience increased ptosis due to a loss of skin elasticity. Many women and medical professionals mistakenly believe that [[breastfeeding]] increases sagging. It is also commonly believed that the breast itself offers insufficient support and that wearing a [[bra]] prevents sagging which has not been found to be true.<ref name=stuart/>
[[Plastic surgeons]] categorize the degree of ptosis by evaluating the position of the [[nipple]] relative to the [[inframammary crease|infra-mammary fold]], the point at which the underside of the breasts attach to the chest wall. In the most advanced stage, the nipples are below the fold and point towards the ground.
== Breast structure == {{main|breast}} Anatomically, a female's [[breast]]s do not contain any [[muscle]] but are composed of soft, glandular tissue. Breasts are composed of [[mammary gland]]s, [[Lactiferous duct|milk duct]]s, [[adipose tissue]] (fat tissue) and [[Cooper's ligaments]].
Mammary glands remain relatively constant throughout life. Fat tissue surrounds the mammary glands, and its volume will normally vary throughout life. Although the exact mechanisms that determine breast shape and size are largely unknown,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Page |first1=KA |last2=Steele |first2=JR |title=Breast motion and sports brassiere design: Implications for future research |journal=Sports Medicine |volume=27 |issue=4 |pages=205–211 |date=April 1999 |pmid=10367331 |url=http://content.wkhealth.com/linkback/openurl?issn=0112-1642&volume=27&issue=4&spage=205|doi=10.2165/00007256-199927040-00001 }}</ref> the amount and distribution of fat tissue and, to a lesser extent, mammary tissue, cause variations in breast size, shape and volume. The Cooper's ligaments offer minimal [[connective tissue]] to support the breasts.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://theboobuddy.com/pages/the-coopers-ligament |title=The Cooper's Ligaments |website=Boobuddy }}</ref>
== Causes == {{See also|Women and smoking#Unique gender differences and health effects for females}}
[[University of Kentucky]] [[plastic surgery|plastic surgeon]] Brian Rinker encountered many women in his practice who attributed their sagging breasts to [[breastfeeding]], which was also the usual belief among medical practitioners.<ref name=lauersen>{{cite book |last=Lauersen |first=Niels H. |title=The Complete Book of Breast Care |year=1998 |publisher=Fawcett Columbine/Ballantine |location=New York |isbn=978-0-449-91241-6 |author2=Stukane, Eileen |quote=...there is no medical reason to wear a bra, so the decision is yours, based on your own personal comfort and aesthetics. Whether you have always worn a bra or always gone braless, age and breastfeeding will naturally cause your breasts to sag.}}</ref> He decided to find out if this was true, and between 1998 and 2006 he and other researchers interviewed 132 women who were seeking [[breast augmentation]] or breast lifts. They studied the women's medical history, [[body mass index]] (BMI), their [[gravidity|number of pregnancies]], their [[Cleavage (breasts)|breast cup size]] before pregnancy, and smoking status. The study results were presented at a conference of the [[American Society of Plastic Surgeons]].<ref name=thompson>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.asj.2008.07.004 |laysummary=http://www.livescience.com/1998-breastfeeding-breasts-sag-study-suggests.html |laysource=LiveScience |laydate=November 2, 2007 |title=The Effect of Breastfeeding on Breast Aesthetics |year=2008 |last1=Rinker |first1=B |last2=Veneracion |first2=M |last3=Walsh |first3=C |journal=Aesthetic Surgery Journal |volume=28 |issue=5 |pages=534–537 |pmid=19083576}}</ref>
According to Rinker's research, there are several key factors. A history of [[cigarette]] smoking "breaks down a protein in the skin called [[elastin]], which gives youthful skin its elastic appearance and supports the breast." The number of [[gravidity|pregnancies]] was strongly correlated with ptosis, with the effects increasing with each pregnancy.<ref name=thompson/> As most women age, breasts naturally yield to [[gravity]] and tend to sag and fold over the [[inframammary crease]], the lower attachment point to the chest wall. This is more true for larger-breasted women. The fourth reason was significant weight gain or loss (greater than {{convert|50|lb}}).<ref name=thompson/> Other significant factors were higher [[body mass index]] and larger [[bra]] cup size.<ref name=rinker2>{{cite journal |last1=Rinker |first1=Brian |last2=Veneracion |first2=Melissa |last3=Walsh |first3=Catherine P. |title=Breast Ptosis |journal=Annals of Plastic Surgery |date=March 2010 |page=1 |doi=10.1097/SAP.0b013e3181c39377 |pmid=20354434 |volume=64}}</ref>
In Rinker's study, 55% of respondents reported an adverse change in breast shape after pregnancy. Many women mistakenly attribute the changes and their sagging breasts to breastfeeding,<ref>{{cite web |title=Sagging Breasts |url=http://www.channel4embarrassingillnesses.com/conditions/sagging-breasts/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502011827/http://www.channel4embarrassingillnesses.com/conditions/sagging-breasts/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 May 2008 |publisher=Channel 4 |accessdate=3 February 2012 |year=2009 }}</ref> and as a result some are reluctant to nurse their infants. Research shows that breastfeeding is not the factor that many thought it was.<ref name=thompson/> Rinker concluded that "Expectant mothers should be reassured that breastfeeding does not appear to have an adverse effect upon breast appearance."<ref name=thompson/> Also discounted as causes affecting ptosis are weight gain during pregnancy and lack of participation in regular upper body exercise.<ref name=rinker2/>
=== Effect of vigorous exercise ===
When running, breasts may move three dimensionally: vertically, horizontally and laterally, in an overall figure-8 motion. Unrestrained movement of large breasts may contribute to sagging over time.<ref name=medbroadcast>{{cite web| first=Amy |last=Toffelmire| title=Why do breasts sag? |url=http://www.medbroadcast.com/channel_section_details.asp?text_id=5822&channel_id=1003&relation_id=4536 |accessdate=3 February 2012 |publisher=MedBroadcast.com}}</ref> Motion studies have revealed that when a woman runs, more than 50% of the breast's total movement is vertical, 22% is side-to-side, and 27% is in-and-out.<ref name=calf>{{cite web |title=Healthy Breast: Why You Should Wear Sports Bras on Every Workout? |url=http://www.calfreduction.net/content/healthy-breast%3A-why-you-should-wear-sports-bras-every-workout%3F |accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> A 2007 study found that encapsulation-type [[sports bra]]s, in which each cup is separately molded, are more effective than compression-type bras, which press the breasts close to the body, at reducing total breast motion during exercise. Encapsulation bras reduce motion in two of the three planes, while compression bras reduce motion in only one plane.<ref name=sciencedaily>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/02640414.2010.497542 |laysummary=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/09/070915124901.htm |laysource=ScienceDaily |laydate=September 23, 2007 |title=The effect of breast support on the kinematics of the breast during the running gait cycle |year=2010 |last1=Scurr |first1=Joanna C. |last2=White |first2=Jennifer L. |last3=Hedger |first3=Wendy |journal=Journal of Sports Sciences |volume=28 |issue=10 |pages=1103–1109 |pmid=20686995}}</ref> Previously, it was commonly believed that a woman with small to medium-size breasts benefited most from a compression-type sports bra, and women with larger breasts need an encapsulation-type sports bra.<ref name=calf/>
== Presentation == [[File:10614 Dr. Placik Breast Lift Chicago, Illinois Arlington Heights.jpg|alt=|thumb|Mastopexy: Pre-operative (left) and post-operative (right) aspects of a breast-lift surgery]] A woman's breasts change in size, volume, and position on her chest throughout her life. In young women with large breasts, sagging may occur early in life due to the effects of gravity. It may be primarily caused by the volume and weight of the breasts which are disproportionate to her body size.<ref name=thompson/>
=== Impact of pregnancy ===
During pregnancy, the [[ovaries]] and the [[placenta]] produce [[estrogen]] and [[progesterone]]. These hormones stimulate the 15 to 20 [[Lobe (anatomy)|lobes]] of the [[Mammary gland|milk-secreting glands]] in the breasts to develop. Women who experience [[gravidity|multiple pregnancies]] repeatedly stretch the skin envelope during engorgement while [[lactation|lactating]]. As a woman's breasts change in size during repeated pregnancies, the size of her breasts change as her mammary glands are engorged with milk and as she gains and loses weight with each pregnancy.<ref name=medbroadcast/> In addition, when milk production stops (usually as a child is [[weaned]]), the voluminous mammary glands diminish in volume, but they still add bulk and firmness to the breast. A 2010 review found that weight gain during pregnancy and breastfeeding were not significant risk factors for ptosis. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rinker|first=Brian|last2=Veneracion|first2=Melissa|last3=Walsh|first3=Catherine P.|date=2010-5|title=Breast ptosis: causes and cure|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20354434|journal=Annals of Plastic Surgery|volume=64|issue=5|pages=579–584|doi=10.1097/SAP.0b013e3181c39377|issn=1536-3708|pmid=20354434}}</ref>
=== Middle-aged women === [[File:Saggy Breast.jpg|thumbnail|Severe ptosis]] In middle-aged women, breast ptosis is caused by a combination of factors. If a woman has been pregnant, postpartum [[Hormone|hormonal]] changes will cause her depleted [[Lactiferous duct|milk glands]] to atrophy. Breast tissue and suspensory ligaments may also be stretched if the woman is overweight or loses and gains weight. When these factors are at play, the breast [[prolapse]]s, or falls forward. When a woman with sagging breasts stands, the underside or inferior skin of the breast folds over the [[inframammary crease|infra-mammary fold]] and lies against the chest wall. The nipple-areola complex tends to move lower on the breast relative to the inframammary crease. The nipple of the breast may also tend to point downward.
=== Post-menopausal women ===
In post-[[menopause|menopausal]] women, breast atrophy is aggravated by the inelasticity of over-stretched, aged skin.<ref>{{cite journal |last=De la Torre |first=J. I. |title=Breast Mastopexy |year=2009 |url=http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1273551-overview#showall |accessdate=February 2, 2012}}</ref> This is due in part to the reduction in [[estrogen]], which affects all body tissues, including breast tissue. The loss of estrogen reduces breast size and fullness. Estrogen is also essential to maintaining a fibrous protein called [[collagen]], which makes up much of the breast's connective tissue.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}}
=== Ptosis scale ===
[[File:Stades de affaissement.png|thumb|right|Stages of ptosis]]
Plastic surgeons describe the degree of breast sagging using a ''ptosis scale'' like the modified ''Regnault ptosis scale'' below:<ref>{{cite web|last=Younai|first=S. Sean|title=Breast Sagging - Ptosis|url=http://www.beautifulself.com/breastlift_ptosis.htm|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=parker/>
* ''Grade I: Mild ptosis''—The nipple is at the level of the infra-mammary fold and above most of the lower breast tissue. * ''Grade II: Moderate ptosis''—The nipple is located below the infra-mammary fold but higher than most of the breast tissue hangs. * ''Grade III: Advanced ptosis''—The nipple is below the inframammary fold and at the level of maximum breast projection. * ''Pseudoptosis''—The nipple is located either at or above the [[inframammary crease|infra-mammary fold]], while the lower half of the breast sags below the fold. This is most often seen when a woman stops nursing, as her milk glands atrophy, causing her breast tissue to sag. * ''Parenchymal Maldistribution''—The lower breast tissue is lacking fullness, the inframammary fold is very high, and the nipple and areola are relatively close to the fold. This is usually a developmental deformity.<ref name=parker>{{cite web|title=Anatomy of Breast Ptosis – How Breasts Sag |url=http://www.parkercenter.net/breast-enhancements-new-jersey/breast_lift_new_jersey/anatomy-of-breast-ptosis/ |accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref>
== Bras and ptosis == {{main|Brassiere}}
Since breasts are an external organ and do not contain muscle, exercise cannot improve their shape. They are not protected from external forces and are subject to gravity. Many women mistakenly believe that breasts cannot anatomically support themselves and that wearing a [[brassiere]] will prevent their breasts from sagging later in life.<ref name="007b Breast">{{cite web| url= http://www.007b.com/why_wear_bras.php |title=Female Intelligence Agency: Why do women wear bras? |website=007b Breast |accessdate=10 May 2011}}</ref> Researchers, bra manufacturers, and health professionals cannot find any evidence to support the idea that wearing a bra for any amount of time slows breast ptosis.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.007b.com/sagging.php |title=Female Intelligence Agency: What causes sagging of breasts?|website=007b Breast}}</ref> Bra manufacturers are careful to claim that bras only affect the shape of breasts while they are being worn.<ref name="007b Breast"/><ref name=cawthorne>{{cite web |first=Simon |last=Cawthorn |title=Bras, the Bare Facts |publisher=Channel 4 |date=November 2000 |url=http://breathing.com/articles/brassieres-2.htm}}</ref>
{{Quote box | quote = "We have no medical evidence that wearing a bra could prevent sagging, because the breast itself is not muscle so keeping it toned up is an impossibility". | source = –John Dixey, former [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Playtex]] | width = 27% | align = right }} Robert Mansell, a professor of surgery at the [[University Hospital of Wales]], in [[Cardiff]], reported that, "Bras don't prevent breasts from sagging, with regard to stretching of the breast ligaments and drooping in later life, that occurs very regularly anyway, and that's a function of the weight, often of heavy breasts, and these women are wearing bras and it doesn't prevent it." John Dixey, at the time [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of [[Playtex]], agreed with Mansell. "We have no medical evidence that wearing a bra could prevent sagging, because the breast itself is not muscle so keeping it toned up is an impossibility."<ref name=stuart>{{cite news|last=Stuart|first=Julia|title=Don't burn your bra just yet |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/dont-burn-your-bra-just-yet-622008.html |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=4 February 2012 |date=November 2, 2000}}</ref>
Two small studies provide some indication that wearing a bra may have an overall negative effect on sagging breasts. In a Japanese study, 11 women were measured wearing a standardised fitted bra for three months. They found that breasts became larger and lower, with the underbust measurement decreasing and the overbust increasing, while the lowest point of the breast moved downwards and outwards. The effect was more pronounced in larger-breasted women. This may be related to the particular bra chosen for the experiment, as there was some improvement after changing to a different model.<ref name=ashizawa>{{Cite journal |vauthors=Ashizawa K, Sugane A, Gunji T |title=Breast form changes resulting from a certain brassière |journal=Journal of Human Ergology |volume=19 |issue=1 |pages=53–62 |date=June 1990 |pmid=2092072}}</ref>
== Medical treatment == {{main|Mastopexy}}
Some women with ptosis choose to undergo [[plastic surgery]] to make their breasts less ptotic. Plastic surgeons offer several procedures for lifting sagging breasts. Surgery to correct the size, contour, and elevation of sagging breasts is called [[mastopexy]].<ref>{{EMedicine|plastic|128|Mastopexy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.breastbook.com/excerpts.htm |first=Dr. R. Scott |last=Smith |title=Fuller Breasts: A Woman's Guide to Breast Augmentation |publisher=Breastbook.com}}</ref> Women can also choose [[breast implants]], or may undergo both procedures. The breast-lift procedure surgically elevates the [[parenchyma|parenchymal tissue]] (breast mass), cuts and re-sizes the skin envelope, and transposes the nipple-areola complex higher upon the breast hemisphere. If sagging is present and the woman opts not to undergo mastopexy, implants are typically placed above the muscle, to fill out the breast skin and tissue. Submuscular placement can result in deformity. In these cases, the implant appears to be high on the chest, while the natural breast tissue hangs down over the implant.
== See also ==
* [[Pencil test (breasts)]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== Additional sources ==
* "Soutien-gorge de sport", in Thierry Adam, ''Gynécologie du sport''. Springer 2012, pp 305–309 * "Facteurs de l'évolution morphologique du sein après arrêt du port du soutien-gorge : étude ouverte préliminaire longitudinale chez 50 volontaires. Olivier Roussel; Jean-Denis Rouillon; Université de Franche-Comté. Faculté de médecine et de pharmacie". Thèse d’exercice : Médecine : Besançon : 2009.
{{Diseases of the breast}}

revision.text:
A '''radiological information system''' ('''RIS''')<ref> {{Citation | last = Haux | first = Reinhold | author-link = | last2 = Winter | first2 = Alfred | author2-link = | last3 = Ammenwerth | first3 = Elske | author3-link = | last4 = Brigl | first4 = Birgit | author4-link = | title = Strategic Information Management in Hospitals | place = New York | publisher = Springer-Verlag | series = Health Informatics Series | year = 2004 | language = en | url = https://books.google.at/books?id=FBk8u3nIN_AC&printsec=frontcover | isbn = 0-387-40356-6 }}</ref> is the core system for the electronic management of imaging departments. The major functions of the RIS can include patient scheduling, resource management, examination performance tracking, examination interpretation, results distribution, and procedure billing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.acr.org/Practice-Management-Quality-Informatics/Informatics/Reference-Guide |title=Reference Guide in Information Technology for the Practicing Radiologist |author= McEnery, Kevin W.|publisher=American College of Radiology |date=2018 |accessdate=2018-07-31}}</ref> RIS complements [[Hospital information system|HIS (hospital information systems)]] and [[Picture archiving and communication system|PACS (picture archiving and communication system)]], and is critical to efficient workflow to radiology practices.
== Basic features == Radiological information systems commonly support the following features: *Patient registration and scheduling *Patient list management *Modality interface using worklists *Workflow management within a department of radiology *Request and document scanning *Result entry *Digital reporting and paper-formatted export functionality *Result transmission, including faxing and e-mailing of clinical reports *Patient tracking *Interactive documents *Creation of technical files *Modality and material management
== Additional features == In addition a RIS often supports the following: *Appointment booking *PACS workflow *Custom report creation *[[HL7]] interfaces with a [[Picture archiving and communication system|PACS]]. HL7 also enables communication between HIS and RIS in addition to RIS and PACS. *[[Bill (payment)|Billing]] *[[Rule engine]]s
==See also== * [[Electronic health record|Electronic health record (EHR)]] * [[eMix]] * [[Medical imaging]] * [[Medical software]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Radiology Information System}} [[Category:Radiology]] [[Category:Medical databases]] [[Category:Electronic health records]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox project | name = UK Biobank | logo = | mission_statement = "improving the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of a wide range of serious and life-threatening illnesses – including cancer, heart diseases, stroke, diabetes, arthritis, osteoporosis, eye disorders, depression and forms of dementia." | commercial = No | type = | location = [[Stockport]], [[Greater Manchester]], UK | owner = | founder = [[Rory Collins]] | established = {{Start date|2007|01}} | website = {{URL|www.ukbiobank.ac.uk}} }}'''UK Biobank''' is a large long-term [[biobank]] study in the United Kingdom (UK) which is investigating the respective contributions of [[gene]]tic predisposition and environmental exposure (including nutrition, lifestyle, medications etc.) to the development of disease. It began in 2006.<ref>[http://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/ UK Biobank home page]</ref><ref>[http://biobank.ctsu.ox.ac.uk/showcase/ UK Biobank data showcase] enumerating currently available data</ref><ref>[http://www.egcukbiobank.org.uk/ UK Biobank Ethics and Governance Council home page]</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/3134622.stm Will Biobank Pay Off?] - 2003 [[BBC]] article mentions criticisms of UK Biobank</ref>
Based in [[Stockport]], [[Greater Manchester]], it is incorporated as a [[limited company]]<ref>Registration number 4978912</ref> and [[Charity Commission of England and Wales|registered charity]]<ref>{{EW charity|1101332}}</ref> in [[England and Wales]], and [[Office of the Scottish Charity Regulator|registered as a charity]]<ref>{{Scottish charity|SC039230}}</ref> in [[Scotland]].<ref name=biobank1>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.1001779|pmid = 25826379|title = UK Biobank: An Open Access Resource for Identifying the Causes of a Wide Range of Complex Diseases of Middle and Old Age|journal = PLOS Medicine|volume = 12|issue = 3|pages = e1001779|year = 2015|last1 = Sudlow|first1 = Cathie|last2 = Gallacher|first2 = John|last3 = Allen|first3 = Naomi|last4 = Beral|first4 = Valerie|last5 = Burton|first5 = Paul|last6 = Danesh|first6 = John|last7 = Downey|first7 = Paul|last8 = Elliott|first8 = Paul|last9 = Green|first9 = Jane|last10 = Landray|first10 = Martin|last11 = Liu|first11 = Bette|last12 = Matthews|first12 = Paul|last13 = Ong|first13 = Giok|last14 = Pell|first14 = Jill|last15 = Silman|first15 = Alan|last16 = Young|first16 = Alan|last17 = Sprosen|first17 = Tim|last18 = Peakman|first18 = Tim|last19 = Collins|first19 = Rory|pmc=4380465}}</ref><ref name=biobank2>{{Cite journal|doi= 10.1126/scitranslmed.3008601|pmid = 24553384|title = UK Biobank Data: Come and Get It|journal = Science Translational Medicine|volume = 6|issue = 224|pages = 224ed4|year = 2014|last1 = Allen|first1 = N. E.|last2 = Sudlow|first2 = C.|last3 = Peakman|first3 = T.|last4 = Collins|first4 = R.}}</ref><ref name=biobank3>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(12)60404-8|title = What makes UK Biobank special?|journal = The Lancet|volume = 379|issue = 9822|pages = 1173–1174|year = 2012|last1 = Collins|first1 = Rory|pmid=22463865}}</ref>
==Design== The study is following about 500,000 volunteers in the UK, enrolled at ages from 40 to 69. Initial enrollment took place over four years from 2006, and the volunteers will be followed for at least 30 years thereafter.
Prospective participants were invited to visit an assessment centre, at which they completed an automated questionnaire and were interviewed about lifestyle, medical history and nutritional habits; basic variables such weight, height, blood pressure etc. were measured; and blood and [[urine]] samples were taken. These samples were preserved so that it was possible to later extract [[DNA]] and measure other biologically important substances. During the whole duration of the study it was intended that all disease events, drug prescriptions and deaths of the participants are recorded in a database, taking advantage of the centralized UK [[National Health Service]].<ref name=draft>[http://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/docs/draft_protocol.pdf Draft protocol for the UK Biobank] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060214144838/http://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/docs/draft_protocol.pdf |date=2006-02-14 }}, 14 February 2002</ref><ref>[http://www.mrc.ac.uk/index/strategy-strategy/strategy-science_strategy/strategy-strategy_implementation/strategy-government_spending_review_initiatives/strategy-biobank.htm Reviewers' comments on Draft protocol, and responses]</ref>
During the initial physical examination, basic feedback was provided to the participant regarding their weight, height, BMI, [[blood pressure]], lung [[vital capacity]], [[bone density]] and [[intra-ocular pressure]]; however if any other medical problems were detected, neither the participant nor their physician would be notified. Problems detected later, such as genetic risk factors, were not conveyed to either participant or physician ("to ensure that volunteers are not penalised by insurance companies, for example, which may require customers to disclose the results of any genetic tests.").<ref name=ns>Andy Coghlan: [https://www.newscientist.com/channel/health/mg18925353.800 One million people, one medical gamble]. ''[[New Scientist]]'', 20 January 2006 </ref>
From 2012, researchers were able to apply to use the database (though they are not given access to the volunteers, who will remain strictly anonymous). A typical study using the database might compare a sample of participants who developed a particular [[disease]], such as [[cancer]], [[heart disease]], [[diabetes]] or [[Alzheimer's disease]], with a sample of those that did not, in an attempt to measure the benefits, risk contribution and interaction of specific [[genes]], lifestyles, and medications.
In 2017 researchers were able to access the database including genetic information.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/609184/uk-biobank-supercharges-medicine-with-gene-data-on-500000-brits/|title=UK Biobank supercharges medicine with gene data on 500,000 Brits|last=Regalado|first=Antonio|date=2017-11-15|work=MIT Technology Review|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> By 2017 Biobank participants had approximately 1.3 million hospitalisations, 40,000 cancer incidents with 14,000 of them having died.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Littlejohns|first=Thomas J.|last2=Sudlow|first2=Cathie|last3=Allen|first3=Naomi E.|last4=Collins|first4=Rory|title=UK Biobank: opportunities for cardiovascular research|url=https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/doi/10.1093/eurheartj/ehx254/3836952|journal=European Heart Journal|doi=10.1093/eurheartj/ehx254}}</ref>
==Development==
An incremental approach was adopted to developing the study procedures and technology, using systems designed and developed by the [[Clinical Trial Service Unit]]. This consisted of a series of pilot studies of increasing complexity and sophistication with interludes for assessment of results and additional scientific input. In-house trials were conducted during 2005, and a fully integrated clinic was run at [[Altrincham]], Greater Manchester throughout Spring 2006 where 3,800 individuals were assessed. On August 22, 2006, it was announced that the main programme would recruit men and women aged between 40 and 69 based from up to 35 regional centres.,<ref name=Guardian>Sarah Hall: [https://www.theguardian.com/science/story/0,,1855468,00.html £61m medical experiment begins] ''[[The Guardian]]'', 22 August 2006</ref> however recruitment proved more efficient than hoped and only 22 centres had been opened when the recruitment target of 500,000 was reached in 2010.
==Initial information collected==
The study was initially launched with a visit consisting of the following:<ref name=":0" />
* A [[paperless]] [[consent]] process * A [[touchscreen]] questionnaire on [[lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] and general health * Touchscreen tests of [[memory]] * An interview with a [[nurse]] on detailed medical history * Measurement of [[blood pressure]] * Measurement of sitting and standing heights * Measurement of weight * Body composition measurement using impedance * Measurement of grip-strength * Breath [[spirometry]] * [[Ultrasound]] bone densitometry of the heel * Collection of [[blood]] and [[urine]] samples
Once the visit-based assessment method was proven, the range of investigations was extended to include:<ref name=":0" />
* Test of hearing discrimination * Measurement of arterial pulse-wave velocity * Measurement of [[visual acuity]] * Measurement of [[intra-ocular pressure]] * Lens refractometry * Fundus image of [[retina]] * [[Optical coherence tomography]] scan of retina * [[Electrocardiogram]] during exercise * Collection of [[saliva]] sample * Dietary assessment
==Ethics and governance==
The UK Biobank project operates within the terms of an Ethics and Governance Framework.<ref name=EGF>[http://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/docs/EGF20082.pdf UK Biobank Ethics and Governance Framework] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227054532/http://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/docs/EGF20082.pdf |date=2008-12-27 }}. ''UK Biobank'', October 2007</ref><ref name=WTEGF>[http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/News/Media-office/Press-releases/2003/wtd002848.htm Ethics and Governance Framework for UK Biobank published for comment]. ''[[Wellcome Trust]]'', 22 September 2003</ref><ref name=BBC2>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/3134482.stm Rules for UK Biobank revealed]. ''[[BBC News]]'', 24 September 2003</ref> The Framework describes a series of standards to which UK Biobank will operate during the creation, maintenance and use of the resource and it elaborates on the commitments that are involved to those participating in the project, researchers and the public more broadly. The independent UK Biobank Ethics and Governance Council provides advice to the project and monitors its conformity with the Framework.<ref name=WTEGC>[http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/News/Media-office/Press-releases/2004/WTX022802.htm Ethics and Governance Council formed to oversee UK Biobank] ''[[Wellcome Trust]]'', 1 November 2004</ref> The Council also advises more generally on the interests of research participants and the general public in relation to the project.
The UK Biobank Board is accountable to the members of the company (the [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|Medical Research Council]] and The [[Wellcome Trust]]) and acts as company directors and as charity trustees. It is chaired by Prof Sir [[Michael Rawlins]].<ref>{{cite web|title=UK Biobank Board|url=http://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/uk-biobank-board/|accessdate=27 November 2014}}</ref>
==Recruitment==
Following the initial pilot stage in the 2005-6 period, the main study began in April 2007 and by the end of that year 50,000 people had taken part. Recruitment reached 100,000 in April 2008, 200,000 in October 2008, 300,000 in May 2009, 400,000 in November 2009 and passed the 500,000 target in July 2010. Participant enrolment was declared complete in August 2010.<ref name=BBC>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/5270478.stm Biobank set for national roll out]. ''[[BBC News]]'', 21 August 2006</ref> The volunteers were largely healthy, wealthy and white European. Rather than recruiting more participants into the biobank, the organisation is helping other institutions establish and run similar initiatives.<ref>{{cite news |title=How 500,000 Britons are critical to assessing global disease risk |url=https://www.ft.com/content/80c82a0a-a48f-11e8-8ecf-a7ae1beff35b?emailId=5b7bce24992e45000493055c |accessdate=1 October 2018 |publisher=Financial Times |date=22 August 2108}}</ref>
==Usage==
The UK Biobank dataset was opened to applications from researchers in March 2012.<ref name = BBC2012>(30 March 2012) [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-17553931 UK biobank opens to researchers] BBC News, Health, Retrieved 30 March 2015</ref> The resource is available to scientists from the UK and outside, whether they work in the public or private sector, for industry, academia or a charity, subject to verification that the research is health-related and in the public interest. Researchers are required to publish their results in an open source publication site or in an academic journal and return their findings to the UK Biobank.<ref name=":0" /> By April 2017 4,600 researchers had registered to use the resource, over 880 applications had been submitted<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/approved-research/|title=Approved research summary|last=|first=|date=2017-05-31|website=UK Biobank|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-08}}</ref> and 430 research projects were completed or underway. 130 peer-reviewed articles based on the UK Biobank data had been published by January 2017.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/published-papers/|title=Published papers, Featured Publications|last=|first=|date=|website=UK Biobank|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-08}}</ref>
==Extensions==
Since the completion of recruitment several new types of data have been added:
* During 2011-12 participants who supplied an email address were asked to assist by completing web-based dietary questionnaires, with the aim of combining a series of daily 'snapshots' to form a picture of overall nutrition. 176,012 of the participants responded at least once and 27,535 completed four questionnaires over a 16-month period.<ref name=":0" /> * During 2012-13 25,000 participants at the Stockport centre were asked to attend the assessment centre to repeat the initial measurements. It was intended to repeat these assessments every few years.<ref name=":0" /> * In 2013 to 2015, Axivity AX3 tri-axial wrist physical activity monitors were distributed to 100,000 participants, which recorded week-long triaxial acceleration at 100 Hz.<ref>(2015) [http://axivity.com/case-studies/biobank UK Biobank; Large Scale Data Collection] Axivity company web page, Retrieved 30 March 2015</ref> This data was centrally processed, and listed on the Data Showcase.<ref>[http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0169649] Large Scale Population Assessment of Physical Activity Using Wrist Worn Accelerometers: The UK Biobank Study</ref><ref>[http://biobank.ctsu.ox.ac.uk/crystal/label.cgi?id=1008] UK Biobank Data Showcase - Physical activity measurement</ref> * In 2014 and 2015 120,000 participants completed a questionnaire on cognitive functions. Four of the tests were repeats of the initial assessment and two tests (symbol digit substitution and trail making) were new.<ref name=":0" /> * In 2015 and 2016, 117,500 participants completed questionnaires on occupational history and related medical information.<ref name=":0" /> * In 2016 and 2017 137,400 participants completed questionnaires on mental health events including subjective well-being estimates, psychotic experiences, self-harm behaviours, traumatic events and cannabis and alcohol use.<ref name=":0" /> * A genomic assay of 820,967 SNPs was conducted on the participants blood samples. Data from an initial 150,000 participants were released in 2015, the remainder in July 2017<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Welsh|first=Samantha|last2=Peakman|first2=Tim|last3=Sheard|first3=Simon|last4=Almond|first4=Rachael|date=2017-01-01|year=|title=Comparison of DNA quantification methodology used in the DNA extraction protocol for the UK Biobank cohort|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1186/s12864-016-3391-x|journal=BMC Genomics|volume=18|pages=26|doi=10.1186/s12864-016-3391-x|issn=1471-2164|pmc=5217214|pmid=28056765|via=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2017/11/what-happens-when-you-put-500000-peoples-dna-online/543747/|title=What Happens When You Put 500,000 People's DNA Online|last=Zhang|first=Sarah|date=2017-11-06|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>, and the first results in October 2018 <ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1038/s41586-018-0579-z |title = The UK Biobank resource with deep phenotyping and genomic data|journal = Nature|volume = 562|pages = 203–209|year = 2018|last1 = Clare|first1 = B.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1038/s41586-018-0571-7 |title = Genome-wide association studies of brain imaging phenotypes in UK Biobank|journal = Nature|volume = 562|pages = 210–216|year = 2018|last1 = Elliott|first1 = L.T.}}</ref>. * Information from UK registries of [[death]] (from 2006) and [[cancer]] (Scotland from 1957, England and Wales from 1995) were linked to the main Biobank dataset on an ongoing basis.<ref name=":0" /> * Data from [[National Health Service|NHS]] hospital inpatient records (England from 1996, Scotland from 1997 and Wales from 1998) were linked to the main dataset on an ongoing basis.<ref name=":0" />
==Ongoing developments==
In 2018 a number of projects were underway to generate additional data:
* A set of additional assays on the blood and urinary samples were being conducted in 2016 and 2017<ref name=":0" /> with blood results expected to be released in Q4/2018. * A new type of assessment centre opened in 2014 to collect imaging data. The visits extended the initial dataset to include magnetic resonance imaging ([[MRI]]) scans of brain<ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1038/nn.4393 |title = Multimodal population brain imaging in the UK Biobank prospective epidemiological study|journal = Nature Neuroscience|volume = 19|pages = 1523–1536|year = 2016|last1 = Miller|first1 = K.L.|pmc = 5086094}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2017.10.034 |title = Image processing and Quality Control for the first 10,000 brain imaging datasets from UK Biobank|journal = NeuroImage|volume = 19|pages = 1523–1536|year = 2016|last1 = Alfaro-Almagro|first1 = F.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite biorxiv |last1=Alfaro Almagro |first1=F. |date=25 April 2017 |title=Image Processing and Quality Control for the first 10,000 Brain Imaging Datasets from UK Biobank |biorxiv=130385}}</ref> and chest regions, whole body dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry ([[DXA]]) scan of bones and joints, ultrasound measurements of the [[carotid]] arteries and resting 12-lead electrocardiogram ([[ECG]]). Initial data on 4,000 participants was released at the end of 2015 and by mid-2018 over 25,000 participants had been scanned. It is planned to scan 100,000 participants by 2022, and to do additional repeat scans on 10,000 of these 2-3 years later.<ref name=":0" /> * A subset of 2500 participants are being asked to repeat the Activity Study at quarterly intervals for a year to gauge the size of seasonal affects.
==Future plans==
In 2018 there were several plans, either provisional or underway, for enhancing the resource:
* Primary care data (such as referrals, diagnoses and prescriptions) were planned to be made available in 2018-2019.<ref name=":0" /> * Linking data from [[National Health Service|NHS]] hospital outpatient records and GP to the main dataset were being investigated in 2018.<ref name=":0" /> * Linkages to disease-specific registries and screening programs were also being investigated in 2018.<ref name=":0" /> * Exome sequencing is underway with the first batch of 50,000 sequences due to be released in mid-2019. * Full genome sequencing was being investigated with a pilot project underway.
==Opinion==
The project has been generally praised for its ambitious scope and unique potential. A [[peer review|scientific review]] panel concluded, the "UK Biobank has the potential, in ways that are not currently available elsewhere, to support a wide range of research".<ref name="BBC"/> [[Colin Blakemore]], chief executive of the [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|MRC]], predicted it "will provide scientists with extraordinary information" <ref name="Guardian"/> and "grow into a unique resource for future generations." <ref name="BBC"/>
There was some early criticism, however. GeneWatch UK, a [[pressure group]] that claims to promote the responsible use of genetic information, asserted that the complexity of the programme could result in the finding of "false links between genes and disease",<ref name="BBC"/> and expressed concern that the genetic information from patients could be [[patent]]ed for commercial purposes. Biobank's chief executive described such a risk as "extremely low, if it exists at all." <ref name="Guardian"/>
The method of recruiting participants was also initially controversial. Participants were sent letters of invitation based on names, addresses, and dates of birth provided by the NHS to the UK Biobank organisers. Although compliant with UK data protection law,<ref name="DataProtection">[http://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/faqs/contacted.php Why have you contacted me?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329101030/http://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/faqs/contacted.php |date=2010-03-29 }}</ref> some people objected to the NHS passing on such data to third parties without explicit consent, and also had concerns about the data security in such a large project.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}}
==Funding== The UK Biobank is funded by the [[Department of Health (UK)|UK Department of Health]], the Medical Research Council, the [[Scottish Executive]], and the [[Wellcome Trust]] medical research charity. The cost of the initial participant recruitment and assessment phase was 62 million [[GBP]].<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/science-news/3326762/62m-Biobank-may-not-be-worth-it-says-professor.html Daily Telegraph 2004]</ref>
==Related projects== [[European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition|EPIC]] (European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition) is a similar study that was started in 1992 and involves 520,000 men and women mostly between 35 and 70 years old from ten European countries. Participants are recontacted every three to five years. It is specifically designed to study the respective roles of diet and genes in the development of cancer.<ref name=draft/><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1038/nrc1298| pmid = 14993902| title = Diet and cancer — the European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition| journal = Nature Reviews Cancer| volume = 4| issue = 3| pages = 206–15| year = 2004| last1 = Bingham | first1 = S. | last2 = Riboli | first2 = E. | url = http://www.angelfire.com/scary/lancelot/pdf/diet_and_cancer.pdf}}</ref>
In 1996 a private company [[deCODE genetics]] Inc. planned to obtain biobank samples, health and genealogical data from the whole population of Iceland - then about 270,000 people.<ref>(9 February 2000) [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/talking_point/631374.stm What price our genes?] BBC News, Retrieved 29 January 2015</ref> The company hoped to use the data to identify genes associated with diseases<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1038/ng.3247| pmid = 25807286| title = Large-scale whole-genome sequencing of the Icelandic population| journal = Nature Genetics| volume = 47| issue = 5| pages = 435–44| year = 2015| last1 = Gudbjartsson | first1 = D. F. | last2 = Helgason | first2 = H. | last3 = Gudjonsson | first3 = S. A. | last4 = Zink | first4 = F. | last5 = Oddson | first5 = A. | last6 = Gylfason | first6 = A. | last7 = Besenbacher | first7 = S. | last8 = Magnusson | first8 = G. | last9 = Halldorsson | first9 = B. V. | last10 = Hjartarson | first10 = E. | last11 = Sigurdsson | first11 = G. T. | last12 = Stacey | first12 = S. N. | last13 = Frigge | first13 = M. L. | last14 = Holm | first14 = H. | last15 = Saemundsdottir | first15 = J. | last16 = Helgadottir | first16 = H. T. | last17 = Johannsdottir | first17 = H. | last18 = Sigfusson | first18 = G. | last19 = Thorgeirsson | first19 = G. | last20 = Sverrisson | first20 = J. T. | last21 = Gretarsdottir | first21 = S. | last22 = Walters | first22 = G. B. | last23 = Rafnar | first23 = T. | last24 = Thjodleifsson | first24 = B. | last25 = Bjornsson | first25 = E. S. | last26 = Olafsson | first26 = S. | last27 = Thorarinsdottir | first27 = H. | last28 = Steingrimsdottir | first28 = T. | last29 = Gudmundsdottir | first29 = T. S. | last30 = Theodors | first30 = A. | display-authors = 29}}</ref> and use that information to develop new drugs. deCODE genetics obtained data and DNA samples on 140,000 Icelanders<ref>Kaiser, Jocelyn (10 December 2012) [http://news.sciencemag.org/people-events/2012/12/purchase-amgen-wont-affect-decode-genetics-research-founder-says Purchase by Amgen Won't Affect deCODE Genetics' Research, Founder Says] Science, Retrieved 29 January 2015</ref> but filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 2009<ref>{{cite web|title=deCODE Genetics declare bankruptcy, will sell core business to US investors|last1=MacArthur|first1=Daniel|date=17 November 2009|publisher=scienceblogs.com|url=http://scienceblogs.com/geneticfuture/2009/11/decode_genetics_finally_goes_u.php|accessdate=29 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120515111234/http://scienceblogs.com/geneticfuture/2009/11/decode_genetics_finally_goes_u.php|archivedate=15 May 2012|df=}}</ref> and as of January 2015 its systems and databanks had been spun off to another company NextCODE Health,<ref>Proffit, Allison (24 October 2013) [http://www.bio-itworld.com/els/2013/10/24/nextcode-health-launches-decode-platform.html NextCODE Health Launches deCODE's Clinical Genomics Platform] Bio IT World, Retrieved 28 January 2015</ref> owned by [[WuXi PharmaTech]].<ref>(9 January 2015) [http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/wuxi-pharmatech-acquires-nextcode-health-to-create-global-leader-in-genomic-medicine-300018311.html WuXi PharmaTech Acquires NextCODE Health to Create Global Leader in Genomic Medicine] PR Newswire, Retrieved 28 January 2015</ref> In 2015, the Chief Executive of deCODE said that with the DNA and family tree they had data collected in Iceland, they could in theory predict which Icelandic women had a high risk of getting breast cancer. However the data had been collected anonymously.<ref>Gallagher, James (26 March 2015) [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-32024158 DNA of 'an entire nation' assessed] BBC News, Health, Retrieved 29 March 2015</ref>
The [[Estonian Genome Project]] was started in 2000 with the aim of improving public health in the country.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.genomenewsnetwork.org/articles/10_00/Estonias_genebank.shtml |title=Give and Take—Estonia's New Model for a National Gene Bank |first=Lane |last=Frank |work=genomenewsnetwork.org |date=6 October 2000 |accessdate=29 January 2015}}</ref> Initially it was hoped to obtain biological samples and health data from 70% of the 1.4 million population of Estonia.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Frank | first1 = L. | title = GENETIC DISEASE:Storm Brews over Gene Bank of Estonian Population | journal = Science | volume = 286 | issue = 5443 | pages = 1262–1263 | year = 1999 | pmid = 10610525 | doi = 10.1126/science.286.5443.1262}}</ref> The project ran into financial difficulties and, as of December 2013, the project had data from 52,000 adult gene donors and the aim had been adjusted downwards to collect genealogical, genome and health data from 5% of the population.<ref name = IntJEpid>{{Cite journal | pmid = 24518929 | year = 2014 | author1 = Leitsalu | first1 = L | title = Cohort Profile: Estonian Biobank of the Estonian Genome Center, University of Tartu | journal = International Journal of Epidemiology | volume = 44 | issue = 4 | pages = 1137–47 | last2 = Haller | first2 = T | last3 = Esko | first3 = T | last4 = Tammesoo | first4 = M. L. | last5 = Alavere | first5 = H | last6 = Snieder | first6 = H | last7 = Perola | first7 = M | last8 = Ng | first8 = P. C. | last9 = Mägi | first9 = R | last10 = Milani | first10 = L | last11 = Fischer | first11 = K | last12 = Metspalu | first12 = A | doi = 10.1093/ije/dyt268 }}</ref>
The [[China Kadoorie Biobank]] study collected questionnaire and physical data and blood samples on 510,000 men and women aged between 30 and 79 from 10 regions in China between 2004-2008 with the aim of investigating chronic diseases (e.g. heart attack, stroke, diabetes, and cancer). Participants have been linked to mortality registers and nationwide health systems and a sub-group of 25,000 are retested every few years.<ref>(2014) [http://www.ckbiobank.org/site/ China Kadoorie Biobank] University of Oxford, Retrieved 28 January 2015</ref><ref name=":0" />
In 2006, a similar project by the U.S. [[National Human Genome Research Institute]] known as "The American project" was proposed.<ref name="ns" /> In 2015 the US [[National Institutes of Health]] launched the "[[Precision Medicine Initiative]]" which was renamed "All of Us" in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://allofus.nih.gov/|title=National Institutes of Health (NIH) — All of Us web page|last=|first=|date=2018|website=US Department of Health and Human Resources - National Institutes of Health|language=en|access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref> This project had enrolled over 10,000 people by January 2018 in a pilot phase and aimed to sign up one million participants by 2022.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/paloma/the-health-202/2018/01/16/the-health-202-nih-wants-1-million-americans-to-contribute-to-new-pool-of-gene-data/5a5ba45a30fb0469e8840135/|title=The Health 202: NIH wants 1 million Americans to contribute to new pool of gene data|last=Cunningham|first=Paige Winfield|date=2018-01-16|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-01-20|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
The Lifelines cohort study was started in 2006 and collects data and samples on 167,000 children, adults and elderly from the Northern part of [[Netherlands|the Netherlands]]. The aim of Lifelines is to constitute a biobank that provides high-quality data and samples by following all participants over a period of at least 30 years.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Scholtens|first=Salome|last2=Smidt|first2=Nynke|last3=Swertz|first3=Morris A.|last4=Bakker|first4=Stephan JL|last5=Dotinga|first5=Aafje|last6=Vonk|first6=Judith M.|last7=van Dijk|first7=Freerk|last8=Zon|first8=Van|last9=Kr|first9=Sander|date=2015-08-01|title=Cohort Profile: LifeLines, a three-generation cohort study and biobank|url=https://academic.oup.com/ije/article/44/4/1172/667081|journal=International Journal of Epidemiology|language=en|volume=44|issue=4|pages=1172–1180|doi=10.1093/ije/dyu229|issn=0300-5771}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.lifelines.nl/researcher/biobank-lifelines|title=cohort study and biobank|access-date=2018-05-18|language=nl-NL}}</ref> The collected data offer excellent opportunities for studies worldwide unraveling the etiology of multifactorial diseases focusing on multifactor risk factors. This will help to move forward to more personalised health care and prevention and to answer the question why some people grow old in good health while others contract diseases.
The Finngen project was launched in 2018 with the aim of collecting biological samples from 500,000 participants in Finland over six years with the aim of improving health through genetic research.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2017-12/uoh-fag121917.php|title=FinnGen, a global research project focusing on genome data of 500,000 Finns, launched|last=|first=|date=2017-12-19|website=EurekAlert!|publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science|language=en|access-date=2018-02-03}}</ref>
[[East London Genes & Health]] is a genomic research study of 100,000 people of Bangladeshi and Pakistani origin carried out by [[Queen Mary University of London]].

{{Infobox University |name = University of Public Health, Yangon (UOPH) |native_name = {{my|ပြည်သူ့ ကျန်းမာရေး တက္ကသိုလ် (ရန်ကုန်)}} |image_name = University of Public Health, Yangon.JPG |image_size = |motto = |established = 2007{{cite news | url=http://www.searo.who.int/en/Section1257/Section2181/Section2211/Section2357_13795.htm | title=University of Public Health, Yangon | date=2007-08-21 | publisher=WHO Regional Office for South-East Asia}} |location = [[Yangon]]
[[Yangon Division]], [[Myanmar]] |coor = |type = Public |staff = |rector = [[Dr. Khay Mar Mya]] |students = |undergrad = |postgrad = |part_time students = |website = {{url|uph-myanmar.gov.mm}} |affiliations = [[Ministry of Health (Burma)|Ministry of Health]] }} The '''University of Public Health, Yangon''' ({{lang-my|ပြည်သူ့ ကျန်းမာရေး တက္ကသိုလ် (ရန်ကုန်)}} {{IPA-my|pjìðṵ tɕáɴmàjé tɛʔkəθò (jàɴɡòʊɴ)|}}) is the premier university of [[public health]] in [[Myanmar]]. Founded in 2007, the university offers only graduate and post-graduate degree programs: Master of Public Health (MPH), PhD in Public Health, Diploma in Medical Science and Diploma in Medical Education.{{cite web | url=http://www.moh.gov.mm/file/Health%20Statistics.pdf | title=Health Statistics | accessdate=2008-12-30 | publisher=Ministry of Health, Myanmar | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081108035911/http://www.moh.gov.mm/file/Health%20Statistics.pdf | archivedate=2008-11-08 | df= }} The university is a member of the South-East Asia Public Health Education Institution Network (SEAPHEIN). ==Location== It is located at the heart of Yangon. The full address is 246, Myo Ma Kyaung street, corner of Bo Gyoke Aung San Road and Lamadaw street, Latha, Yangon. It is just across the road in front of University of Medicine 1 which was the oldest medical school in Myanmar. ==History== The university was founded in 2007 to strengthen the public health system (including human resources for public health) and infrastructure in Myanmar.{{cite web | url=http://www.whomyanmar.org/EN/Section1_102.htm | title=Regional Director participates in the opening ceremony of the University of Public Health in Yangon | accessdate=2008-12-31 | publisher=WHO Myanmar}} It is to help strengthen referral systems by providing technical back-up. Referral facilities for primary, secondary and tertiary care are important to effective community health work. Current dean of the school is Professor [[Nay Soe Maung]] who has served as an army doctor up to the rank of a colonel. He is ex-husband of one of the daughters of former Myanmar Junta head. ==Entrance== Physicians(M.B.B.S), dentists(B.D.S), nurses(B.N.Sc) and health assistants(B.Comm.H) are allowed to enter this school. Medical doctors and community/public health professions who are working in government service can enroll the UOPH via entrance exam. Applicant must be under 50 years old. They also finished the training of Central Institute of Civil Service in Myanmar. It is under authority of Ministry of Health in Myanmar. ==See also== * [[University of Community Health, Magway]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://uph-myanmar.gov.mm Official website] {{coord missing|Burma}} 4.Myanma Alinn Daily Newspaper in 2013-06-15 {{DEFAULTSORT:Public Health}} [[Category:Universities and colleges in Yangon]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Yangon Region]] [[Category:Medical schools in Myanmar]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Myanmar]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2007]]

{{about |the nationwide health information system developed by the US Department of Veterans Affairs | |VISTA (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates |date=September 2012}}
[[File:VA VISTA Architecture.png|thumb|The VISTA Architecture is an "Onion" with concentric layers of functions. At its core is a single shared database that all applications use. ]]
The '''Veterans Information Systems and Technology Architecture (VISTA)''' is the nationwide veterans clinical and business information system of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs. VISTA consists of 180 applications for clinical, financial, and administrative functions all integrated within a single database, providing single, authoritative source of data for all veteran-related care and services. The U.S. Congress mandates the VA keep the veterans health record in a single, authoritative, lifelong database, which is VISTA.
VISTA supports the clinical, administrative, and financial operations of over 1200 hospitals and clinics of the [[Veterans Health Administration]] (VHA).<ref>{{cite web |title=VA Health Care |url=http://www.va.gov/health }}</ref> The VHA is the largest integrated health delivery network in the United States,<ref>{{cite web |title=Nation's Largest Healthcare System Pledges Involvement in Healthy Hospital Initiative |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/opa/admpress.nsf/8822edaadaba0243852572a000656841/66a4a31db7c1ae178525703d0067d18b!OpenDocument | publisher=US Environmental Protection Agency (Sep 2003)}}</ref> providing care for over 8 million veterans by 180,000 medical professionals throughout the continental U.S., Alaska, and Hawaii on a single, integrated national healthcare information network of VISTA systems.<ref>{{cite web |title=Veterans Health Administration – Locations |url=http://www2.va.gov/directory/guide/division_flsh.asp?dnum=1}}</ref>
VISTA was developed by physician-developer teams within the U.S. [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Department of Veterans Affairs]] (VA), and as such has high physician user satisfaction. VISTA received the Computerworld [[Smithsonian Award]] for best use of Information Technology in Medicine in 1995, and continues to receive the highest overall physician satisfaction scores in national Electronic Health Record (EHR) surveys. In 2014 and again in 2016 national surveys of over 15,000 physician end-users of EHRs rated VISTA/CPRS the highest overall, above all other commercial EHR systems.<ref name="MedscapeSurvey2016">{{cite web|vauthors=Peckham C, Kane L, Rosensteel S|title=Medscape EHR Report 2016: Physicians Rate Top EHRs|url=http://www.medscape.com/features/slideshow/public/ehr2016|website=[[Medscape]]|accessdate=27 August 2017|date=25 August 2016}}</ref> Over 65% of all physicians trained in the U.S. rotate through the VHA and use VISTA/CPRS, making VISTA the most familiar [[Electronic health record|EHR]] in the U.S.
==Features==
VISTA is a patient-centric integrated inpatient-outpatient enterprise health information system. VISTA was originally named the Decentralized Hospital Computer Program (DHCP) because it was implemented prior to the existence of the Internet when all computers were decentralized. VISTA is an integrated database and application server, and includes [[CPOE|computerized order entry]], [[bar code]] medication administration, [[electronic prescribing]], and [[Guideline (medical)|clinical guidelines]].
Originally, VISTA had a terminal interface accessible only via a keyboard. In 1997 a Windows-based, mouse-driven [[graphical user interface]] called the Computerized Patient Record System (CPRS) was added. CPRS provides a [[client–server]] interface that allows health care providers to review and update a patient's electronic medical record. CPRS provides flexibility in a wide variety of settings so that a consistent [[Window (computing)|Windows]] interface is presented to a broad spectrum of health care workers.
=== Clinical Functions ===
{{columns-list |colwidth=30em|
