== Achievements == For its development of VistA, the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]] (VA) / [[Veterans Health Administration]] (VHA) was named the recipient of the prestigious Innovations in American Government Award presented by the Ash Institute of the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]] at [[Harvard University]] in July, 2006. The VistA electronic medical records system is estimated to improve efficiency by 6% per year, and the monthly cost of the [[Electronic health record|EHR]] is offset by eliminating the cost of even a few unnecessary tests or admissions.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Effect of the implementation of an enterprise-wide Electronic Health Record on productivity in the Veterans Health Administration |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract;jsessionid=7C274D08947B0625B3B540BEF2E70367.tomcat1?fromPage=online&aid=416400 | doi = 10.1017/S1744133105001210 | pmid= 18634688 | volume=1 | issue=Pt 2 |date=April 2006 | journal=Health Econ Policy Law | pages=163–9}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=VistA:Winner of the 2006 Innovations in American Government Award |url=http://www.innovations.va.gov/innovations/docs/InnovationsVistAInfoPackage.pdf |publisher=The Ash Institute for Democratic Governance and Innovation at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government |format=PDF |access-date=January 22, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114065510/http://www.innovations.va.gov/innovations/docs/InnovationsVistAInfoPackage.pdf |archive-date=January 14, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The adoption of VistA has allowed the VA to achieve a pharmacy prescription accuracy rate of 99.997%, and the VA outperforms most public sector hospitals on a variety of criteria, enabled by the implementation of VistA.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=BusinessWeek, Red Oak, IA (USA) |date=July 16, 2006 |url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/06_29/b3993061.htm?chan=tc&chan=technology_technology+index+page_best+of+the+magazine |title=The Best Medical Care in the U.S. How Veterans Affairs transformed itself – and what it means for the rest of us}}</ref>
VA hospitals using VistA are one of only thirteen hospital systems that have achieved the qualifications for [[Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society|HIMSS]] stage 7, the highest level of electronic health record integration,<ref>VA Testimony of Roger Baker before Congress on July 14, 2009 – Congressional and Legislative Affairs{{cite web |title=Open Source Healthcare IT at a National Level |url=http://www4.va.gov/OCA/testimony/hvac/soi/090714RB.asp |author=va.gov | publisher=United States Department of Veterans Affairs (2009)}}</ref><ref>HIMSS Analytics Stage 7 Hospitals{{cite web |title=HIMSS Analytics Stage 7 Hospitals |url=http://www.himssanalytics.org/hc_providers/stage7Hospitals.asp |author=himssanalytics.org |publisher=HIMSS Analytics |access-date=July 13, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726152036/http://www.himssanalytics.org/hc_providers/stage7Hospitals.asp |archive-date=July 26, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> while a non-VA hospital using VistA is one of only 42 US hospitals that has achieved HIMSS stage 6.<ref>{{cite web |title=Honored for EMR Sophistication, HIMSS Analytics Announces Stage 6 Hospitals |url=http://www.himssanalytics.org/general/pr_02262009.asp | publisher=HIMSS Analytics (Feb 2009)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Midland Memorial Hospital Uses OpenVista Clinical Framework to Improve Patient Care and Reduce Costs |url=http://www.medsphere.com/press/20080304 | publisher=Medsphere (Mar 2008)}}</ref>
== Licensing and dissemination == The VistA system is [[public domain]] software, available through the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom Of Information Act]] directly from the VA website<ref>{{cite web |title=VistA – VHA Office of Health Information |url=http://www.ehealth.va.gov/VistA.asp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170120183324/http://www.ehealth.va.gov/VistA.asp }}</ref> or through a growing network of distributors, such as [http://code.osehra.org/gitweb/?p=VistA-M.git;a=tree;f=Packages the OSEHRA VistA-M.git tree].
== VistA modules and projects ==
=== Database backend === VistA was developed using the M or [[MUMPS]] language/database. The VA currently runs a majority of VistA systems on the proprietary [[InterSystems]] [[Caché (software)|Caché]] version of MUMPS, but an [[open source]] MUMPS database engine, called [[GT.M]], for [[Linux]] and [[Unix]] computers has also been developed. Although initially separate releases, publicly available VistA distributions are now often bundled with the GT.M database in an integrated package. This has considerably eased installation. The free, open source nature of GT.M allows redundant and cost-effective failsafe database implementations, increasing reliability for complex installations of VistA.
=== Database projections === An open source project called [http://www.esiobjects.org/ EsiObjects] has also allowed the (ANSI- Standard) MUMPS language and database technology to evolve into a modern object-oriented language (and persistent-object store) that can be integrated into mainstream, state-of-the-art technologies. For the Caché MUMPS database, a similar object-oriented extension to MUMPS called [[Caché ObjectScript]] has been developed. Both of these have allowed development of the MUMPS database environment (by programmers) using modern object-oriented tools.
[http://vistapedia.net/index.php?title=M2Web_Overview M2Web] is an open source web gateway to MUMPS for use with VistA.
A free open source module from [http://gradvs1.mgateway.com/main/index.html M/Gateway] called MGWSI has been developed to act as a gateway between GT.M, Cache, or M21 MUMPS databases and programming tools such as PHP, ASP.NET, or Java, in order to create a web-based interface.
=== Patient Web Portal === [http://www.myhealth.va.gov/ MyHealtheVet] is a web portal that allows veterans to access and update their personal health record, refill prescriptions, and schedule appointments. This also allows veterans to port their health records to institutions outside the VA health system or keep a personal copy of their health records, a [[Personal health record|Personal Health Record (PHR)]].
=== VistA Imaging ===
The Veterans Administration has also developed [[VistA imaging|VistA Imaging]], a coordinated system for communicating with [[Picture archiving and communication system|PACS]] (radiology imaging) systems and for integrating others types of image-based information, such as EKGs, pathology slides, and scanned documents, into the VistA electronic medical records system. This type of integration of information into a medical record is critical to efficient utilization.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Imaging Economics, Skokie, IL (USA) |date=December 2002 |url=http://www.imagingeconomics.com/issues/articles/2002-12_01.asp |title=PACS Lessons Learned at the Baltimore VA |subscription=yes}}</ref>
It can be used independently or integrated into the VistA electronic health record system (as is done in VA health facilities).
== Deployments and uses ==
=== Role in development of a national healthcare network ===
The VistA electronic healthcare record has been widely credited for reforming the VA healthcare system, improving safety and efficiency substantially. The results have spurred a national impetus to adopt electronic medical records similar to VistA nationwide.
[[VistA Web]] collectively describes a set of protocols that in 2007 was being developed and used by the VHA to transfer data (from VistA) between hospitals and clinics within the pilot project. This is the first effort to view a single patient record so that VistA becomes truly interoperable among the more than 128 sites running VistA today.
A Clinical Data Repository/Health Data Repository ([https://web.archive.org/web/20091024045131/http://www1.va.gov/vadodhealthitsharing/page.cfm?pg=9 CHDR]) allows interoperability between the DoD's Clinical Data Repository (CDR) & the VA's Health Data Repository (HDR). Bidirectional real time exchange of computable pharmacy, allergy, demographic and laboratory data occurred in phase 1. Phase 2 involved additional drug–drug interaction and allergy checking. Initial deployment of the system was completed in March 2007 at the El Paso, Augusta, Pensacola, Puget Sound, Chicago, San Diego, and Las Vegas facilities.
VistA has been interfaced with commercial off-the-shelf products. Standards and protocols used by VA are consistent with current industry standards and include HL7, DICOM, and other protocols.
Tools for [[Continuity of Care Record|CCR]]/[[Continuity of Care Document|CCD]] support have been developed for VistA, allowing VistA to communicate with other [[Electronic health record|EHRs]] using these standardized information exchange protocols.<ref>{{cite web |title=Opensource CCR and CCD support for VistA based systems Project Update (Powerpoint slideshow) |url=http://groups.google.com/group/ccd-ccr-project/web/CCR-CCD-Update-090219.ppt |publisher= WorldVistA.org (Feb 2010)}}</ref> This includes the [[Mirth (software)|Mirth]] open source cross platform HL7 interface and [[Nationwide Health Information Network#CONNECT|NHIN Connect]], the open source health information exchange adaptor.
The VistA EHR has been used by the VA in combination with Telemedicine to provide surgical care to rural areas in Nebraska and Western Iowa over a {{convert |400000 |sqmi |km2 |adj=on}} area.<ref>{{cite web |title=VA Telemedicine Program Expands Access to Bariatric Surgery |url=http://www.generalsurgerynews.com/index.asp?section_id=410&show=dept&issue_id=588&article_id=14411 | publisher=General Surgery News Vol. 36, Number 12 p.40 (Dec 2009)}}</ref>
=== Usage in non-governmental hospitals ===
Under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), the VistA system, the CPRS graphical interface, and unlimited ongoing updates (500–600 per year) are provided as public domain software.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.va.gov/cprsdemo/page.cfm?pg=1 |title=Introduction to VistA software and the FTP site |publisher=US Department of Veterans Affairs}}</ref>
This was done by the US government in an effort to make VistA available as a low cost [[Electronic Health Record]] (EHR) for non-governmental hospitals and other healthcare entities.
With funding from The Pacific Telehealth & Technology Hui, the Hui 7 produced a version of VistA that ran on [[GT.M]] in a [[Linux]] [[operating system]], and that was suitable for use in private settings. VistA has since been adapted by companies such as [http://www.bluecliffinc.com Blue Cliff], [http://www.docstorsys.com DSS, Inc.], [http://www.medsphere.com/ Medsphere], and [http://sequencemanagers.com Sequence Managers Software] to a variety of environments, from individual practices to clinics to hospitals, to regional healthcare co-ordination between far-flung islands. In addition, VistA has been adopted within similar provider environments worldwide. Universities, such as UC Davis and Texas Tech implemented these systems. A non-profit organization, [[WorldVistA]], has also been established to extend and collaboratively improve the VistA electronic health record and health information system for use outside of its original setting.
VistA (and other derivative EMR/EHR systems) can be interfaced with healthcare databases not initially used by the VA system, including billing software, lab databases, and image databases (radiology, for example).
VistA implementations have been deployed (or are currently being deployed) in non-VA healthcare facilities in Texas,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?command=viewArticleBasic&taxonomyName=Knowledge+Center&articleId=9120541&taxonomyId=1&pageNumber=1 |title=Old code proves key to modern IT at Midland Memorial Hospital |publisher=Computerworld (Nov 2008)}}</ref> Arizona,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://waysandmeans.house.gov/hearings.asp?formmode=printfriendly&id=7233 |title=Statement of Matthew King, M.D., Chief Medical Officer, Clinica Adelante, Inc, Surprise, Arizona |publisher=US Congress House Committee on Ways and Means (July 2008)}}</ref> Florida, Hawaii,<ref name="VSA">{{cite web |url=http://www.vistasoftware.org/why/ss.html |title=VistA has been implemented in a variety of locations worldwide. |publisher=Vista Software Alliance}}</ref> New Jersey,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.medsphere.com/news/159-hoboken-university-medical-center-selects-medspheres-openvista-solution-to-improve-patient-care-achieve-meaningful-use |title=Hoboken University Medical Center Selects Medsphere's OpenVista Solution |publisher=Medsphere (Oct 2009)}}</ref> Oklahoma,<ref name="VSA"/> West Virginia,<ref name="bodtke">{{cite web |url=http://vistatour.blogspot.com/ |title=VistA Tour Announcement (Oct 2008)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nextgov.com/nextgov/ng_20090327_6548.php |title=VA's health record system cited as model for a national network |publisher=Nextgov (Mar 2009)}}</ref> California,<ref>{{cite web |title=Oroville Hospital to Deploy Medsphere OpenVista Electronic Health Record |url=http://www.businesswire.com/portal/site/google/?ndmViewId=news_view&newsId=20070116006067&newsLang=en |publisher=Businesswire, (Jan 2007)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Kern Medical Center Selects OpenVista |url=http://www.medsphere.com/news/144-kern-medical-center-selects-openvista-system-for-clinical-transformation-and-meaningful-use |publisher=Medsphere, (Dec 2009)}}</ref> New York,<ref>{{cite news |title=Brooklyn's Lutheran Medical Center Selects Medsphere OpenVista for Electronic Health Record Deployment |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2007_Jan_8/ai_n17096323/ |publisher=BNET, (Jan 2007) | date=January 8, 2007}}</ref> and Washington, D.C.<ref name="VSA"/><ref name="VistAWorld">{{cite web |title=Implementation of the Veterans Health Administration VistA Clinical Information System around the World |url=http://www.shepherd.edu/surc/cosi/VistA%20around%20the%20world%202008.doc |publisher=ElectronicHealthcare, 7(2) 2008: 83–89 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219001349/http://www.shepherd.edu/surc/cosi/VistA%20around%20the%20world%202008.doc |archive-date=February 19, 2012 }}</ref>
In one state, the cost of a multiple hospital VistA-based EHR network was implemented for one tenth the price of a commercial EHR network in another hospital network in the same state ($9 million versus $90 million for 7–8 hospitals each). (Both VistA and the commercial system used the MUMPS database).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.crossoverhealth.com/2009/01/30/ten-fold-10x-is-there-really-an-order-of-magnitude-difference/ |title=Ten Fold (10X): Is There Really an Order of Magnitude Difference? |publisher=CrossOver Health (Jan 2009)}}</ref>
VistA has even been adapted into a Health Information System (VMACS) at the veterinary medical teaching hospital at [[University of California, Davis School of Veterinary Medicine|UC Davis]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vista.vmth.ucdavis.edu/notebook/index |title=Demonstration of M2Web |publisher=UC Davis VMTH (Veterinary Medical Hospital) (Dec 2008)}}</ref>
===International deployments===
VistA software modules have been installed around the world, or are being considered for installation, in healthcare institutions such as the [[World Health Organization]],<ref name="bodtke"/> and in countries such as Mexico,<ref name="VSA"/><ref name="bodtke"/><ref>{{cite web |title=VistA use continues to grow in Mexico |url=http://www.modernhealthcare.com/article/20070112/FREE/70112018 |publisher=ModernHealthcare.com (Jan 2007)}}</ref> American Samoa,<ref name="VSA"/> Kurdistan, Iraq, Finland, Jordan,<ref>{{cite web |title=Jordan picks Perot to help implement VistA |url=http://www.ehealthonline.org/news/news-details.asp?News=Jordan-picks-Perot-to-help-implement-VistA&NewsID=15810 |publisher=EHealth (Jan 2009)}}</ref> Germany,<ref>Implemented in 1992 at the Berlin Heart Institute, VistA is still in use there.{{cite web |title=VistA News – July 18, 2006 – Harvard Honors the VA, VistA |url=http://www.mail-archive.com/hardhats-members@lists.sourceforge.net/msg16312.html |publisher=HardHats}}</ref> Kenya,<ref name="bodtke"/> Nigeria,<ref name="Nigeria">{{cite web |title=MINPHIS: Nigeria's experience using VistA, MUSTI, and other technologies in building their own national health information system |url=http://www.hoise.com/vmw/05/articles/vmw/LV-VM-10-05-19.html |publisher=Virtual Medical Worlds (August 2005)}}</ref> Egypt,<ref name="VSA"/> Malaysia, India,<ref>{{cite web |title=Global Tender for Computerization and Hospital Information System Jai Prakash Narayan Apex Trauma Center |url=http://www.aiims.ac.in/aiims/tender/TC-578-CF(Specification).pdf |publisher=Jai Prakash Narayan Apex Trauma Center}}</ref> Brazil, Pakistan,<ref name="VistAWorld"/> and Denmark.<ref name="Denmark">{{cite web |title=Læge: Open source vil kunne løse Danmarks EPJ-problemer |url=http://www.version2.dk/artikel/8238-laege-open-source-vil-kunne-loese-danmarks-epj-problemer |publisher=Version 2 (August 2008)}}</ref>
In September 2009, Dell Computer bought Perot Systems, the company installing VistA in Jordan (the Hakeem project).<ref>{{cite web |title=Dell To Acquire Perot Systems For $3.9 Billion, Creating Comprehensive, Customer-Focused It-Solutions Company |url=http://www.perotsystems.com/MediaRoom/PressRelease092009 |publisher=Perot Systems (Sep 2009)}}</ref>
== History ==
The name "VistA" (Veterans Health Information System and Technology Architecture) was adopted by the VA in 1994, when the Under Secretary for Health of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA), Dr. Ken Kizer, renamed what had previously been known as the Decentralized Hospital Computer Program (DHCP).
Both Dr. Robert Kolodner ([[Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology|National Health Information Technology Coordinator]])<ref>https://www.hhs.gov/healthit/onc/mission/</ref> and George Timson (an architect of VistA who has been involved with it since the early years) date VistA's actual architecture genesis, then, to 1977.<ref>{{cite book |title=Computerizing Large Integrated Health Networks: The VA Success |author=Robert Kolodner, MD |year=1997}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=The History of the Hardhats |url=http://www.hardhats.org/history/hardhats.html | publisher=Hardhats.org}}</ref> The program was launched in 1978 with the deployment of the initial modules in about twenty VA Medical Centers. The program was named the Decentralized Hospital Computer Program (DHCP) in 1981.
In December 1981, Congressman Sonny Montgomery of Mississippi arranged for the Decentralized Hospital Computer Program (DHCP) to be written into law as the medical-information systems development program of the VA. VA Administrator Robert P. Nimmo signed an Executive Order in February 1982 describing how the DHCP was to be organized and managed within the VA's Department of Medicine and Surgery.
In conjunction with the VA's DHCP development, the (IHS) [[Indian Health Service]] deployed a system built on and augmenting DHCP throughout its Federal and Tribal facilities as the Resource and Patient Management System ([http://www.ihs.gov/CIO/EHR/index.cfm RPMS]). This implementation emphasized the integration of outpatient clinics into the system, and many of its elements were soon re-incorporated into the VA system (through a system of technology sharing). Subsequent VistA systems therefore included elements from both RPMS and DHCP. Health IT sharing between VA and IHS continues to the present day.
The U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) then contracted with Science Applications International Corporation (SAIC) for a heavily modified and extended form of the DHCP system for use in DoD healthcare facilities, naming it the [[Composite Health Care System|Composite Health Care System (CHCS)]].
Meanwhile, in the early 1980s, major hospitals in Finland<ref>{{cite book |title=Medical informatics 20/20 (Case Studies of VistA Implementation United States and International) p. 276 |author=Douglas E. Goldstein |year=2007 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=JivKd9gTA5cC&pg=PT312&lpg=PT312&dq=M+database+medical+finland+Musti | isbn=978-0-7637-3925-6 | publisher=Jones & Bartlett Learning |display-authors=etal}}</ref> were the first institutions outside of the United States to adopt and adapt the VistA system to their language and institutional processes, creating a suite of applications called MUSTI and Multilab. (Since then, institutions in Germany, Egypt,<ref name="VSA"/> Nigeria,<ref name="Nigeria"/> and other nations abroad have adopted and adapted this system for their use, as well.)
The four major adopters of VistA – VA (VistA), DoD (CHCS), IHS (RPMS), and the Finnish [http://messi.uku.fi/tike/his/english/musti.html Musti consortium] – each took VistA in a different direction, creating related but distinct "dialects" of VistA. VA VistA and RPMS exchanged ideas and software repeatedly over the years, and RPMS periodically folded back into its code base new versions of the VA VistA packages. These two dialects are therefore the most closely related. The Musti software drifted further away from these two but retained compatibility with the infrastructure of RPMS and VA VistA (while adding additional GUI and web capabilities to improve function). Meanwhile, the CHCS code base diverged from that of the VA's VistA in the mid-eighties and has never been reintegrated. The VA and the DoD had been instructed for years to improve the sharing of medical information between the two systems, but for political reasons made little progress toward bringing the two dialects back together. More recently, CHCS's development was brought to a complete stop by continued political opposition within the DoD, and it has now been supplanted by a related, but different, system called [[Armed Forces Health Longitudinal Technology Application|AHLTA]]. While AHLTA is the new system for DoD, the core systems beneath AHLTA (for Computerized Physician Order Entry, appointing, referral management, and creation of new patient registrations) remain those of the underlying [[Composite Health Care System|CHCS]] system. (While some ongoing development has occurred for CHCS, the majority of funds are consumed by the AHLTA project.) Thus, the VistA code base was split four ways.
Many VistA professionals then informally banded together as the "Hardhats" (a name the original VistA programmers used for themselves) to promote that the FOIA (Freedom of Information Act) release of VA VistA (that allows it to be in the public domain) be standardized for universal usage.
[[WorldVistA]] was formed from this group and was incorporated in March 2003 as a non-profit corporation. This allowed the WorldVistA board of directors to pursue certain activities (obtaining grants, creating contracts, and making formal alliances) that they otherwise could not pursue as an informal organization. It is, however, an organization independent of the VA system and its version of VistA therefore differs from that of the VA's. Nevertheless, it maintains as an objective that its public version be compatible (interoperable) with the VA's official version. It has developed [http://sourceforge.net/projects/worldvista/files/ packages of WorldVistA] for multiple operating systems, including Linux (Debian/Ubuntu and Red Hat) -based and Microsoft Windows-based operating systems. Co-operation with the maintainers and vendors of [http://medsphere.com OpenVistA], another widely deployed open source public version of VistA, helps maintain interoperability and a standardized framework.
In 2011 the [[Open Source Electronic Health Record Agent]] (OSEHRA) project was started (in cooperation with the Department of Veterans Affairs) to provide a common code repository for VistA (and other EHR and health IT) software.<ref>{{cite web |title=VistA Community Makes Major Strides Towards Code Unification |url=http://www.openhealthnews.com/hotnews/vista-community-makes-major-strides-towards-code-unification | publisher=OpenHealth News (Jan 2012)}}</ref>
In summary, it was the joint collaboration of thousands of clinicians and systems experts from the United States and other nations, many of them volunteers, that the VistA system has developed.
== Supporters of VistA == <!-- (The paragraph below needs revision and references to meet Wikipedia standards. Please see the discussion.) A very important champion of VistA, originally called the Decentralized Hospital Computer Program (DHCP), was Congressman Sonny Montgomery of Mississippi, who served in Congress from 1967 until 1997 died in May 2006. The support Congressman Montgomery provided to the VA has been greatly missed. The first Hardhats were the developers of DHCP, called that because they felt like they were working on an "Underground Railroad" and there are great true stories and myths associated with its beginnings. Because the VA has had VistA they have been able to improve care and become more efficient with their resources and have been able to become one of the premier health providers in the world despite being grossly underfunded by Congress. Some people have suggested that the VA could become the nucleus of a United States national health care system. --> There have been many champions of VistA as the electronic healthcare record system for a universal healthcare plan. VistA can act as a standalone system, allowing self-contained management and retention of healthcare data within an institution. Combined with [[BHIE]] (or other data exchange protocol) it can be part of a peer-to-peer model of [[universal healthcare]]. It is also scalable to be used as a centralized system (allowing regional or even national centralization of healthcare records). It is, therefore, the electronic records system most adaptable to a variety of healthcare models.
In addition to the unwavering support of congressional representatives such as Congressman [[Sonny Montgomery]] of Mississippi, numerous IT specialists, physicians, and other healthcare professionals have donated significant amounts of time in adapting the VistA system for use in non-governmental healthcare settings.
The ranking member of the House Veterans Affairs Committee's Oversight and Investigation Subcommittee, Rep. [[Ginny Brown-Waite]] of Florida, recommended that the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] (DOD) adopt VA's VistA system following accusations of inefficiencies in the DOD healthcare system. The DOD hospitals use [[Armed Forces Health Longitudinal Technology Application|Armed Forces Health Longitudinal Technology Application (AHLTA)]] which has not been as successful as VistA and has not been adapted to non-military environments (as has been done with VistA).<ref name="BHIE">{{cite journal |journal=Government Health IT, Falls Church, VA (USA) |date=May 9, 2007 |url=http://govhealthit.com/article102670-05-09-07-Web |author=Mosquera, Mary |title=Full VA/DOD e-health sharing several years off |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926231729/http://govhealthit.com/article102670-05-09-07-Web |archivedate=September 26, 2007}}</ref>
In November 2005, the U.S. Senate passed the Wired for Health Care Quality Act, introduced by [[Mike Enzi|Sen. Enzi]] of Wyoming with 38 co-sponsors, that would require the government to use the VA's technology standards as a basis for national standards allowing all health care providers to communicate with each other as part of a nationwide health information exchange. The legislation would also authorize $280 million in grants, which would help persuade reluctant providers to invest in the new technology.<ref>{{cite web |title=Senator Endorses VistA for EHR Standard |publisher=Linux MedNews |url=http://www.linuxmednews.com/1137769193 |date=January 20, 2006}}</ref> There has been no action on the bill since December 2005. Two similar House bills were introduced in late 2005 and early 2006; no action has been taken on either of them, either.<ref>{{cite web |title=Library of Congress: Thomas: Bills, resolutions: S.1418 |publisher=Library of Congress |url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d109:s.01418: |accessdate=June 10, 2007 }}</ref>
In late 2008, House Ways and Means Health Subcommittee Chair Congressman [[Pete Stark]] (D-CA) introduced the Health-e Information Technology Act of 2008 (H.R. 6898) that calls for the creation of a low-cost public IT system for those providers who do not want to invest in a proprietary one.<ref>{{cite web |title=Representative Stark Introduces Health-e Information Technology Act of 2008 |publisher=Medicare Update |url=http://medicareupdate.typepad.com/medicare_update/2008/09/representative.html |date=September 16, 2008}}</ref>
In April 2009, Sen. John D. Rockefeller of West Virginia introduced the Health Information Technology Public Utility Act of 2009 calling for the government to create an open source electronic health records solution and offer it at little or no cost to safety-net hospitals and small rural providers.<ref>{{cite news |title=An Affordable Fix for Modernizing Medical Records |work=Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124104350516570503 |date=April 30, 2009 | first=Laura | last=Landro}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Rockefeller Introduced Legislation Calling For Universal Adoption of Electronic Health Records |publisher=United States Senator Jay Rockefeller |url=http://rockefeller.senate.gov/press/record.cfm?id=311951 |date=April 23, 2009}}</ref>
==VistA Derivatives== * [http://astronautvista.com/ Astronaut VistA] – an installer suite for different versions of VistA, with multiple enhancements and bug fixes. * [[WorldVistA]] or [http://www.worldvista.org WorldVistA EHR] * [http://medsphere.com/ OpenVistA] (Medsphere) * [http://osehra.org Osehra-Vista] (OSEHRA) * [http://www.vxvista.org/ vxVistA] (Document Storage Systems, Inc.)
An effort has been made by the Astronaut team, WorldVistA team, members of the VistA Software Alliance, and the OSEHRA to standardize structure between the platform derivatives to allow for future interoperability, as part of the vision for a national healthcare network record system.{{Citation needed |date=December 2012}}
==See also== * [[Electronic health record]] * [[Health informatics]] * [[MUMPS]] * [[Veterans Health Administration]] * [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]] * [[FileMan]] * [[VA Kernel]] * [[GNUmed]] * [[GNU Health]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://vistapedia.net/index.php?title=Main_Page Vistapedia: the WorldVistA Wiki] * [http://www.hardhats.org Hardhats] – a VistA user community * [http://groups.google.com/group/Hardhats/ Hardhats Google Group] – a forum to discuss installation of WorldVistA * [http://wiki.laptop.org/go/VistA_Monograph_Wiki VistA Monograph wiki] (OLPC project) * [http://www.vistasoftware.org VistA Software Alliance] (VistA Software Vendor Trade Organization) * [http://www.osehra.org OSEHRA] – Open Source Electronic Health Record Agent, a code repository for VistA * [http://www.pacifichui.org/ The Pacific Telehealth & Technology Hui] * [http://www1.va.gov/imaging/page.cfm?pg=3 VistA Imaging overview] (Department of Veterans Affairs) * [http://www1.va.gov/VADODHEALTHITSHARING/Bidirectional_Health_Information_Exchange.asp BHIE] – Bidirectional Health Information Exchange protocols of the Department of Veterans Affairs * [http://www.fredtrotter.com/2007/11/10/why-is-vista-good-the-vista-open-source-development-model/ Why is VistA good?] * {{cite web | title=Innovations Award | url= http://www.ashinstitute.harvard.edu/Ash/pdfs/VAVistAreleasefinale.pdf | accessdate=July 25, 2006 |format=PDF}} – Ash Institute News Release * [http://liutiu.narod.ru/VistA_Glossary.htm VistA Glossary] LiuTiu Medical Administrative Lexicon (Brokenly translated into English from Russian) * [http://ubuntudoctorsguild.dyndns.org/public/index.php/Main_Page#Electronic_Medical_Records_.28EMRs.2FEHRs.29 Ubuntu Doctors Guild] Information about implementing VistA and other open source medical applications in Ubuntu Linux *[https://www.politico.com/agenda/story/2017/03/vista-computer-history-va-conspiracy-000367 A 40-year 'conspiracy' at the VA] Politico, 2017
Videos about VistA: * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090523104947/http://blip.tv/file/405389 History of Vista Architecture] Interview with Tom Munnecke * [http://blip.tv/file/1187881 Interview with Rob Kolodner] regarding VistA's potential for the [[National Health Information Network]] * [http://blip.tv/file/1187881 Impact of VistA] Interview with Dr. Ross Fletcher * [http://blip.tv/file/1188770 Interview with Philip Longman] * [http://blip.tv/file/1187514/ Events leading up to the development of VistA] Interview with Henry Heffernan * [http://blip.tv/file/1187241/ History of Vista] Interview with Ruth Dayhoff * [http://blip.tv/file/1186772/ Early development of the Decentralized Hospital Computer Program] Interview with Marty Johnson * [http://blip.tv/file/1188922/ Early days of the VA "Underground Railroad"] Interview with Tom Munnecke

page.title: Wishing Well: Water for the World

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=November 2011}} [[File:Wishing Well Logo.jpeg|thumb|Wishing Well Logo]] {{Infobox organization | name = Wishing Well: Water for the World | type = Non-governmental organization | founded_date = 2006 | founder = Ryan Groves, Jason Harvey, and Brendan Groves | location = [[Oklahoma City]] | area_served = 10 countries | mission = Empower communities to transform their world by providing water to those in need. | homepage = [http://www.wishingwellafrica.com/ www.wishforwater.com] }} '''Wishing Well: Water for the World''' is 501(c)(3) public charity, based in [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]]. Wishing Well: Water for the World was founded by college students at [[Pepperdine University]] in spring of 2006, the headquarters then moved to [[Oklahoma Christian University]] in the fall of 2006. Wishing Well: Water for the World empowers communities to transform their world by providing water to those in need.{{cite web|title=Wishing Well: Water for the World|url=http://www.wishingwellafrica.com/|publisher=Wishingwellaferica.com|accessdate=5 July 2011}} == History == '''Pepperdine University'''
Students at Pepperdine raised the money for three water wells funded through [[Blood Water Mission]]. Their efforts were noticed by [[Laura Bush]] 2007, she said, "…Clean water, it's so simple. It's something all of us can do, even college students. We can go to a village and build a water well, and we know things are going to be better than they were. So far, students (at Pepperdine University) have raised about $14,000 for Wishing Well. Your efforts have already helped put a clean-water pump in a rural town near Nairobi, and this summer, two more will be installed — another in Kenya, and one in The Gambia, near a World Bible School. Because of your generosity, hundreds of children will have access to clean water — and the hope of good health." {{cite web|last=Bush|first=Laura|title=First Lady|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/04/20070428-4.html|publisher=Whitehousegeorgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov.gov|accessdate=20 June 2011}} '''Oklahoma Christian University'''
In fall of 2006, the headquarters of Wishing Well moved to Oklahoma Christian University in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. Students at Oklahoma Christian University started fundraising by putting on a night of prayer and hosting a student art gallery on campus. Oklahoma Christian students Ryan Groves, Travis Hughes, Taylor Walling, Joshua Burgin, Whitney Parker, and Chase Layman used a portion of the funds raised to fly to Rwanda to film a documentary about the water crisis. Wishing Well grew, and they started chapters at schools and churches around the United States.{{cite web|title=The Talon|url=http://blogs.oc.edu/talon/cat/wishing_well_wishes_for_water_and_workers/|publisher=oc.edu|accessdate=23 June 2011}} ==National events == '''Town Hall Theater'''
Wishing Wells documentary, One Drop, premiered at the town hall theater on Time Square in NewYork City. The NON, Rock Wagon Live Painters, David Bowden Poetry and Ester Havens Photography{{cite web|last=Havens|first=Esther|title=OC – WISHING WELL AFRICA: WATER FOR THE WORLD FUNDRAISING EVENT !|url=http://estherhavens.com/blog/archives/512|publisher=Estherhaven.com|accessdate=5 July 2011}} were featured at the event.{{cite web|title=Wishing Well Documentary Trailer: One Drop|url=http://video.liveearth.org/video/Wishing-Well-Documentary-Traile|publisher=Live Earth|accessdate=20 June 2011}} '''Creativity World Forum'''
Wishing Well partnered with Toms shoes in November 2010, where 250 High School and College students walked barefoot for 2 miles through downtown Oklahoma City, carrying water jugs. They walked on stage where they were joined by [[Hanson (band)|Hanson]], [[Sandi Patty]] and Eric Logan.{{cite web|title=Water Walk: Creativity World Forum|url=http://newsok.com/water-walk-creativity-world-forum/multimedia/video/677724281001|publisher=NewsOK|accessdate=20 June 2011}} '''TedXOKC'''
Ryan Groves spoke about responding to crisis with creativity. He outlined using human empowerment to end the water crisis.{{cite web|title=TEDxOKC - Ryan Groves - "How to Save the World: Responding to Crisis with Creativity"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YOYdrUzsQEM|publisher=TEDX.com|accessdate=20 June 2011}}{{cite web|title=OC Alumni and Student Featured at First TEDxOKC Conference|url=http://blogs.oc.edu/ocnews/oc_alumni_and_student_featured_at_first_tedxokc_conference/|publisher=oc.edu|accessdate=5 July 2011}} ==Work with other charities ==
WIshing well has funded several wells through Blood Water Mission, Living Water International and Charity: Water. Wishing Well has shared some of their photos from their Africa trip with Charity: Water and held events with them. Wishing Well partnered with [[Blake Mycoskie]] in a barefoot water walk in downtown Oklahoma City. Wishing Well has partnered with Water 4 to dig several well in [[Rwanda]]. == Operations == Currently, Wishing Well is building hand dug wells that only use materials that are sourceable in country. When they go to dig a well, they teach residents how to build a well so they can start a well digging companies.{{cite web|title=Wishing Well: Water for the World|url=http://greatnonprofits.org/reviews/profile2/wishing-well-water-for-the-world|publisher=Great NonProfits|accessdate=1 July 2011}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wishing Well: Water for the World}} [[Category:501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations]] [[Category:Water and the environment]] [[Category:Drinking water]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2006]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Oklahoma]]
